story:
///////////////

Nous avons atteint notre objectif de 500 $ HOURRA! Toute somme supplémentaire amassée d’ici la fin de la campagne servira à retenir les services d’un traiteur pour la soirée du vernissage! Un exposant le ventre plein est un exposant heureux!

///////////////


Exposition Juré Craché 

Les 18, 19 et 20 juin prochains se tiendra l’exposition des finissants en graphisme du Cégep Marie-Victorin à l’Espace Libre.

L’exposition se veut la conclusion de nos trois années d’études. Ce sera pour nous l’occasion de démontrer nos compétences aux différents professionnels de l’industrie du design graphique, du multimédia ou encore de la publicité. Cette exposition est une étape très importante dans notre cheminement professionnel et scolaire.

 

Ce dont nous avons besoin

L’argent ne pousse pas dans les arbres, et malgré la générosité de nos commanditaires et les nombreuses activités de financement, il nous en manque. Nous faisons donc appel à votre générosité afin de nous aider à amasser les sommes manquantes.

L’argent servira à l’impression d’affiches et de pièces de promotion, à la location et l’achat d’équipement, au paiement de notre équipe technique et à la location de la salle.

Si nous dépassons notre objectif de 500 $, nous pourrons réduire le nombre d’activités de financement, ce qui nous donnerait plus de temps pour polir nos portfolios!

 

Ce que vous recevrez

Afin de faire de cette campagne de financement un franc succès, nous mettrons à profit nos talents de graphiste.  En contribuant à notre exposition, vous aurez la possibilité de recevoir des affiches, T-shirts, macarons, flyers, une passe VIP, etc., ainsi que notre plus grande reconnaissance!

 

D’autres moyens pour nous aider

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement à notre exposition, nous vous invitons tout de même à partager par courriel ou via les médias sociaux le lien de notre campagne afin d’augmenter notre visibilité.

Aussi, si vous connaissez des entreprises que nous pourrions contacter afin de réduire le coût de notre exposition, s’il vous plait, contactez-nous! Nous offrons de la visibilité à toute entreprise qui voudrait contribuer au bon déroulement de notre exposition!

 

*** TOUS LES ENVOIS SERONT FAITS AU DÉBUT DU MOIS DE JUILLET ***

*** AJOUTEZ TOUJOURS 3$ DE PLUS QUE LA VALEUR DE VOTRE SÉLECTION AFIN DE COUVRIR LES FRAIS DE LIVRAISONS ***

Cette exposition est une étape très importante dans notre cheminement professionnel et scolaire.
 
Ce dont nous avons besoin
L’argent ne pousse pas dans les arbres, et malgré la générosité de nos commanditaires et les nombreuses activités de financement, il nous en manque. Nous faisons donc appel à votre générosité afin de nous aider à amasser les sommes manquantes.
L’argent servira à l’impression d’affiches et de pièces de promotion, à la location et l’achat d’équipement, au paiement de notre équipe technique et à la location de la salle.
Si nous dépassons notre objectif de 500 $, nous pourrons réduire le nombre d’activités de financement, ce qui nous donnerait plus de temps pour polir nos portfolios!
 
Ce que vous recevrez
Afin de faire de cette campagne de financement un franc succès, nous mettrons à profit nos talents de graphiste.  En contribuant à notre exposition, vous aurez la possibilité de recevoir des affiches, T-shirts, macarons, flyers, une passe VIP, etc., ainsi que notre plus grande reconnaissance!
 
D’autres moyens pour nous aider
Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement à notre exposition, nous vous invitons tout de même à partager par courriel ou via les médias sociaux le lien de notre campagne afin d’augmenter notre visibilité.
Aussi, si vous connaissez des entreprises que nous pourrions contacter afin de réduire le coût de notre exposition, s’il vous plait, contactez-nous! Nous offrons de la visibilité à toute entreprise qui voudrait contribuer au bon déroulement de notre exposition!
 
*** TOUS LES ENVOIS SERONT FAITS AU DÉBUT DU MOIS DE JUILLET ***
*** AJOUTEZ TOUJOURS 3$ DE PLUS QUE LA VALEUR DE VOTRE SÉLECTION AFIN DE COUVRIR LES FRAIS DE LIVRAISONS ***

story:
Our Story

In 2009 Helltown Workshop moved into a space on the second floor of the Whaler's Wharf in Provincetown, Ma., before that it was a traveling art show, taking over restaurants and bars. The original concept was the creation of Mat Millett, Kris Smith, and Ethan Manach, other invaluable members include Joey Mars, Andrew Jacob, Shawn Morris, Scott Bruns,Lessposh. With a simple goal in mind, getting people excited about a night of art, new work from friends/favorite artists etc. Getting people involved in collecting art and becoming part of the art world. We enjoy showcasing the unseen talent of the Outer Cape, contemporary, outsider, lowbrow artists and giving them a platform to present their work and having a bit of fun in the process.

After 4 Amazing years in the Whaler's Wharf space, we have closed those doors as of the January 1st 2013.

Not to worry, HTWS will be opening a new, larger work space with the emphasis on the "workshop" aspect of HTWS. A 900 square foot industrial space that would be a perfect home for our working studio. We are a diverse group, so we need a multimedia workspace. A spray booth, a screen printing press, mold-making/casting and more, stuff you can't really make in your living room.

 

The Impact

In the short term, the studio will provide local artists the space to work on projects for upcoming deadlines and exhibitions.

In the long term, the space will be used to host art classes and workshops, rental space for visiting artist and a home base for "HTWS presents" promotions.

 

What We Need

We are looking to raise $10,000, which will help to maintain the space, contribute to the rent, utilities and supplies to get the studio up and running. We are all working artists, so we don't have all the funds to get the studio jump started.

Here's a breakdown of some of the basic costs that this campaign will help fund:

Rent is $950 per month

Utilities are about $100 per month

Construction costs to section off stations for screen printing and other work space will run approximately $600

Screen printing set up, press, chemicals, screens, ink (some of which we have, but are reoccurring costs) $1200+

Basic studio supplies lights, tape, paint, etc. $400+

It should take us about a month to get the Studio assembled, to be able to fully utilize the space.

Other donations will help to keep the space running smoothly, upcoming shows and exhibitions, etc.

This Is Where YOU Come In!

For your contribution, we will show our gratitude with the highest praise for your support of local art and artists AND hand made goodness from the new studio!

 
Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you are a Contributor, Collector or Admirer, as with all of our shows, YOU are the key part in keeping the art scene alive!

Please help us spread the word, tell your friends, family, anyone who may want to help keep handmade art thriving on the Outer Cape!

There are tools built in to Share this campaign with your contacts on Facebook, Twitter, Etc.

Thank You for taking the time to check us out!

story:
My name is Faith Grady, and I am a young makeup artist attending Make-up Designory (or MUD) in Burbank, California. Ever since I decided to attend MUD, I have had my eye on the Battle of the Brushes competition, and am incredibly honored to have been accepted as a finalist while still in school!

For those of you who are not familiar with Battle of the Brushes, it is a make-up competition held at IMATS (International Make-up Artist Trade Show) every year. You are eligible for this competition the day you begin classes at a recognized school, through 12 months after graduation. Each show (LA, NYC, London, Sydney, Toronto, and Vancouver) have 8 finalists for the Beauty/Fantasy competition and 8 students for the Character/Prosthetic competition. After they have applied their makeup (2 hours for Beauty/Fantasy and 3 hours for Character/Prosthetic), the make-ups are judged by industry leaders and 3 make-ups from each competition are recognized as 1st, 2nd and 3rd place.

Since I am a full time student, and most of the jobs I take are on a trade for basis (doing make-up and hairstyling to get pictures for my website and portfolio), this trip is an extra expense I don't have budgeted for. I will do whatever it takes to get to Toronto and compete in this competition, and that's why I'm asking for your help in aiding me to get there! Every little bit counts, and I would greatly appreciate any donation- whether it be your physical time, prayers, sharing this campaign or, if you are able, monetarily- in order to help me create the best make-up I possibly can. 

Thank you so much in advance for your help and support! I cannot tell you how much it means to me.

-Faith Grady

story:
Thank you first of all for showing the interest in my project. My name is Hamza, i have been a lifetime, activist of the Palestinian cause but for pro-justice globally for the entirety of my adult life. I am from the UK, and have always been a great proponent for artistic expression to help support understanding & to promote dialogue. Intifada Street is an explosion of artistic expression that aims to reflect the more than average discontent one feels about the injustice in the world. It owes a lot to the Resistance Art that has carried the fight in raising awareness of inequalities in the world for generations.

So in that spirit of revolutionary art Intifada Street aims to carry the flag and introduce resistance art to a new generation of people – YOU. 

Your contributions will help to bring this into fruition.


Your contributions and support will help in acquiring to secure a Direct to Garment Printer in order for this art to be printed on posters, tee's and also other apparel. This in turn will activate a wider audience to the struggle whilst at the same time create a space for future interactions with grassroots organisations to help support refugees so that they are able to tell their own story through artistic expression by ensuring the relevant equipment can be provided whether, for graphics art, photography, film etc.

For this dream to be released i am asking for your heartfelt support so that £10,000 can be helped to kickstart the project. Your contributions will ensure that a greater space will open for interactions globally to human causes of justice & equal rights.
Of course, if the relevant target is not achieved then rest assured that monies collected will be put forward towards a graphical book release whilst at the same time helping to ensure we are one step closer to achieving our initial goal.
Your contribution is invaluable for Intifada Street to go ahead. So please i ask you to assist by contributing or further by helping to share this with other like minded people and beyond anyone who supports independent revolutionary art. The success of the campaign is totally dependent on your interest & active support so that the narrative of OUR story is not pushed to the margins. Thank you for your time and support.

Kind Regards
Hamza
Intifada Street

story:
Who We Are

We are Cory Hinesley and Lydia DeMonte, Kansas City Art Institute graduates living and working in Kansas City, MO.

We are currently working with a local organization, KC+Connect, sponsored through KC Studio Magazine. The program seeks to give local artists the opportunity to network and display their art by helping organize events and publicizing them.

Through KC+Connect, we are participating in a group exhibition in September 2014 at the Hilliard Gallery in the Crossroads Art District.

Read more about us on the KC+Connect website:

Lydia's bio

Cory's bio

What We're Doing

We are each creating bodies of work and collaborating on sculptural installation.

We want to display our work using a nontraditional method. We aim to make photography more experiential through installation, using sculpture, lighting, and sound. We want our viewers to explore our photographs and the environment we create.

What We Need

It's important to us that we display our work in a professional manner. We want to create quality installations as well as beautifully framed art.

We have already budgeted for all of the expenses involved in producing this exhibit. Please see the table below for details on what we are contributing, and what we need your help with.

Why We Need You

KC+Connect has given us such an awesome opportunity. We want to contribute in the pioneering of this program by creating a quality experience and memorable work.

Kansas City has an amazing art scene and we believe in its potential. We want to help with the publicity of the program and other artists, and we believe that the best way to do that is through creating a special experience along with our work.

Art is kick ass, but also expensive to produce.

    What's in it for You?

    Besides helping starving artists? Some awesome rewards in addition to the warm fuzzy feeling in your soul.

    Time sensitive rewards:

    • Contribute $50 Go on-set with Cory Hinesley for one of her cray cray photo shoots and receive an 8x10 print of the final image! Snacks will be provided. Available July 1 - July 11. Maximum five rewards. 
    • Contribute $50 Go on-set with Lydia DeMonte for one of her amazing photo shoots and receive an 8x10 print of the final image! Drinks will be provided. Available July 12 - July 18. Maximum five rewards.
    • Contribute $100 Join Lydia and Cory for a fancy dinner party in the months following the exhibition. Food AND drinks will be provided. Black tie optional. Available July 19 - July 25. Maximum ten rewards.
    • Contribute $300 Have your own personal photo session with Cory and Lydia after the exhibition with a theme of your choice. Nothing pornographic. Don't be gross. Available July 25 - July 30. Maximum two rewards.

    Ongoing rewards:

    • Contribute $5 A thank-you shout out on social media!
    • Contribute $15 A postcard from the event with a personal thank you from Cory and Lydia in addition to a social media shout out!
    • Contribute $25 A handwritten letter from Cory and Lydia in addition to a post card, personal thank you, and social media shout out! Maximum 10
    • Contribute $35 A 8x10 print from either Cory or Lydia in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 10
    • Contribute $45 An 8x10 print AND a handwritten letter, in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 5
    • Contribute $55 A photo book from the exhibit in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 10
    • Contribute $65 A photo book from the exhibit AND  handwritten letter, in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 5
    • Contribute $75 An 8x10 print from both Cory and Lydia, in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 10
    • Contribute $100 A photo book from the exhibit and an 8x10 print from either Cory or Lydia, in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 10
    • Contribute $150+ A photo book from the exhibit, an 8x10 print from both Cory and Lydia, and a handwritten letter, in addition to a personal postcard and social media shout out! Maximum 10

    If the maximums are met for the ongoing rewards we will be posting shiny new rewards for those levels of contribution!


      THANK YOU WE LOVE YOU GIVE US MONEY YOU'RE GREAT :D

story:
Hello, I am Paul-Jules, and I am a 6 year old artist.

I discovered my passion for painting at a very early age: I was only four when I painted my first abstract work, which is now on display in my grandfather's home. Today, two years later, I am a mostly self-taught artist, already known for painting my flowers and trees. I had a small exhibition at a restaurant in Schweich, Germany, where I sold 9 of my works for charity, raising 210 € for children in Angola. 

Now my goal is to share the proceeds of the sale of all my artworks with those who are in need. The trip to Charleston will be my next step toward helping others. I intend to give at least 20% of money I make from painting with those less fortunate than me. 

I have already received international recognition for my art, and I plan to continue my career. I will participate in several international competitions, and I plan a new exhibition to raise more money for charity. 

What I Need, and Your Perks!

My 2015 dream is to participate in the Spoleto Festival USA and Piccolo Spoleto Festival this May. The funds you pledge will help me acquire the necessary materials, tickets and accommodation for myself and my parents. If I don't manage to raise all the funds, everything you give me will be used to purchase materials (acrylic paints, brushes, canvas, etc.) and to fund my way into art school.

Please check below the funding tiers and their perks.

    • €1 - Thanks for supporting the campaign!  You get my heartfelt gratitude for being generous!
    • €5 - Thanks for supporting me. Your name will be mentioned on my Paul Jules Butler website, and on my Facebook fan page. 
    • €25 - You will receive a thank you postcard, depicting one of my favorite artworks.  This includes the cost of postage, for local and international fans alike. You also get my heartfelt gratitude, a mention on my website and on my Facebook fan page.
    • €50 - You will receive a 10x15 cm poster on acrylic glass of one of  my paintings. This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies). You also get a postcard, as well as my heartfelt gratitude, a mention on my website and on my Facebook fan page.
    • €100 - You will receive an original artwork by me, 18x24 cm, acrylic on canvas. This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies).  You also get a postcard, as well as my heartfelt gratitude, a mention on my website and on my Facebook fan page.
    • €250 - You will receive an original artwork by me, 30x40 cm, acrylic on canvas. This includes the cost of shipping (and shipping supplies). You also get a postcard, as well as my heartfelt gratitude, a mention on my website and on my Facebook fan page.


    Shipping

    Shipping for all contributors is included in your perk, so no need to send anything additional!   Most everyone should get their perks by May 2015.  International shipping does take a little bit longer, so some of you may see yours in June.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    I understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  You can spread the word about this campaign to anyone you think might be interested. Thanks for your support in helping me to help others!

story:
The grain elevators in Western Canada have for years been referred to as prairie icons, prairie cathedrals or prairie sentinels and have become a visual symbol of what farming in this part of the country is all about. There were as many as 5758 grain elevators in 1933. These grain elevators dominated the prairie landscape for more than a century with every community having at least one.

Today many of these grain elevators are being dismantled, demolished and removed from the landscape. Railway lines are being abandoned and the railways want them removed for safety reason. It's just another sign of progress. Those existing today will soon be history.

I moved to Regina, Saskatchewan in Fall 2009 to work for Saskatchewan Wheat Pool (now called Viterra). The idea behind this project striked me when I visited the Moose Jaw elevator back in Fall 2009. Since then, I've been trying hard to make this project happen. I traveled to small towns in southern Saskatchewan with my photographic equipment, trying to capture whatever I can in the best possible way.

Project Details

These pictures will be exhibited in various art galleries in India starting from "The Art Galleries" at "Kerala Lalithakala Academy for Fine Arts", Calicut, Kerala, India on May 12 - 17, 2015 and at "Kerala Lalithakala Academy for Fine Arts", Thrissur, Kerala, India from May 21-26, 2015. These pictures will then move to various Art Galleries in India throughout the year.

I am raising funds to exhibit the images of the Grain Elevators and the life in Western Canada in high quality medium. The exhibition would be held from May 12 - 17 2015 at Lalithakala Academy, Calicut, Kerala, India

"The idea is get the images of these elevators to people around the world for future references as monuments and art and also to throw light on the prairie culture that depend(ed) on these icons."

The printing of art work for the exhibition is ongoing right now and will be complete by mid-April. Rakesh, the owner and Stanley, the manager at Elegent Traders, Thrissur, India has promised us to provide all museum quality framing and services for 20% discount.

The $6,500 goal will pay for the museum quality framing supplies and glass. The breakup is as follows:

$1000 towards the creation and shipment of all rewards

$2500 towards the frames and Archival Mat

$1500 for glass.

$1000 toward labor charges


Below are just a few pictures, digitally edited pictures from my project so far. They are photographs digitally edited to look like a painting which I am selling here as a part of the reward. The final project  will contain minimally edited  photographs in their original state in best possible quality.



A few other pictures from the project:


Thank you in advance for your generous support.  I am so excited about this exhibition. With your support, I hope to get these pictures to as many people as possible. Thanks again and again, it means the world to us!


About the Perks

$10- A Random Art work from above, send to you as post card

$25- A limited edition museum quality fine art print [8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] of one of the Grain Elevators of your choice (images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.

$45- Two artworks of your choice - Limited edition museum quality fine art prints(images above) [8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] of any two my Fine Art displayed here.+ Your name and Link added to the supporters page.

$60 - One limited edition museum quality fine art print [12" X 18"print on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] of one the Grain Elevators of your choice (images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.

$100- All 6 limited edition museum quality fine art prints of the Grain Elevator art works(images above)[8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] + Your name and Link added to the platinum supporters page.

$100- Two limited edition museum quality fine art print [12" X 18"print on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] of the Grain Elevators of your choice(images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.

$250- All 6 limited edition museum quality fine art prints of the Grain Elevator art works(images above) [12" X 18"images on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] + Your name and Link added to the platinum supporters page.

We promise to keep our contributors in the loop all along the way. We know that we can't do this without you.  If you ever have any questions, feel free to reach out to us and we will get back to you ASAP.
story_txt: The grain elevators in Western Canada have for years been referred to as prairie icons, prairie cathedrals or prairie sentinels and have become a visual symbol of what farming in this part of the country is all about. There were as many as 5758 grain elevators in 1933. These grain elevators dominated the prairie landscape for more than a century with every community having at least one.Today many of these grain elevators are being dismantled, demolished and removed from the landscape. Railway lines are being abandoned and the railways want them removed for safety reason. It's just another sign of progress. Those existing today will soon be history.I moved to Regina, Saskatchewan in Fall 2009 to work for Saskatchewan Wheat Pool (now called Viterra). The idea behind this project striked me when I visited the Moose Jaw elevator back in Fall 2009. Since then, I've been trying hard to make this project happen. I traveled to small towns in southern Saskatchewan with my photographic equipment, trying to capture whatever I can in the best possible way.Project DetailsThese pictures will be exhibited in various art galleries in India starting from "The Art Galleries" at "Kerala Lalithakala Academy for Fine Arts", Calicut, Kerala, India on May 12 - 17, 2015 and at "Kerala Lalithakala Academy for Fine Arts", Thrissur, Kerala, India from May 21-26, 2015. These pictures will then move to various Art Galleries in India throughout the year.I am raising funds to exhibit the images of the Grain Elevators and the life in Western Canada in high quality medium. The exhibition would be held from May 12 - 17 2015 at Lalithakala Academy, Calicut, Kerala, India"The idea is get the images of these elevators to people around the world for future references as monuments and art and also to throw light on the prairie culture that depend(ed) on these icons."The printing of art work for the exhibition is ongoing right now and will be complete by mid-April. Rakesh, the owner and Stanley, the manager at Elegent Traders, Thrissur, India has promised us to provide all museum quality framing and services for 20% discount.The $6,500 goal will pay for the  museum quality framing supplies and glass. The breakup is as follows:$1000 towards the creation and shipment of all rewards$2500 towards the frames and Archival Mat$1500 for glass.$1000 toward labor chargesBelow are just a few pictures, digitally edited pictures from my project so far. They are photographs digitally edited to look like a painting which I am selling here as a part of the reward. The final project  will contain minimally edited  photographs in their original state in best possible quality.A few other pictures from the project:Thank you in advance for your generous support.  I am so excited about this exhibition. With your support, I hope to get these pictures to as many people as possible. Thanks again and again, it means the world to us!About the Perks$10- A Random Art work from above, send to you as post card$25- A limited edition museum quality fine art print [8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] of one of the Grain Elevators of your choice (images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.$45- Two artworks of your choice - Limited edition museum quality fine art prints(images above) [8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] of any two my Fine Art displayed here.+ Your name and Link added to the supporters page.$60 - One limited edition museum quality fine art print [12" X 18"print on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] of one the Grain Elevators of your choice (images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.$100- All 6 limited edition museum quality fine art prints of the Grain Elevator art works(images above)[8" X 10"image on an 8.5"X 11" Paper] + Your name and Link added to the platinum supporters page.$100- Two limited edition museum quality fine art print [12" X 18"print on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] of the Grain Elevators of your choice(images above) + Your name and Link added to the supporters page.$250- All 6 limited edition museum quality fine art prints of the Grain Elevator art works(images above) [12" X 18"images on a 13" X 19" Fine Art Paper ] + Your name and Link added to the platinum supporters page.We promise to keep our contributors in the loop all along the way. We know that we can't do this without you.  If you ever have any questions, feel free to reach out to us and we will get back to you ASAP.

story:
Hi, my name is Naomi Harwin this year I graduated from Norwich University of the arts where I studied Fine Art and in July I was offered a graduate residency at Airspace Gallery in Stoke-on-Trent.

SOLO EXHIBITION 

As part of the residency, in January I will have my first Solo exhibition.  In exchange for some of my art I would love your help in supporting the creation of the works to be shown in this exhibition. 

In August I moved from Cambridgeshire to Hanley to begin my 6-month residency with Airspace.  Over this time the program has provided a studio space and regular support meetings which has allowed me to focus and continue my practice, while providing valuable professional development.  Throughout the program I have covered my materials as well as living cost, but as I begin to prepare for the solo show, your support would be of great assistance in enabling me to produce the work to its full potential. Your donations will help in covering the cost of materials, aiding the production and installation of the work as well as advertising the show.  

I hope to make this a fantastic exhibition!

The first solo exhibition is a milestone in every artist's career, which is why it is such an exciting and significant opportunity.   While beneficial for my own career I hope that my residency show will also aid and promote the rising cultural profile of Stoke-On-Trent. As organisations such as Airspace Gallery aim to encourage graduates and artist to live and work in the area through their residencies, projects and events.  Looking to establish a hub of creative activities.

REWARDS

In exchange for your donations I am offering a range of postcards, digital prints, drawings and paintings and an invitation to my exhibition at Airspace Gallery in January.  All the rewards on offer give a taster of the works you will be supporting for the exhibition.  

Another way that you can support my campaign is through sharing it with your friends and family, this would be extremely helpful in expanding the awareness of my exhibition and campaign. 

MY PRACTICE  

Here is a little bit about my work.

My process-based practice sets out to investigate our relationship with objects and spaces, through the creation of my own forms. Most recently, I have been focusing particularly on the processing of visual stimuli, striking up a dialogue between a form and its represented image.

Examining the transference of information from a three-dimensional form to a two-dimensional plane, I explore the role of the representation and its ability to inform our understanding of our environment.

Studying and extracting the features of the three-dimensional form, each work reveals a snippet of information about the original object.  Both the form and its representations are deconstructed separated into layers of information, which then triggers the construction of new arrangements.


I have found that making work on this residency at Airspace, my process feels much more fluid and engaging and it has been the most enjoyable experience of making work I have found so far.  I have lots of ideas for works that I am hoping to soon materialize and I would be extremely grateful of your support.  

Naomi Harwin

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • This campaign is to aid us in building the the top deck, and for LED and an upgraded sound system.
  • For our top contributors, we will take you and 35 of your friends around SF on the bus!

The Impact

The bus is constantly being transformed, but as its third update, this will be the wildest! We are designing CNC-cut art for the outside, some of which is removable, to make the bus easier to transport.

  • This art car has been entertaining all over the US in the default world, but now its time to share her with the Playa family 
  • We previously have held hundreds of parties with the bus and will continue to do so on and off the Playa
  • 1st year we raised funds and bought the bus a new heart (diesel) so she will be dependable for burning man

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
    • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

    And that's all there is to it.


    This is the bus out over the last two years :)

story:
We are premiering our new motion picture Forgiveness to help raise money for a film festival tour.  Shot in Eastpointe Michigan.  Come out for a night of live entertainment, refreshments and a live Q&A with the director and cast.

FORGIVENESS

"Forgiveness" is a segment of the anthology feature film "5 Keys" made by five local metro Detroit filmmakers.  Created by Bosco and starring Lindsey Sullivan, Dan Hogan, Suzanne Pixley, Andrea DiGiglio and Robert Rovinsky.  Written by Christopher Siaens and Shay McLean.

By helping fund this project we will be able to submit to film festivals around the country while showing off the talent that Detroit has to offer.

ABOUT THE DIRECTOR

Award winning director and visual effects artist Bosco has been working hard for over a decade to transform his unique visions into motion picture stories.  Born and raised in the metro Detroit area, he has found the best and most talented actors and crew in Michigan and is now ready to share our local talent and his vision with the world. 


INDEPENDENT FILM IN METRO DETROIT

Help support your local independent filmmakers. 

A few years ago Hollywood breezed through town stirring emotions and building hopes.  Many local actors got stars in their eyes and had dreams of the silver screen.  Overnight the city and suburbs boomed with blockbuster movies coming to town. Then it was gone as quickly as it had arrived.  We still have a few films coming in now and then, but Detroit is not the New Hollywood like we were told it was going to be.  There's a bright side to all of this.  Our local talent is still here.  We were making independent films before Hollywood came to town and we're still here doing it now.  Let's not wait for Hollywood any longer.  It's time to stop importing our entertainment and start exporting our talent.  By coming to our premier and buying a poster or a dvd you will help local talent raise the funds necessary to exhibit and distribute our home grown films and you'll experience a wonderful night of entertainment that you're sure to remember.

RISKS

Forgiveness has already been filmed and our premier has already been scheduled. No delays are foreseen.

story:
Wandering – Inside the Artist's Mind is an exhibition curated by Colleen Seambos. This exhibition is a capstone project for her M.A. Arts Administration degree from the Savannah College of Art and Design E-Learning campus.

With this exhibition Colleen hopes to introduce a new young and talented pool of artists to the Toledo art scene. The exhibition will feature 5-10 artists who live and work in the Toledo area. All work entered in the exhibition will showcase each artist's unique abilities in medium, style and subject matter. The purpose of the exhibition is to show Toledo an eclectic mix of work without parameters. “Thinking outside the box” if you will.

The exhibition will run for one week in August 15 - August 22, 2014. The costs associated with the show are, gallery rental, installation and build costs, marketing and promotional materials, postage, an opening and closing reception and de-installation.

Please help make this exhibition a success with any size contribution. With your donation, Colleen will be on her way to realizing her dreams and beginning a budding career as an exhibition planner and designer.

story:
The Muckenthaler Cultural Center in Fullerton is teaming up with the City of Placentia and the local Boys & Girls Club to create the first ever Teen Arts Center for the City. We have raised $140,000 for programs we would like to create a music recording studio for teens in the center. We have received a $5,000 donation for equipment. Now we need $5,000 to bring in RYTMO, the experts in teen music recording programs to run the program. For more on RYTMO visit rytmo.org

At the end of the year the teens will create a CD of their music.

Won't you help these youth reach their dreams?!

story:
WE FOUND THE PERFECT SPOT FOR A NEW                 ~RECCENTER~


IT'S A CEMENT BUILDING LOCATED NEXT TO A LIQUOR STORE SURROUNDED BY WAREHOUSES AND AN ABANDONED LOT.

~THIS IS HOW YOU HAVE FUN GUYS~

WE NEED YOUR HELP!!

WE WILL PROVIDE YOU WITH FUN IF U HELP US!!

HELP US!!

U KNOW WE ARE FUN!!

WE WILL PAINT IT BLUE!!

IT WON'T BE CALLED RECCENTER BECAUSE THAT WAS A SACRED PLACE!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The money is basically going to first months rent and deposit. We are confident we will make the money we need to sustain the venue. We just need some help with start up cost and blue paint!

WE CAN RE-LIVE SUMMER 2012 OVER AND OVER AGAIN.

REMEMBER MOVIE NIGHTS??

REMEMBER CRAZY SICK, SAD WORLD PARTIES??

REMEMBER WEIRD NOISE BANDS PLAYING ON RANDOM TUESDAYS??

REMEMBER ALL THOSE PEOPLE YOU HOOKED UP WITH??

~RECCENTER WAS WILD~ 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

LET'S HAVE ANOTHER FUN PLACE TO CELEBRATE FRIENDSHIP. 

OAKLAND NEEDS THIS. 

I NEED THIS.

WE ALL NEED THIS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

WE WILL FIGURE OUR PERKS AND STUFF LATER

~ Mike and Lucas

story:
Roll 4 Iknitiative hits the road!


Gaming, crafting and having fun have been a part of my life since I can remember. This year I am planning to go to GenCon, but I could use a little extra money to make it there and back, have somewhere to sleep AND shower (this is very important to me), and eat the occasional meal of fresh foods.

We are not not without skills and talents in our household, so in return for helping me get to GenCon without robbing a bank, there are backer rewards which will be hand made for you and a little bit of voting fun.
I want to dye my hair, but I'm not sure which color to go with, so in addition to getting your own knitted goodie, made by my two hands, you get to help me decide which color my hair will be at GenCon. All of my Perk Rewards can be found in the gallery here or at  my Etsy shop for reference - https://www.etsy.com/shop/Roll4iKnitiative - so go check out the Wee Heroes I've made so far for ideas and back this campaign! For obvious reasons, it may not be possible to have all rewards before GenCon, since they are all made by hand, but depending on the success of this campaign, they should all be out within a reasonable amount of time, certainly in time for the winter holiday season, unless this just goes through the roof!

My husband, Andrew is a freelance writer for Rogue Genius Games, he will be traveling with me. The $500 Goal will be plenty to cover gas, hotel expenses and food for our round trip from Cincinnati to Indianapolis. The higher level perks will include pdfs of his own design, so if you haven't picked them up yet, this is a great way to get them!

Now for the voting and hair color! Which is really the exciting part.

I am going to dye my hair a color by your choosing! Each pledge will also count as a vote for the color you think I should sport at GenCon 2014. Your choices are Red, Blue, Green, Purple or my natural Brown. I will be doing this dyeing myself and it will go over my natural hair color, no bleaching involved, I'm not sure I'm that committed to unnatural hair colors, but I assure you, the color will be noticeable!

Due to limitations on number of Perks available. A poll will be sent out at the close of this Campaign for those who cannot vote and choose their Perks at the same time. That's okay, it just means we'll have to be super quick on the turn around come the end of the funding!
Not only will you be helping us get to GenCon and make important self-image decisions, you will be promoting my knitting habit by giving me specific fun things to knit for you!
Thank you for all your support! We would especially like to thank Owen Stephens for allowing us to provide Rogue Genius Games pdfs for Perk Rewards!

See you all at GenCon!

story:
Who?

Loser Slam is the longest running poetry slam in New Jersey, just nine years young.  National slam scoring is based on a 0 to 10 scale, with 0 being the worst and 10 being the best, but Loser Slam does it backwards, to humble poets while they "check their egos at the door."  This year Loser Slam hosted a season of FREE writing workshops, poetry open mics and slams at Two River Theater in Red Bank, NJ.  Poets wrote, edited, and polished their performances in order to qualify to compete in the final grand slam.  The top four poets of that final slam advance to the next level, National Poetry Slam, creating the 2014 Loser Slam Team: LowSir.


LowSir Poets: TruLyfe, Savon Bartley, Jonathan Ware, and Linette Reeman


What?

Poetry Slam is a competition started in the 1980s by a construction worker named Marc Smith. [“So what?!”]  The first National Poetry Slam took place in San Francisco in 1990, consisting of just three teams and has since grown to include 72 teams from infinity and beyond (but mostly, North America and sometimes other continents).  This year, National Poetry Slam returns to the Bay Area.


Where?

This year the National Poetry Slam is in Oakland, California, which is approximately 3080 miles away from Red Bank, New Jersey.


When?

National Poetry Slam 2014 happens from August 5th through the 9th.

Rewards will be sent between August and September.


Why?

Do you love poetry? ["Yes!"] Do you love artistic communities?? ["Yes!"] Do you love the people headlining this year's Loser Slam team??? ["YES!"] Do you want to see those three things come together in an explosion of creativity and general awesomeness?????? ["YES!!!!!!"] Well, then you've answered your own internal questions.


How?

Since May, we have been working with our coach MaryCae to hone our craft even further, while writing new group poems, while practicing relentlessly, while drinking water and eating Nilla Wafers.  We feel ready to represent our corner of the country, but we need help from our community.

As you could imagine, the trip to Oakland is a lotta bit expensive.  If you have extra change stuck in the couch cushions, a silver dollar that’s actually worth fifty, or some frequent flyer miles we could use, we would be incredibly grateful.

We some nifty prizes to offer our contributors such as TShirts, a team chapbook, audio of our poems, one of a kind artwork by local artists, and Linette will even dye her hair the color of your choice (sending a video and photos of the process).

Our expenses are roughly: $3500 for five people to flap their wings across the country in an actual aeroplane, $1000 for poets to sleep and shower at a hotel, and $500 to register the team to compete.


You can find LowSir performing at fundraising shows in New Jersey:

  • July 14, 2014 @ 6:00pm @ Revolutionary Lounge @ 1776 Hooper Ave, Toms River, New Jersey 08753 https://www.facebook.com/events/688961101159633/
  • July 21, 2014 @ 6:30pm @ Reactivation Series @ 656 Hamilton St, Somerset, New Jersey 08873 https://www.facebook.com/events/503700779731494/
  • July 30, 2014 @ 5:30pm - SEND OFF PARTY @ Coffee Corral @ 177 Drs James Parker Boulvard, Red Bank, NJ 07701 @ (FaceBook event TBA)

LowSir has some regional poetry slams happening in the near future:

  • July 12 @Suffern Poetry
  • July 25 @Nuyorican Poets Cafe
  • July 28 @The louderARTS Project
  • July 29 @Urbana Poetry

Please friend or follow us on social media:

  • www.facebook.com/LoserSlam
  • www.twitter.com/LoserSlam
  • www.youtube.com/LoserSlamPoetry
  • Instagram: @LoserSlamPoetry


Special Thank You's to contributing artists:

Maxine Snow, Grace Cooley, and Billie Haas for donated art, Liz Ditzel for our TShirt design, and Sue Works for our team logo.  These artists have selflessly donated their time, talents, and products to help us with this fundraising campaign. They are all the bomb and deserve all the love and hugs in the world!




If you can't contribute financially, please share this campaign, show Losers Love at one of our shows, or toss a wish into a well for us (not a penny, we could use that).
story_txt:
Who?Loser Slam is the longest running poetry slam 
in New Jersey, just nine years young.  National slam scoring is based on
 a 0 to 10 scale, with 0 being the worst and 10 being the best, but 
Loser Slam does it backwards, to humble poets while they "check their 
egos at the door."  This year Loser Slam hosted a season of FREE writing
 workshops, poetry open mics and slams at Two River Theater in Red Bank,
 NJ.  Poets wrote, edited, and polished their performances in order to 
qualify to compete in the final grand slam.  The top four poets of that 
final slam advance to the next level, National Poetry Slam, creating the
 2014 Loser Slam Team: LowSir.LowSir Poets: TruLyfe, Savon Bartley, Jonathan Ware, and Linette ReemanWhat?Poetry
 Slam is a competition started in the 1980s by a construction worker 
named Marc Smith. [“So what?!”]  The first National Poetry Slam took 
place in San Francisco in 1990, consisting of just three teams and has 
since grown to include 72 teams from infinity and beyond (but mostly, 
North America and sometimes other continents).  This year, National 
Poetry Slam returns to the Bay Area.Where?This year the National Poetry Slam is in Oakland, California, which is approximately 3080 miles away from Red Bank, New Jersey.When?National Poetry Slam 2014 happens from August 5th through the 9th.Rewards will be sent between August and September.Why?Do
 you love poetry? ["Yes!"] Do you love artistic communities?? ["Yes!"] 
Do you love the people headlining this year's Loser Slam team??? 
["YES!"] Do you want to see those three things come together in an 
explosion of creativity and general awesomeness?????? ["YES!!!!!!"] 
Well, then you've answered your own internal questions.How?Since
 May, we have been working with our coach MaryCae to hone our craft even
 further, while writing new group poems, while practicing relentlessly, 
while drinking water and eating Nilla Wafers.  We feel ready to 
represent our corner of the country, but we need help from our 
community. As you could imagine, the trip to Oakland is a lotta 
bit expensive.  If you have extra change stuck in the couch cushions, a 
silver dollar that’s actually worth fifty, or some frequent flyer miles 
we could use, we would be incredibly grateful. We some nifty 
prizes to offer our contributors such as TShirts, a team chapbook, audio
 of our poems, one of a kind artwork by local artists, and Linette will 
even dye her hair the color of your choice (sending a video and photos 
of the process).Our expenses are roughly: $3500 for five people 
to flap their wings across the country in an actual aeroplane, $1000 for
 poets to sleep and shower at a hotel, and $500 to register the team to 
compete. You can find LowSir performing at fundraising shows in New Jersey:
July 14, 2014 @ 6:00pm @ Revolutionary Lounge @ 1776 Hooper Ave, Toms River, New Jersey 08753 https://www.facebook.com/events/688961101159633/

July 21, 2014 @ 6:30pm @ Reactivation Series @ 656 Hamilton St, Somerset, New Jersey 08873 https://www.facebook.com/events/503700779731494/

July 30, 2014 @ 5:30pm - SEND OFF PARTY @ Coffee Corral @ 177 Drs 
James Parker Boulvard, Red Bank, NJ 07701 @ (FaceBook event TBA)
LowSir has some regional poetry slams happening in the near future:
July 12 @Suffern Poetry

July 25 @Nuyorican Poets Cafe

July 28 @The louderARTS Project

July 29 @Urbana Poetry

Please friend or follow us on social media:
www.facebook.com/LoserSlam
www.twitter.com/LoserSlam

www.youtube.com/LoserSlamPoetry

Instagram: @LoserSlamPoetry

 to help us with this fundraising campaign. They are all the bomb and 
deserve all the love and hugs in the world!
If you can't contribute financially, please share this campaign, show Losers Love at one of our shows, or toss a wish into a well for us (not a penny, we could use that).

story:
For ten years strong, we here at Voted Best Camp have kept the booze flowing like the graceful arc of Stan vomiting his beer with an artful tip of his cap. Have any of you ever stopped to wonder how exactly we manage to get you so very credibly craphammered??

Ask yourself...have we ever failed to give you masterfully crafted genitals on your face when you've blacked out on one of or many plush, and pristine sofas? Name a moment we have neglected to fully support you in all bad decisions, or attempted to restrain you from guzzling down motivation to drop-in on a massive half-pipe for the first time in your life.....

DO SOMETHING FOR US FOR A CHANGE!!

Help us make this grand achievement in wasted life worthwhile!

Every year we face the insurmountable challenge of bringing the hate to the Playa. The shoulders of our mighty benefactor are chiseled and strong...yet this weight can become unbearable. We here with Voted Best Family all do our best to pitch in and tackle the obstacles awaiting us at every turn.

But, with just a few dollars a day, YOU can help VBC become stronger than ever!!!

-All you give, we guarantee to put into the bar in order to give it right back to you in liquid form! 
-The more money we have, the more options you have for how you want to hate yourself tomorrow! 

-We have the Vampirates.

story:
Who We Are and Our Idea:

  • Culture Mill is a 501 ( c )( 3 ) organization based in Saxapahaw, NC. We develop projects that combine artistic and community-based initiatives. We foster collaboration, exchange and new models for creative place-making.
  • We have a 44-seat blue bird bus; we have readied it to run on biodiesel and we plan to put it to use for both regular public transportation to and from Saxapahaw, and also to facilitate original and dynamic site-specific cultural events. The bus itself was a generous gift from Saxapahaw residents and business owners: Doug Williams and Claire Haslam.
  • We will begin by commissioning four amazing new site-specific artworks (dances, installations, concerts), and taking audiences to them by bus in the summer of 2015; we will then begin a regular transportation route between Saxapahaw and Carrboro, NC in the fall. We will develop further routes as we build our capacity.
  • Using the bus for public transportation will not only bring people to and from work, school and existing cultural events in Saxapahaw, but will further our mission to cross-pollinate communities, spreading awareness of various cultural activities in order to grow a population engaged with art and creativity in general.
  • The bus is not yet named. We took community suggestions for the name of the bus at Culture Mill's launch party and our bus team will make a decision by the end of April.
  • Helping us get this project off the ground will launch an innovative program that both meets community transportation needs and supports new artistic and cultural initiatives. In short, it is a new model for creative communities.

What We Need & What You Get:

  • We need $10,000 dollars to get this program off the ground. This money will be split between the transportation and artistic elements of the bus. Funds will be used for 1 year of insurance, bio-diesel fuel, drivers, artistic costs for four site-specific events around Saxapahaw, NC, as well as maintenance costs.
  • All donations are tax-deductible, and rewards include free passes on the bus, growlers from Haw River Farm House Ales, dinners at the Eddy Restaurant and Pub, gift certificates with Haw River Canoe and Kayak Company, memberships to Saxapahaw Shiftwork Co-working Space, group and private yoga classes, private Argentine Tango Instruction, massages and tickets to a show of your choice at the award-winning Haw River Ballroom!
  • If we do not make our goal of $10,000, we will still use contributed funds for the same purposes; we will however, scale back the amount of biodiesel fuel, the scale of art events, the range of initial possible routes, and will rely more heavily on bus fares to get our project going. 
  • If we exceed our goal, funds in excess of $10,000 will simply create more capacity and greater possibilities in both transportation and artistic projects.

Who exactly will this project impact?

  • Those who enjoy dynamic and ground-breaking site-specific art events and want to be part of innovative ideas and new models.
  • Those who live in central North Carolina and would use a bus service to and from Saxapahaw.
  • Those who live in Saxapahaw and would benefit from a regular bus service to surrounding cities

Why We Can Pull This Off:

  • Culture Mill has an incredible community of support ready to assist this project: We are a member of Piedmont Biofuels Coop and enjoy professional consultation on the use of biofuels, we have good mechanics and we have completed an extensive community needs survey with over 100 participants lending their ideas and their vocal support for the benefits and possibilities of this program, and finally, the Saxapahaw community is no stranger to renowned, innovative and successful initiatives.

Risks & Challenges:

  • Our bus has passed NC state inspection and has been certified in good condition; however, unexpected mechanical issues can slow up the early stages of this program. Therefore we plan to keep a close eye on the mechanics of our bus with regular diagnostic checks, and to have a reserve of funds for any work that needs to be done.
  • We expect it will be on ongoing process to best understand which routes, times and projects fit the needs of the local community as well as the larger community. To facilitate this process, we plan to keep a fluid conversation going with our community, so that we can be flexible and responsive if problems arise and as community desires and needs continue to be clarf,ied.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't contribute, you can still help us out:

  • Spread the word about what we are doing. Share our campaign on social media (Indiegogo has great share tools) and by word-of-mouth, and when the time comes for us to launch our bus, come and ride it!

community desires and needs continue to be clarf,ied.

story:
Bridging the Gaps

December 26-30th, 2014   

In the last week of December 2014, Bridging The Gaps will bring together 150 teen boys and girls as well as 35 college-age coaches from across India for a 5 day sleep-away camp. We facilitate their bonding as teammates over sport (Ultimate Frisbee*) and art-based personal development activities. During the course of the camp, they overcome barriers, challenge themselves to develop skills and relationships and learn to celebrate the diversity of other's experiences.

Our camp intentionally brings together participants and coaches from various socio-economic, geographic and cultural backgrounds. In fact, the majority of our participants have never traveled outside their communities and would not be able to afford to attend camp without financial aid. Bridging the Gaps, is organized in collaboration with Pudiyador (pudiyador.org), a Chennai based NGO that provides safe and fun learning space for underprivileged children and young people. 


Why?

In India, we live in a tremendously unequal society. Our mission is to inspire a generation of Indian youth to bridge the socio-economic gaps created by poverty, gender and class, through a uniquely designed sport-art camp.  Our camps build and foster important values such as gender equality and open-mindedness, that translate into impactful benefits to the young campers, both players and coaches.

Where?
This December's camp will be held in Auroville, a small city located south of Chennai, about 2.5 hrs by bus/car and home to a vibrant international community including many talented and spirited Ultimate Frisbee players.  


We’ve done this before....and we'll do it again!

Our first camp was held in Surat in May 2014 where 120 teen campers and 30+ coaches had a 5 day experience of a lifetime!  This December we'll bring 150 kids and 35+ coaches to Auroville and plans are already in the works for our next camp in May 2015.



Our three tier model - how participants, youth leaders and coaches benefit:

Many of our coaches and youth leaders are from the same communities as our participants. They face a similar uphill climb with regards to poverty, gender and class based discrimination.

Our coaches and youth leaders attend ‘role model training’ sessions before camp begins. This prepares our coaches and youth leaders to facilitate meaningful discussions, teach the technical Ultimate Frisbee curriculum and conduct team building exercises.

Our participants attend pre-camp orientation which tells them what to expect at camp. For many, this will be the first time they have traveled to a different state or been away from their family; pre-camp orientation prepares them for their 5 day adventure. 



How you can help: 

  • Contribute to our Indiegogo campaign and help us to:
    (a) cover costs of transport/accommodation/meals for participants and coaches
    (b) provide a stipend for coaches                                                                                       (c) purchase discs, cones, whistles (coaches love 'em!), plain t-shirts (for teens to create their own jerseys!) and art supplies 
  • Spread the word
  • Help us get in touch with other sponsors


*Why Ultimate Frisbee:

For this camp, we have chosen to use Ultimate Frisbee because of how well it lends itself to promote personal development and intercultural exchange.

Ultimate is unique and best suited for Bridging the Gaps because it is:

  • Co-ed & non-contact:  Boys and girls play together on a team - an aberration to cultural practices within Indian communities where boys and girls rarely mix in sport.

  • Self refereed:  Contested fouls are settled through discussion between the players involved. This facilitates open communication between players and teaches participants how to resolve conflict. It is rare for a sport to allow for this type of player-to-player dialogue.

  • Spirit of the Game (SOTG):  SOTG is a heightened version of sportsmanship where competitive play is encouraged, but never at the expense of respect between players, adherence to the rules, and the basic joy of play. SOTG is built into the rules of the sport.


Meet the organizers:

Liz Haynes

Liz works in the sports for development field in India, Australia and the U.S. with a focus on innovative programming for underserved teenagers.  Liz also brings 10 years of expertise in nonprofit and corporate finance/operations to the team.  

Sangeeta Isvaran
Sangeeta, founder of Wind Dancers, is a dancer-performer who builds programs in marginalized, underprivileged communities using the arts in education, empowerment and conflict resolution. Speaking 8 languages she has  worked with NGOs and governmental agencies disseminating the Wind Dancers ethos across more than 40 countries.

Manix Narayanan

Manix is the Executive Director of Pudiyador, a Chennai-based NGO that provides after-school programs to underserved youth, and has spent the last decade growing Pudiyador’s programs across the city. Manix is an avid Ultimate player and has helped to grow the sport across India.

story:
ANNOUNCING OUR FINAL STRETCH GOAL:

THANK YOU! We have reached our 1st stretch goal of $10,000 and we still have more days to go! THANK YOU!!!!!!!

We would love to reach our 2nd stretch goal of $15,000 It will enable us to be fully funded for over a years worth of contributors, articles and documentation! This would be a huge bonus for everyone involved. Please continue to spread the word and contribute if you can! We are so excited to work on this project!!


Vignettes Collection

Hello, I am Sierra Stinson. I am a curator, facilitator and enabler based in Seattle, Washington. I began Vignettes in December 2010 with my partner artist Graham Downing in our apartment on Capitol Hill. It started off as a bi-weekly one night only exhibition space for Seattle-based artists to exhibit new works and installations. Over the last three + years we have exhibited over 45 artists. Now working on our fourth year we would like to split Vignettes into two parts - the Gallery still based inside our home AND the Collection...


WHAT IT IS:

Vignettes Collection will be an online venue exhibiting work by artists from Seattle and beyond. It will contain interviews with artists, studio visits, and articles about contemporary art in and outside of the Pacific Northwest. It will also play host to an eCommerce element where singular works by featured artists are for sale. We are interested in exploring what it is to represent the under-represented and non-represented artist and reevaluate a galleries relationship with the artist and the collector.


WHAT WE NEED:

With your donation we can afford to construct Vignettes Collection 's website, pay all of the contributors of the online venue: photographers, editors, writers, artists, and the website designer.


VIGNETTES COLLECTION CONTAINS:

STUDIO VISITS / INTERVIEWS

We will pair each featured artist with a writer for a studio visit and interview. These will then be published weekly on the site.

Paul Komada's studio in Pioneer Square, Seattle


Chandler Woodfin's studio in Sodo, Seattle

Artist Adam Boehmer in his studio in Capitol Hill, Seattle




SELECT ARTWORK FOR PURCHASE

To enable a collector in everyone we will feature a select piece of art by each artist in the Collection for sale.

The work will be photographed in two ways

1. product shot

2. in a home to show scale and within a lived-in environment



THE BUDGET

Total budget for Vignettes Collection is $15,000 and we are asking for $8,000 to undergo the first part of the collection.

Donations enable us to :

    - Construct and design the website for the Collection

    - Pay contributors : artists, writers and photographers

    - Lighting and photo equipment for documenting the art

    - The helping hands of assistants

    - The little things : business license, printer, paper, custom made certificates of authenticity printed at Bremelo Press

If we don't receive the minimum of $8,000 this project will not be funded. It is the very least we need to jump-start the concept and build the site to house all of these ideas and explore the possibilities!

STRETCH GOALS:
$10,000 : We could host more artists on the site as well as expand upon our features. We can create more content for the site within it's first year and beyond. 

$15,000 : We would be fully funded for over a years worth of contributors, articles and documentation! This would be a huge bonus for everyone involved.

THE PERKS

Donate $50 and receive a personalized Vignettes mug!


Donate $300 and photographer Megumi Shauna Arai will turn you into the subject by taking your portrait to be featured on the Vignettes Collection site along with a written profile / interview on you and what you would like to share with us! You also receive a print of your portrait.

                

           Portrait of artist Serrah Russell by photographer Megumi Shauna Arai



Donate $700 and we take 1/2 of your contribution and put it towards a piece of art of your choosing exhibited at Vignettes Gallery or in the Vignettes Collection! Think of it as a down payment on a future work of art by an amazing artist.

'Significant Objects' series created for Vignettes Love Party by Kelly Bjork and Joe Rudko



Please spread the word if you cannot contribute to Vignettes Collection. The more people who know about it the better it is for everyone involved. We are grateful of any support we receive and look forward to sharing the Collection with you in the near future!

Thank you for your consideration and have a beautiful day!


Cheers,

Sierra Stinson and Graham Downing




A FEW PAST VIGNETTES GALLERY EXHIBITIONS

"HANDLE WITH CARE" by Maggie Carson Romano and Adam Boehmer, 2013

'RE/SEMBLANCE' by Erin Frost, 2013

'We Are Happy To Serve You' by Sean McElroy, 2012

'i still know you' by Ian Toms and Mikey Rioux, 2011

LINKS
http://vignettes.us/

https://www.facebook.com/vignettesgallery

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/vignettes-collection/x/6287698



Special Thanks to Marcy Stone-Francois for filming our campaign video.
Graham Downing, Olivia McCausland, Aidan Fitzgerald, Adam Boehmer, for helping organize this campaign.
Eric Olson and Andrew Nedimyer who will construct and design the online venue.
Special recognition to artist Kelly Bjork for her illustration at the end of the video of Graham, Sierra and Dinah.

ANNOUNCING OUR FINAL STRETCH GOAL:THANK YOU! We have reached our 1st stretch goal of $10,000 and we still have more days to go! THANK YOU!!!!!!!We would love to reach our 2nd stretch goal of $15,000 It will enable us to be fully funded for over a years worth of 
contributors, articles and documentation! This would be a huge bonus for
 everyone involved. Please continue to spread the word and contribute if you can! We are so excited to work on this project!!Vignettes CollectionHello, I am Sierra Stinson. I am a curator, facilitator and enabler based in Seattle, Washington. I began Vignettes in December 2010 with my partner artist Graham Downing in our apartment on Capitol Hill. It started off as a bi-weekly one night only exhibition space for Seattle-based artists to exhibit new works and installations. Over the last three + years we have exhibited over 45 artists. Now working on our fourth year we would like to split Vignettes into two parts - the Gallery still based inside our home AND the Collection...
WHAT IT IS:
Vignettes Collection will be an online venue exhibiting work by artists from Seattle and beyond. It will contain interviews with artists, studio visits, and articles about contemporary art in and outside of the Pacific Northwest. It will also play host to an eCommerce element where singular works by featured artists are for sale. We are interested in exploring what it is to represent the under-represented and non-represented artist and reevaluate a galleries relationship with the artist and the collector. 
WHAT WE NEED:
With your donation we can afford to construct Vignettes Collection 's website, pay all of the contributors of the online venue: photographers, editors, writers, artists, and the website designer.VIGNETTES COLLECTION CONTAINS:STUDIO VISITS / INTERVIEWSWe will pair each featured artist with a writer for a studio visit and 
interview. These will then be published weekly on the site. Paul Komada's studio in Pioneer Square, SeattleChandler Woodfin's studio in Sodo, SeattleArtist Adam Boehmer in his studio in Capitol Hill, SeattleSELECT ARTWORK FOR PURCHASETo enable a collector in everyone we will feature a select piece of art by each artist in the Collection for sale. The work will be photographed in two ways1. product shot2. in a home to show scale and within a lived-in environmentTHE BUDGET
Total budget for Vignettes Collection is $15,000 and we are asking for $8,000 to undergo the first part of the collection.Donations enable us to :
- Construct and design the website for the Collection 
- Pay contributors : artists, writers and photographers 
- Lighting and photo equipment for documenting the art
- The helping hands of assistants
- The little things : business license, printer, paper, custom made certificates of authenticity printed at Bremelo Press
If we don't receive the minimum of $8,000 this project will not be funded. It is the very least we need to jump-start the concept and build the site to house all of these ideas and explore the possibilities! STRETCH GOALS: $10,000 : We could host more artists on the site as well as expand upon
 our features. We can create more content for the site within it's first
 year and beyond.  $15,000 : We would be fully funded for over a years worth of 
contributors, articles and documentation! This would be a huge bonus for
 everyone involved.
THE PERKS
Donate $50 and receive a personalized Vignettes mug!Donate $300 and photographer Megumi Shauna Arai will
turn you into the subject by taking your portrait to be featured on the Vignettes Collection site 
along with a written profile / interview on you and what you would
 like to share with us! You also receive a print of your portrait.                            Portrait of artist Serrah Russell by photographer Megumi Shauna AraiDonate $700 and we take 1/2 of your contribution and put it towards a piece of art of 
your choosing exhibited at Vignettes Gallery or in the Vignettes Collection! Think of it as a down payment on a future work of art by an 
amazing artist.'Significant Objects' series created for Vignettes Love Party by Kelly Bjork and Joe RudkoPlease spread the word if you cannot contribute to Vignettes Collection. The more people who know about it the better it is for everyone involved. We are grateful of any support we receive and look forward to sharing the Collection with you in the near future!Thank you for your consideration and have a beautiful day!Cheers,Sierra Stinson and Graham Downing A FEW PAST VIGNETTES GALLERY EXHIBITIONS"HANDLE WITH CARE" by Maggie Carson Romano and Adam Boehmer, 2013'RE/SEMBLANCE' by Erin Frost, 2013'We Are Happy To Serve You' by Sean McElroy, 2012'i still know you' by Ian Toms and Mikey Rioux, 2011LINKShttp://vignettes.us/https://www.facebook.com/vignettesgalleryhttp://www.indiegogo.com/projects/vignettes-collection/x/6287698Special Thanks to Marcy Stone-Francois for filming our campaign video. Graham Downing, Olivia McCausland, Aidan Fitzgerald, Adam Boehmer, for helping organize this campaign. Eric Olson and Andrew Nedimyer who will construct and design the online venue.Special recognition to artist Kelly Bjork for her illustration at the end of the video of Graham, Sierra and Dinah.

story:
My name is Ally Ahern and I am an 18 year old singer songwriter from Chicago, IL. I am currently working on my upcoming release. I have been studying voice for 3 years and currently attend Chicago Academy for the Arts, and have been writing songs since I was 9 years old.  

I want to create a visual world for my music to live in.  I have a very clear idea of the aesthetic world I want to create around my music.  I would be so grateful for any and every contribution I am able to get in order to put my vision to life. 

I will use every penny of the funds to pay for the video and promotion for the video.  Even if I am unable to reach my goal of $700, I will still use whatever money I raised towards the video.  I need this amount of money in order to make the quality of the video I’m looking to make, so I can reach a vast audience. 

Aside from donations, sharing this project and my music will help me more than you know!

story:
Dear Community,

After a recent detailed internal review of the tasks required for us to effectively manage Ecotopia, we have realized we need to reign in all other projects, including the Omage Sculpture Garden. The task of getting basic infrastructure on the land in a way that balances impact, sustainability and making it a safe place to visit has been massively complex. It has taken us considerably longer then we expected and we are still working through many logistics which need more time then we had hoped for. 

We feel that we have not be able to effectively communicate the vision for Omage and that it has been interpreted as a massive set of installations, which understandably concerns people. That was never the interest or intention, and if anything, we are aiming to bring artistic elements to the project which encourage interactivity and appreciation of the land. More to the point, it has been overreach for us to even try to facilitate this, when we are still struggling with the most basic aspects of opening the land again to safe and responsible usage. 

Funds that have been donated to Omage to date will be used on some much smaller art installations which focus on using materials naturally found on the land. All Perks that have been claimed will be honored at the dates offered in the campaign. We would also like to offer a small event for the family and friends that have made donations. This is a simple and easy way for us to show our love and proceed at this time. 

We appreciate everyones support and their comments. We continue to evolve with the process and it is a major learning journey for all involved. Our plan is to focus exclusively on the short term of putting water, power and visitation systems in place which allow the community to visit the land in a  safe responsible way. 

We will continue with the Omage Sculpture Garden vision once we have solidified Ecotopia infrastructure. We will keep you abreast of the project as it develops~

We thank you for your amazing support,

Ecotopia Staff and Omage—


Please contact Brian Tortora if you have further questions
