We will keep you abreast of the project as it develops~We thank you for your amazing support,Ecotopia Staff and Omage—Please contact Brian Tortora if you have further questions

story:
“I’m Sorry.”


Those are frequently the words that people say to me when I tell them that I’ve been teaching ninth graders for seventeen years.  As if I were being forced somehow into this profession against my will...dragged into work every day by some maniacal school gnomes or similar creatures.  The fact is, I love my job.  Teaching is not easy and anyone who says so doesn’t know what the heck they’re talking about or is a liar.  There are days when I laugh and there are days when I cry.  The hope is that you don’t break down and cry in the classroom, but I’d be lying if I said that hasn’t happened more than once.  I think that people forget that on top of teaching History (as I do), or Math, or English, or the Arts, or P.E., or World Languages, or Career and Technical Education, or Science, or any other discipline, that we deal with people and that we ourselves are...people.  We are not mindless robots who go in day after day and drill information (although some reformers would like this).  We have emotions and ups and downs like everyone else.  I think it is that humanity, however, which makes a good teacher.  We form connections with our students and colleagues.  I am still friends with some of my teachers from school and I have friendships with several of my former students.


I started with photography when I was at Bridgewater College in the early to mid 90s.  I travelled across the country with my parents in 1993 and took some photos.  My boyfriend (now husband) said they were good and encouraged me to take more pictures, which I did.  My father gave me his old Minolta XG-7 camera and I took a lot of photos through college, not really knowing what the heck I was doing, but it was a lot of fun.  Then graduation, and marriage, and job, and child, and no time for such hobbies.  Then, in 2008 I joined an online community called Whitechapel, founded by Warren Ellis.  This online community had several threads related to art, including S.P.I.T., the Self Portrait Image Thread, where people checked in each week with a self portrait, updating how they were doing and what was going on in their lives. I received a lot of encouragement from the community and bought a Sony Alpha200 DSLR camera and started...well...taking a metric ton of pictures.  I went out with reckless abandon and just played with my camera, taking pictures of anything and everything. I forced myself to undertake several long-term projects.  I completed two 365 Day self portrait projects as well as one project where I took a picture with a fisheye lens every day for a year.  I found that I enjoyed doing these projects because they forced me to get creative and do a lot of practical problem solving.  The teacher became the student through practice and self-assessment.


The past few years, I’ve had moderate success with my photography business, I have had several shows in the area of Harrisonburg, VA as well as art displayed in other galleries in the United States and elsewhere. I missed the discipline, however, of a long-term project.  I didn’t want to complete another self-portrait project because I had already done it twice, and I wanted to try something new.  During the work week prior to school last year, I was hit with the idea of making a photography project about school.  I sent out a survey to our faculty and staff, asking if they would be okay with me coming into their classes on my planning period and before and after school and taking photos of them.  I decided that I wanted the focus of this project to be the teachers and life in the school, rather than the students--besides the legal issue of not being able to show students’ faces, that’s not what I wanted the project to be about.  So many people have no idea what really goes on in a school on a daily basis.  This is what I wanted to show.  I determined that I could show the students by not shooting their faces, or using long exposures or shallow depth of field to blur their faces so you could see them...but not see them.  The teachers are the ones in focus here.  And so the 180 Days project was born.  I missed a day or two due to illness, a few technical errors, and being just too darn busy, but over the course of the school year, I captured almost 1500 photos.  I sent these photos daily through email to faculty and staff and the feedback was positive.  I also displayed them on social media and it was fun being able to share them with my friends and the public.  


During the course of the school year, people began to ask me what I was planning to do with these photos after the project was over.  My first thought was that I would love to have them in a show.  Now, 1500 photos is way too much for a show, so I sent out sampling to prospective venues.  The show proposal was accepted by Larkin Arts in Harrisonburg, VA.  I narrowed down the photos to about 200 and the committee at Larkin helped me make the final decision about the final 180 photos to make up the project.


180 pieces is a lot of art and I am asking for some help to cover the costs of mounting the show.  And so here is the proposal. The art gallery and I would like to keep the final pieces we have chosen under wraps until the opening, so that, even though the project was public, there is still an element of mystery to the opening and the surprise of seeing what has been chosen.


I am looking for patrons to sponsor pieces. Patrons will pre-pay for pieces and receive a voucher which can be used to claim a piece of art at the show.  Selection will be on a first-come, first-served basis; the sooner you attend the show, the more choices you will have for the redemption of your voucher.  Pieces must remain on display for the duration of the show and will be available for pickup or shipment after the show is over at the end of June, 2017.


I am seeking patrons for 90 of the 170 smaller pieces.  These will be 5X7 prints mounted on gallery depth wooden panels at a cost of $45 each.  If you are interested in a small piece, but can not make the show, it can be shipped to you for an additional cost  to cover shipping and handling.  The small pieces will be mounted on wooden panels, and should be able to be shipped easily.  Since the images will not be available in advance, I will choose a piece for you at random.


I am seeking patrons for five of the ten large pieces.  These are available for $250 each.They will be 16X24, professionally matted and framed.  Unfortunately, we will not be able to ship these.


I have also prepared an online album of “B-sides.”  These are photos which were taken for the project, but have not been previously seen or shared.  If you would like to sponsor my project, but are unable to make a large contribution, you will gain access to these new photos, never before available to the public, for a donation of $10 or more.  Patrons who purchase vouchers for show pieces will also receive access to these photos.


I am very excited about this opening in June of 2017.  The opening will be on part of the First Fridays Downtown: Harrisonburg on June 2, 2017.


Thank you for your time and for your support.


Cara Walton

Carawaltonphotography.com

story:
SoundIsRed:

SoundIsRed is a music and visual project started in 2010 that has released two full length albums, a graphic novel accompanied by and EP, and other items like stickers and t-shirts.  There are many more projects in the works for 2014.  Every one of these projects in the past and future heavily relies technology.  SoundIsRed uses computers to learn, compose, edit, review, upload, communicate, create, and perform.  With a reliable computer workstation, the goals for SoundIsRed throughout this year will be much easier to attain. 

The Problem: 

Unfortunately, the SoundIsRed computer is dieing after many years of service. 

Good news: All files are backed up on external hard drives. 

Bad news:  Buying a new computer is not financially possible.

Solution: 

Use all of the SoundIsRed merchandise to pay for a new computer workstation. 

Rundown: 

%100 of the $1,500 goal will go towards the purchase of a new computer workstation.  AND... The best part about this fundraiser is every single perk is ready to be shipped.  If the goal is met, all perks will be in the mail headed to your door immediately.

Challenges: 

The biggest challenge is getting outside the SoundIsRed fan circle.  If you already have these SoundIsRed stickers, albums, and shirts, please share this fundraiser with people who don't know about it.  Making this fundraiser a success depends on your support online. 

Please share:

Share this kickstarter page on your FaceBook, Twitter, or whatever.  It will directly support the creation of more albums, videos, and everything SoundIsRed.

story:
Thank you for helping build the US Cycling Monument!

Progress continues here -

http://www.uscyclingmonument.com


Perk Highlights (scroll down to view):

  • JANE GOODALL phone greeting - very rare gift!

  • Bob Roll or Phil Ligget phone greeting!

  • Athens Games Olympic Torch!

  • Signed 1993 Team Motorola Jersey!

  • Your own USC Monument Jersey!
    •

                                                  (Click here for larger view)

One of the country’s most important sporting and community-inspired artworks is heading toward the finish line in Boulder, Colorado. With the first round of funding complete, including significant contributions from Alcoa and MillerCoors, the U.S. Cycling Monument is on target for a July 2014 fundraising deadline.

To date, six major donors, in-kind support from 40 businesses, and the donation of 100 inscribed cobblestones have given the project great momentum. Now in Phase II the public at large, and all corporate supporters are able through this final campaign to raise the remaining $150,000 that will enable construction to start.

“Years of prep and approvals with the City, Parks and Recreation, and Arts Commissions are done,” said monument advisory board member and design phase consultant Michael Aisner. “We have heard much from people around the world who have been touched in some way by these great races that they too wanted to participate, have their names on cobbles and stones and donate. This last push will be able to assuredly sew this up by July.”

Commemorates the Birthplace of International Pro Cycling in the US

In association with the Boulder Parks and City representative, PLAY Boulder Foundation, designed by Colorado artist Kimmerjae Johnson, the monument will be the focal point of North Boulder Park, the historic heart of modern U.S. cycling. This is where, in 1975, entrepreneur Mo Siegel founded the Red Zinger Classic, an event that morphed into the 16-day Coors International Bicycle Classic, which race promoter Aisner expanded into one of the four biggest stage races in the world.  Covering four states, starting in San Francisco  it garnered CBS/NBC/ESPN coverage, a Warner Bros film and sold $1.5 million in race merchandise in five countries and every year it ended right where the monument will be situated.  It helped put Boulder on the map, attracting countless athletes and bike/sports industry businesses, and as America's "healthiest and thinnest cities," helped fulfill Siegel’s dream of a city dedicated to healthy physical activity through cycling.

With a profile changing dynamically as one moves through and around the sculpture, its elegant 50-foot-long, spiraling beam of aluminum will convey the excitement of a bike race’s breakaways, chases and sprints.

                                                  (Click here for larger view)

Like a silver ribbon, the beam will sail above the cobblestone plaza, between a canted stone archway ('Winner’s Circle') and a massive standing stone ('Talking Stone'). On this element will be written the history of the Red Zinger and Coors Classics, commemorating all the winners, along with their successors in today’s USA Pro Cycling Challenge. 

On the north border of the plaza, a sweeping arc of substantial buff sandstone block creates a seat wall for visitors to rest and view the monument and the park. Plantings in a raised bed supported by this wall will blow in the wind, like fans waving on the racers.      

To complete funding, the project requires more sponsors, along with individual donations for inscribed blocks, cobblestones, and the many "perks" listed here.

Inscribed 6" by 12" tumbled sandstone cobble - for your $100 donation.

For more details of the monument, go to www.uscyclingmonument.com 

FAQ's About this Project (click here)

For further information on funding contact project manager Zach Johnson at uscyclingmonument@gmail.com.

PERK Details:

$100 or $500 Inscribed Cobblestone 

You can "own" a piece of the monument. 

The cobblestone plaza will be made up of a mosaic of six inch by one foot ($100) and one foot by two foot ($500) inscribed sandstone cobbles. 

What Can Be Inscribed On The Cobbles?

  • Your Name, Company Name, or Name of a Loved One(s) (living or passed)
  • An Inspirational Quote, Favorite Music Lyrics, What Boulder or Cycling means to you
  • Put the name of your cycling team, your running club, triathlon club, baseball/softball/soccer team
  • Your favorite volunteer or non-profit group or activity
  • Or most any other creative ideas you might have (with appropriate decorum and in the spirit of the project).

Who Can Purchase Cobbles?

  • YOU!  Any fan of cycling, any fan of Boulder - whether you have enjoyed the park or the ZInger/Coors Classic in the past, or maybe you just want to support the cause and share your Boulder pride!
  • Red Zinger/Coors Classics Racers, Staff, Crew, Teams, Associates!!  If you participated in making the Red Zinger and Coors Classic the premiere event in US cycling, get your name on this beautiful monument!!
  • Past and Current Professional and Amateur Cyclists and/or Teams.  If you would like to be included in the Competing Cyclist area, tell us your team or classification from the appropriate cycling body and the years you competed.

$1000, $2500 or $5000 Sandstone Blocks

A beautiful, very prominent sitting wall will border the sweeping planter along the north side. This will be comprised of elegant inscribed 2 foot ($1,000), 3 foot ($2,500) and 4 foot ($5,000) sandstone blocks.  Where else can your name or company name or inspirational quote be so prominently placed for the public to view in perpetuity? And be associated with such a great tradition?

FAQ's About this Project (click here)

$2,000 - 10,000 Your Personalized Voicemail

$5,000  -  Athens Games Olympic Torch Package

$500  -  Signed Motorola Team Jersey

$75  -  U.S. Cycling Monument Jersey by Primal

                                                  (Click here for larger view)

$75  -  RecoFit Leg Compression Sleeve

$25  -  U.S. Cycling Monument T-Shirt

                                                  (Click here for larger view)

$15 - U.S.Cycling Monument Souvenir Ornament

$5  -  U.S. Cycling Monument Sticker

$15,000  -  Bernard Hinault's 1985 Tour de France Bicycle  SOLD! Thank You!

That's right, his actual bike used in the 85 Tour. To view larger photos on this collector's item,Visit the US Cycling Monument website.
story_txt:
Thank you for helping build the US Cycling Monument!Progress continues here -http://www.uscyclingmonument.comPerk Highlights (scroll down to view):

JANE GOODALL phone greeting - very rare gift!

Bob Roll or Phil Ligget phone greeting!
Athens Games Olympic Torch!
Signed 1993 Team Motorola Jersey!

Your own USC Monument Jersey!
                                                  (Click here for larger view)One of the country’s most important sporting
and community-inspired artworks is heading toward the finish line in Boulder, Colorado.
With the first round of funding complete, including significant contributions
from Alcoa and MillerCoors, the U.S. Cycling Monument is on target for a July 2014 fundraising deadline.

To date, six major donors, in-kind support
from 40 businesses, and the donation of 100 inscribed cobblestones have given the
project great momentum. Now in Phase II the public at large, and all corporate supporters are able through this final campaign to raise the remaining
$150,000 that will enable construction to start.
“Years of prep and approvals with the City,
Parks and Recreation, and Arts Commissions are done,” said monument advisory
board member and design phase consultant Michael Aisner. “We have heard much from people around the world who have been touched in some way by these great races that they too wanted to participate, have their names on cobbles and stones and donate. This last push will be able to assuredly sew
this up by July.”
Commemorates the Birthplace of International Pro Cycling in the USIn association with the Boulder Parks and City representative, PLAY Boulder Foundation, designed by Colorado artist Kimmerjae Johnson, the monument will be the focal
point of North Boulder Park, the historic heart of modern U.S. cycling. This is
where, in 1975, entrepreneur Mo Siegel founded the Red Zinger Classic, an
event that morphed into the 16-day Coors International Bicycle Classic, which race promoter Aisner expanded into one of the four biggest stage races in the world.  Covering four states, starting in San Francisco  it garnered CBS/NBC/ESPN coverage, a Warner Bros film and sold $1.5 million in race merchandise in five countries and every year it ended right where the monument will be situated.  It
helped put Boulder
on the map, attracting countless athletes and bike/sports industry businesses, and as America's "healthiest and thinnest cities," helped fulfill Siegel’s dream of a city dedicated to healthy physical
activity through cycling.With a profile changing dynamically as one moves through and around the sculpture, its elegant
50-foot-long, spiraling beam of aluminum will convey the excitement of a bike race’s breakaways, chases and
sprints.                                                  (Click here for larger view)Like a silver ribbon, the beam will sail above the cobblestone plaza,
between a canted stone archway ('Winner’s Circle') and a massive standing stone ('Talking Stone'). On this element will be written the
history of the Red Zinger and Coors Classics, commemorating all the winners,
along with their successors in today’s USA Pro Cycling Challenge. On the north border of the plaza, a sweeping arc of substantial buff sandstone block creates a seat wall for visitors to rest and view the monument and the park. Plantings in a raised bed supported by this wall will blow in the wind, like fans waving on the racers.       To complete funding, the project requires more sponsors, along with individual donations for inscribed blocks, cobblestones, and the many "perks" listed here.Inscribed 6" by 12" tumbled sandstone cobble - for your $100 donation.For more details of the monument, go to www.uscyclingmonument.com FAQ's About this Project (click here)
For further information on funding contact project manager Zach
Johnson at uscyclingmonument@gmail.com.PERK Details:$100 or $500 Inscribed Cobblestone You can "own" a piece of the monument.  
The cobblestone plaza will be made up of a mosaic of six inch by one foot ($100) and one foot by two foot ($500) inscribed sandstone cobbles. What Can Be Inscribed On The Cobbles?
Your Name, Company Name, or Name of a Loved One(s) (living or passed)

An Inspirational Quote, Favorite Music Lyrics, What Boulder or Cycling means to you

Put the name of your cycling team, your running club, triathlon club, baseball/softball/soccer team

Your favorite volunteer or non-profit group or activity
Or most any other creative ideas you might have (with appropriate decorum and in the spirit of the project).
Who Can Purchase Cobbles?
YOU!  Any fan of cycling, any fan of Boulder - whether you have enjoyed the park or the ZInger/Coors Classic in the past, or maybe you just want to support the cause and share your Boulder pride!
Red Zinger/Coors Classics Racers, Staff, Crew, Teams, Associates!!  If you participated in making the Red Zinger and Coors Classic the premiere event in US cycling, get your name on this beautiful monument!!
Past and Current Professional and Amateur Cyclists and/or Teams.  If you would like to be included in the Competing Cyclist area, tell us your team or classification from the appropriate cycling body and the years you competed.
$1000, $2500 or $5000 Sandstone Blocks
A beautiful, very prominent sitting wall will border the sweeping planter along the north side. This will be comprised of elegant inscribed 2 foot ($1,000), 3 foot ($2,500) and 4 foot ($5,000) sandstone blocks.  Where else can your name or company name or inspirational quote be so prominently placed for the public to view in perpetuity? story:
As sure as the beautiful sky can be blue, I want to express myself poetically and true.

MISSION
As an author/poet I want to be a mentor and an inspiration to the audience by using creative writing and arts. And I also want to emphasize dramatization through context and thought provoking words.

FUNDING
By the appreciative contribution, fans would be able to buy a book, see performances, and keep up with my literature through a professional and chic website.


Here is a sample of my writing. Genre: Romance

REMEMBER ME

Remember me, though you try to forget me

Reminisce on how you made me feel

Time moved slower as we laughed and carried on

The shallowness upon the deep surface

I know that you can’t forget because I know how I felt

No cares in the world and occupied in each others presence

Whatever the reason maybe, remove the imprint

The stain will remain for a while

You know how I made you feel

Your face gave it away

This silly game that is played

But instead, I walked away

Remember me

And I also want to emphasize dramatization through context and thought provoking words. FUNDINGBy the appreciative contribution, fans would be able to buy a book, see performances, and keep up with my literature through a professional and chic website.Here is a sample of my writing. Genre: RomanceREMEMBER ME Remember me, though you try to forget me Reminisce on how you made me feel
 Time moved slower as we laughed and carried on
 The shallowness upon the deep surface
 I know that you can’t forget because I know how I felt
 No cares in the world and occupied in each others presence
 Whatever the reason maybe, remove the imprint
 The stain will remain for a while
 You know how I made you feel
 Your face gave it away
 This silly game that is played
 But instead, I walked away
 Remember me

story:
Hello

I am Natalie Meagan, creative director and founder of The Crybaby Club. CB is the community, passion project,  and brand focused on creating content, art & products centered around mental illness awareness, inclusivity, community, self love and sensitivity as a strength.
You can read more about us and what we do here. 

We are hoping to raise money for 2019 travel to Dallas, Texas (and maybe even a few other places depending on the funds received), general restocking and for funding future projects like the "Y'all Means All" enamel pin. 
 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the deal:

  • The Dallas event is the main incentive for this fundraiser. I want to be able to comfortably cover my travel fees, inventory stocking, set up costs, etc. so that I can enjoy this festival without having to stress myself out to get there. Stocking requires a lot of product orders for the event. Usually, it is easy to restock because people can preorder/pay upfront, but with an event like this, I will be paying out of pocket in order to then travel and hopefully make sales to cover those costs. NOT TO MENTION I am planning to just go alone, if I raise enough money, I can pay for an assistant to come with me and oh my god...how great would that be??
  • By investing in me, you will get my un ending gratitude PLUS a few great perks which you can learn more about below. 
  • If I happen to not reach my goal, the funds will go towards exactly what I have said: stocking, restocking and prepping for events. Every little bit helps and is appreciated.
     

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share this campaign on your facebook, twitter, instagram, etc. It really can make a huge difference in spreading the word and getting more eyes on the campaign! 
  • Share Crybaby! We are on Instagram, Facebook and we have a website + blog. Send people our way, tag friends in our posts, like our pictures, etc. All of this helps advance our reach and you never know who may find us through you! 

Let me know if you have any questions or comments and I am so, so happy that you are here. Thank you for reading my story, thank you for believing in my work, thank you for your support.

story:
Do you like to be turned on? Do you dig being titillated?  Do you need a little pick me up in the libido area?  Then Oh! Daddy is the book for you!

 

Oh! Daddy is a collection of erotic art and fiction collected by artist Aaron Morgan. After he exhibited some of his work at the 2012 Seattle Erotic Arts Festival, he was filled with the desire to publish a collection of erotic works featuring artists and writers that excite him. Oh! Daddy is the fruit of this, his latest obsession.

Oh! Daddy is envisioned as a 100+ page full-color coffee-table book impregnated by the naughty imaginings of over 20 writers and artists from around the world. It represents a body of work shaped by heavy petting and tender kisses into a multifaceted sculpture of a modern eros. Aaron provided each contributor with one creative impulse, as light and provocative as the scantiest evening wear: “Give me something that you find deeply erotic.” With that libertine mandate, each consensual partner produced work that penetrates a different area of the body erotic.

To bring this supreme effort to a climax, to move Oh! Daddy from fantasy into hardcopy reality, we need the financial help of people who like to watch. With your support, dear voyuer, we will achieve a full release of this our seed upon the world.

The business end of this transaction involves a mere $8000 funding goal, most of which will go toward publishing the book itself. As an artist, Aaron knows the importance of paying artists for their work, and he will allocate a portion of your support to each contributor. The more money we receive beyond our base funding goal, the more each artist will be paid for their work.

story:
My Story

Hello! My name is Amanda Candella and I am an art student at Pacific Lutheran University. This is a small, liberal arts school located in Tacoma, WA. 

As a graduating art student at PLU, I am required to participate in the art department's senior exhibition in Spring of 2012. Students are required to submit pieces related to their chosen fields and concentrations (mine being graphic design). These submissions are then reviewed and a student's best work is chosen for inclusion in the show. I've got plenty of small class projects to choose from, but I want to go big for my last piece of college work. 

This is where you come in! I need funding for this to-be-determined masterpiece. The university provides us with the space and the advice of our professors, but all financial responsibilities of the projects are the students' to cover.  


The Impact

Thanks to your contributions, PLU students, staff, and community members will be able to witness my work. This exhibition is a chance to show my peers and professionals what I have learned over the past four years. And if we are being honest, I have learned that creativity and drive will take you far, but a final work of art with no financial restrictions will take me much farther. Publicity? Another exhibition? Entrance to an awesome grad school?   


You've Got What I Want

I have set my goal at $500. This is an estimate seeing as I do not currently know the extent or theme of this project. 
Printing costs, materials, and installation equipment start to add up quickly. Regardless of whether or not the full amount is raised, all of the money raised here will go towards preparing and installing my work.  

And out of appreciation for your support, I will include a visual shout-out to all of my contributors within the piece.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Share & tell your friends! There is no better advertising than word of mouth. And just think about how fancy & philanthropic you'll sound when you tell your friends you made a donation to a broke art student!

story:
Our Story

For the 2nd Ghetto Biennale in Port-au-Prince, Haiti,  Jean Elie Gilles, Ebby Louis Angel and I will facilitate an International Folklore Exchange with Haitians and international visitors using folklore to open a dialogue about the current conditions in Haiti after the January 2010 earthquake. The project will consist of gathering stories, mask making, writing and theater workshops, which during the final week of the Biennale in December 2011, will culminate in the choreography of a live multi-media performance. The central theme of the project will be based in the legend of the Loup Garou, a werewolf found in Haitian lore as well as in Native American, Canadian and French culture.

                     

The Impact

 In Haiti, the Loup Garou represents a shape-shifting character that often mirrors the social and political struggles about the countryï¿½s poverty and repression. For the project, we will use the loup-garou legend to initiate a dialogue about the erasure and revision of Haitian identity that has been complicated by colonialism and most recently neo-colonialism. Finally, through the process of storytelling and a multifaceted process, we aim to celebrate Haitian culture and its history of resistance. 

What We Need & What You Get

We would like to raise $3000 to cover our various project expenses including: travel and lodging, stipends for Haitian collaborating artists Jean Elie Gilles and Ebby Louis Angel, digital media equipment, art and costume materials, and workshop expenses such as printing and refreshments for workshop participants. 

We have 5 unique gifts available to those who contribute to our campaign including: limited edition artwork by Ivy Jeanne, Emmalee Conner and Duskin Drum. We also have beautiful original photographs of Haiti and a DVD of work by Jakmel Ekspresyon/ Cine Institute filmmakers Zaka Chery and Ebby Louis Angel which includes two short films and American filmmaker Cary Cronenwett's  video diary of JE's  super eight hand-processing workshop from July 2011. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support is appreciated in whatever way you can contribute. Please forward this far and wide to your friends, family and community. For more information about the Ghetto Biennale please visit: http://www.ghettobiennale.com/    For more info about Jakmel Ekspresyon please visit:  http://www.jakmelekspresyon.wordpress.com/

story:
You are the reason I create.


We live and breathe in the physical world, with real hardships and real pressures. Despite all that, you may be surprised to learn: suffering is optional. Setting that idea in motion shifts everyday experience into a heightened state of creativity; life becomes your art and your awakening becomes your reality.


:

Learn more about project creator, Laurie Perez: http://www.indiegogo.com/joybroker

:

What others are saying about SPiN:

.

“Check this out, people! My friend Laurie is an AMAZING writer and a darling person. You’ll want to get in on this!” -Amanda

.

“Please pledge to Laurie’s enlightening new project! I am doing so… she is vibrant and enlightening and should bring that to everyone else!” -Eric

.

“I am happy to back something to do with positivity, joy and compassion.” -Jane

.

“I believe in what inspires me, I believe in YOU full heartedly. It makes me very happy to have a small part in making your dream come true. I cannot wait to read your book.” -Evelina

.

“She’s one of the sweetest spirits I have ever met!” -Christopher

.

“One of the smartest + most talented people I know is looking to fund a multimedia project…called Spin.” -Mark

.

“[Laurie’s] Tempest was the kind of event we desperately need here. It was phenomenal!” “Support an exciting project!” -Joanna

.

“I believe in your project and can’t wait to experience it for myself.” -Kerri

.

“Laurie is an Amazing writer. This book I know will be a positive influence to anyone who reads it. Support our local artists!” -Brenda

.

“I believe in this woman who calls herself a ‘joybroker.’ She lives in joy & is a joy to know… She wants to birth books, CDs, and be a midwife for others’ personal transformations. If I [could], I’d fund Laurie’s project in full.” -Marianne

.

“There are a lot of wonderful, creative, and ambitious people in our… community. Laurie Perez is one of these people… Much love to all those who take their dreams with them upon waking to the next day.” -Deon

.

“I’m an official Patron of the Arts! I am backing Laurie’s new project; author, poet, inspiration, joy broker, just a few words to describe Laurie. ‘Project’ doesn’t begin to describe what Laurie is creating, a book, a movement and its so simple to be a part of it all.” -Tisha

.

“Please take a moment to… think about Laurie’s new book…this woman is a part of my heart/soul without even having met her…her book will be very important to many people.” -Heather

story:
Our Story

The Centre for Art Tapes (CFAT) is a non-profit organization that has been in Halifax since 1979. We serve as a production facility and presentation facility for those interested and working in media arts. We provide space, facilities and support for artists, filmmakers and community organizations working in digital art. In addition to our equipment and facilities services, we provide a number of public programs for the community such as beginner level video, audio and electronics mentorship, youth video camps (see our gallery for an example of these videos) a scholarship program (the video above, by artist Eleanor King, is an example of the work that comes out of this program), residency programs, exhibitions and public screenings. CFAT is a great resource for anyone who is interested in media arts!

For the first time ever, we are relocating to a custom built space with beautiful and industry standard suites in order to better serve our community with their specific media art needs.

Your support will connect you to a vibrant community through the benefits of a membership, and aid CFAT in preparing for the new services offered to our community.

The Impact

The impact of your donation - be it $10 or $2000 - will be beneficial to the Centre and most importantly, it's members. All funds go directly into the services offered to our members and will help support our organization as a whole!

What We Need & What You Get

Donations of $10 - $30 will give you $10 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment)

Donations of $35 will get you an associate membership at Centre for Art Tapes, and  $10 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment). This is a supporting membership that gets you access to our facilities on 'Free Thursdays". Great for anyone looking to do a quick video edit or digitize tapes, and for individuals who are not media artists but wish to show their support as a "Friend of CFAT"!

Donations of $65 get you an Individual Membership, and  $10 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment). In addition to helping fund CFAT, you will get rental discounts on ALL equipment and facilities and access to "Free Thursdays". Even if you have no experience in video, drop on by and see what's possible!

Donations of $100 gets you an individual membership, and $20 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment) plus - a 'we love you!'

Donations of $250 will get you an individual membership, $30 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment), a high five and 'we love you'.

Donations of $500 will get you an individual membership and $100 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment), a special CFAT video cheer and "YOU ROCK".

Donations of $1000+, and you get an individual membership, 200$ CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment), a special CFAT video cheer, plus we might name one of our suites after you! No seriously.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us expand our network by spreading the link to this campaign! Tell your friends, family members, friends of the arts! We want to reach our goal and expand our membership base in the process!
story_txt:
Our Story
The Centre for Art Tapes (CFAT) is a non-profit organization that has been in Halifax since 1979. We serve as a production facility and presentation facility for those interested and working in media arts. We provide space, facilities and support for artists, filmmakers and community organizations working in digital art. In addition to our equipment and facilities services, we provide a number of public programs for the community such as beginner level video, audio and electronics mentorship, youth video camps (see our gallery for an example of these videos) a scholarship program (the video above, by artist Eleanor King, is an example of the work that comes out of this program), residency programs, exhibitions and public screenings. CFAT is a great resource for anyone who is interested in media arts!For the first time ever, we are relocating to a custom built space with beautiful and industry standard suites in order to better serve our community with their specific media art needs.
Your support will connect you to a vibrant community through the benefits of a membership, and aid CFAT in preparing for the new services offered to our community.

Even if you have no experience in video, drop on by and see what's possible!
Donations of $100 gets you an individual membership, and $20 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment) plus - a 'we love you!'Donations of $250 will get you an individual membership, $30 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment), a high five and 'we love you'.Donations of $500 will get you an individual membership and $100 CFAT Dollars (Credit towards the Centre's rental equipment), a special CFAT video cheer and "YOU ROCK".

story:
MinifigCustomsIn3d

... is a small internet shop providing custom designed items for LEGO minifigs.  The technique behind is rather new but nevertheless fast growing. If you are interested in some details check out the interview pulished in the Ugly Duckling Blog

Short Summary

During the past three years of designing and printing items I had the following dream:

  • Beeing able to make prototypes immedeatly
  • using Resin as material
  • printing in colors
  • achieveing a resolution nearby an ABS print

Today I have seen this project which can bring this dream to reality.

So if this project becomes reality I'm able to purchase an affordable home printing device.

Afterwards I can start a periode of design adaptations for my existing items to improve the quality and to check the possibility of having colored prints.

Further Infos

you will find a lot of usefull informations on my shop entry page:

http://www.shapeways.com/shops/MinifigCustomsIn3d

or browse some results on my flickr page:
 
http://www.flickr.com/photos/34336019@N07/
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but are willing to help, please speak about this campaign.

story:
What We're Doing:

Touring OUTwordlyFabulous, a show about stopping bullying and homophobia, around the Midwest and the Bible Belt this summer.

We're taking the show to GLBT centers to speak mainly to with kids, Unitarian Churches to speak with congregations, and public high schools to speak to the general student populace.

We're talking to everyone.  The bulliers and the bullied and the bystanders.  We're all in this together.  The show treats us all as inter-related.

As of 5/25 we've booked GLBT Centers in Missouri, Pittsburgh, Fayetteville (KY), Dallas, Austin, and Memphis.  These were all from cold calls.  We have contacts in other parts of the country: Knoxville, Baltimore, Jackson (MS), Houston, Columbus (OH), who are working on getting us other performances. 

The Show

The show is a 90 minute, fully-produced (lights, sound, props, costumes), one-woman, performance piece that addresses all aspects of bullying.  There are poems, monologues, rants and audience participation.  It's a piece that has something for everyone in it.  And the audience is all people between the ages of 13 and 93.  (We've even had some seven year olds watch the show!)

What We Need & What You Get

For this tour to help stop bullying all across the Midwest and the South, we need gas money, money to rent a van to get our five-person crew and housing in 10 locations (we're looking for sponsorship for underwriting the rest of the towns and cities).  Breakdown:  220 miles/day (average) with 22 mpg = 11 gallons @ $3.19 (average)/gallon = $35.09/day (average) x 30 days = $1052.70.  Van rentals: $1950.00 (each - seven-seater van, rented for 32 days, 22 mpg), one for the crew, one for the set/tech equipment.   Housing $1982.30 for five people, 3 rooms in 10 cities ($192/city or $60/room).


Even $5 makes a difference.  We love donations from $1 to $1000.


If we don't reach our funding goal, funding that is raised will go toward fuel and van rentals.  We will attempt to find housing donated by supporters of the campaign in each town and we've got some crew who are down for tents, but we'd really like to stay places with running water nearby.  :-)


Perks for Donating:  Copy of DVD about the show, Personalized birthday poems, "I am Enough" tee-shirt, along with lots of other stuff.

Our Story - How we Got Here

OUTwordlyFabulous is a spoken word performance show with a message to stop bullying and homophobia in our country for youth and adults. 


Award-winning spoken word artist Pandora Scooter wrote and performs the show, directed and produced by To and Fro Production CEO, Cedric Hill.  There are make up artists, wardrobe staff, videography, photography, support staff, stage management, publicity, marketing and a company manager.  You'll hear from some of these people in the video above.  The show is the result of 18 people's work -- all from all backgrounds, ages and sexual orientations coming together to create a show designed to make the world more compassionate and inclusive.


The result of all these people's work is a 90 minute, fully produced (lights, sound and projections) powerhouse of a one-woman show about stopping bullying and homophobia which contribute to the "Culture of Mean" that children find themselves in every day - both at home and at school.  


On March 10th, we premiered OUTwordlyFabulous to critical success.  Since then we have performed the show in a variety of forms throughout New Jersey and in Los Angeles in preparation for performing across the country.


The Impact

Dr. Paula Rodriguez-Rust, New Jersey's premiere sociologist and expert on Anti-Bullying programs, endorsed the show, as did two Licensed Clinical Social Workers.  Responses were overwhelmingly positive, including comments such as, "Now I want to go and change my school!" or "Thank you for showing me how much bullying goes on around me."  or "I never thought about having an all inclusive society, I will think about that more."


US Congressman Frank Pallone's also endorsed OUTwordlyFabulous.

OUTworldlyFabulous's message, according to Dr. Rust, is on the cutting edge of current anti-bullying strategies - compassion, inclusion, self-love and self-acceptance are the tools being used to combat the bully culture - and it's working.  Statistics show that more and more children are speaking up about bullying going on in their schools and are becoming less tolerant of it due to messages such as these.

It is this message that OUTwordlyFabulous gets out.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you believe in the cause, but can't help out with a donation of cash, please consider helping out by doing one or more of the following.


a) Call someone you know and talk to them about the project and ask them to contribute

b) Contact an organization or school anywhere in the country and tell them about this project and find out if they would like to have OUTwordlyFabulous at their venue (and then forward us the information, please).

c) Don't forget to Tweet about us and to Post about us on Facebook.

d) Just be as kind as you can be.

story:
Do you have something to say? These one-of-a-kind t-shirt designs are littered with expressions that are hard to resist. In each t-shirt, colourful illustrations meet colourful language.

Digitally printed on high quality t-shirts by the best in the industry. Because swearing is an art.

Colourful language is self-expression in its most pure state. Embrace it!

Money raised will fund the event which will exhibit the collection alongside a backdrop of colourful live art performances including dance, music and interactive murals.


Click the images below to see more work in their portfolios.

story:
Our Story

A few things went wrong in creating content about Chicago Artists Month. 

1. We got to busy and forgot about it

2. We can't get any institutional support for advertising on our site

3. All the October artists have been written and the writers have moved onto the film site.

The Impact

We have absolutely nothing on the schedule regarding CAM, and no money to do anything. If we stay on our current course, no one who reads the site will even know that October is supposed to be a big month for artists. 


What We Need & What You Get

We only need a few hundred bucks to bring some staff back to CAMag and do some great stuff. We'll immediately create a slideshow on the sidebar as soon as we have $150. If everybody participating throws in a few bucks, we'll create a whole bunch of sponsored posts, maps, weekly calendar, etc. The top 5 contributors will get a bonus sponsored post about their 5 respective endeavors.

story:
You may or may not know this, but I am obsessed with Louis-Jacques-Mandé Daguerre and the photographic process he developed - the daguerreotype (just the word gives me chills). If you know this already, then you know how important what I'm about to tell you is. The Daguerrian Society is holding its 75th Annual Symposium in October in Bry-sur-Marne, France, with visits to his home, his grave, and most importantly, the newly restored diorama painting that was his last. There will be unique opportunities to go behind the scenes, visits to institutions and access to rare daguerreotypes that only the Daguerreian Society can make possible. 

Louis-Jacques-Mande Daguerre

Like me, Daguerre was a painter and a photographer.  He was the first French panorama painter. He created theatrical illusions and was celebrated for his set design. And then he devloped one of the first, and arguably the most stunning photographic process. Daguerreotypes, like Daguerre's dioramas, are about first-hand experience.  Like paintings, they are one of kind objects, made on highly polished silver plates which are exposed by the camera and then developed with mercury and gold. Thanks to a grant, I had the opportunity to make a couple myself (top image), and it was an incredible experience. My dream is to one day make my own daguerreotypes, when I have the space and the resources - but until that can happen, I will continue to research, adore, and help keep the love alive for a 175 year old photographic process.

First photograph of a human being.  Taken in 1838 by Louis Daguerre in Paris.

Shells and Fossils, Louis Daguerre, ca. 1850, 

Daguerreotypes and Daguerre, himself, have been a big influence in how I think of both painting and photography. My photographic portraits require a great deal of preparation, they involve a sense of theater, and the prints are mounted on aluminum plates, which harkens back to the daguerreotype plate. I could not make the photographs I make without working and experimenting in other mediums, and like Daguerre, I am not afraid to try new things, depending on my vision. I think of both my paintings and my photographs as ephemeral experiences that, like daguerreotypes, can only be fully appreciated in person.

*or* by Jen Bandini, 2013

I am asking for your patronage to attend this once in a lifetime trip. As you may know, I suddenly fell ill in 2009 with neurological and rheumatological diseases that continue to cause chronic pain and fatigue, along with other symptoms. This illness has made opportunities like this financially impossible. 

Your funding will go towards paying for my flight, hotel, and the symposium fee (plus fees charged by Indiegogo and Paypal). If I do not reach my funding goal, you will pay nothing - there is no way I can do this without your help! Any funds received over my funding goal will help pay for food, ground transportation, and film for my trip. 

Please know that even the smallest donation will be greatly appreciated. If every one of my 393 Facebook friends donated just $7.63, my trip would be fully funded! If you can not afford to help out, I would so love if you could share my campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your blog... anywhere! (You can use the tools found right here on this page)

I will post continuous updates of my experience on Facebook and on Instagram, which I consider my photographic sketchbook. The complete story will be told in words and the more luscious pictures that can be found on my blog, escapetonewyork.net. Thanks for you time and your help!

Connect with me on Facebook (Jen Bandini) or Instagram (@e2ny).

My portrait photography is at jenbandini.com.

My paintings are at jenbandinipaintings.com

My lifestyle photography and writing are at escapetonewyork.net 


Incentives:

The Facebook Friend - $7.63 and up

If all 393 of my Facebook friends donated $7.63, my campaign would be funded.  At this level, you can become my Facebook friend, where you will receive daily updates on my experience, including more information than you will ever need about JML Daguerre! You will receive a personal thank you, as well as your name on my blog as a patron of my trip.

The Video Pal - $25 and up

At $25 or above, you will receive a personal video message thanking you for your contribution, taken in Paris (and hopefully sent from Paris if the Wi-fi gods are good to me).  Your name will also appear on my blog as a patron.

The Postcard Patron - $50 and up

At $50 and above, you will receive a postcard from Paris, sharing an experience from my day or a quick drawing, as well as your name on my blog as a patron.

The Polaroid Patron - $100 and up

I've always thought Polaroids were similar to Daguerreotypes.  Both are unique objects, and both are prints made in the presence of the subject. At this level you will receive a signed, Polaroid taken on my trip - maybe of Daguerre's grave, maybe of the Louvre - sent to you after I return to NYC. You will also receive a postcard from Paris and your name on my blog as a patron.

Daguerre Drawing - $300

At $300 and above you will receive a watercolor drawing - perhaps of Daguerre (of course), or some other scene and a Polaroid taken on my trip sent to you after my return. You will also receive a postcard from Paris and your name on my blog as a patron.

Patron Extraordinaire - $500

At $500 and above, you will receive a Paris-related watercolor drawing, a Polaroid, a postcard from Paris, your name on my blog as a patron, and a specially-produced "photo sketchbook" of pictures taken on my trip.

At $500 and above, you will receive a Paris-related watercolor drawing, a Polaroid, a postcard from Paris, your name on my blog as a patron, and a specially-produced "photo sketchbook" of pictures taken on my trip.

story:
Teen Art Salon is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit art service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Teen Art Salon must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

1. Who we are/why we're here

Teen Art Salon began as a forum for adolescent creatives to workshop their ideas and converse with like-minded peers outside of their everyday classroom. 

Established as a learning laboratory that prioritizes inquiry, inclusiveness, and self-expression, Teen Art Salon offers salon seminars on contemporary art, issues of social justice, and the politics of youth sub-culture. In addition, we spent the summer hosting a free co-working studio space for adolescent activists, artists, and writers to work on unfinished projects and collaborate on new ones!

On September 18th,  Teen Art Salon's inaugural exhibition "Juvenilia" opened at 103 Allen St, featuring over 20 teenage artists from across North America. A preview of works on view can be found here: http://www.teenartsalon.com/new-page/

We hope to use this platform to expand our programming schedule and widen participation. We want to do this by providing our NYC students with greater access to materials and equipment to develop their creative projects, and to continue to plan future events in support of young artists nationwide.

2. Our Philosophy
We believe that the extent to which we as a society value arts education, and the way in which arts and humanities are taught to adolescents, needs to be reevaluated. As MIT professors Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee have argued in their recent book, The Second Machine Age, technology has moved on from replacing textile workers and farm hands.  Computers are now diagnosing medical conditions, algorithms are performing audits, and software is doing the work of paralegals. The creative industries are becoming more relevant and accessible than ever, which is why the youth of today should be exploring their creativity and actualizing their imaginations. We provide a space in which adolescents may conduct such research. 

Our open studios are modeled after former art salons throughout history, providing an inclusive, non-hierarchal environment for young artists to collaborate and innovate. 

Social pressures of our society discourage young people from pursuing creative careers and getting involved in the cultural industry. This perpetuates a passive devaluation of art in our society, especially to low-income and marginalized groups and we need to reverse this! 

Teen Art Salon provides access to space for adolescents, something our urban infrastructure lacks.

3. Our plans for donations 

As the workshops and seminars increase in popularity, we hope to provide greater networking opportunities and invite guest speakers/participants from professionals in creative fields. Our co-working space would benefit hugely from access to editing software, AV equipment, and installation materials. The ability to take our young artists on site visits and inspire them outside of their community will go towards purchasing out first van to connect groups of aspiring artists nationwide. Finally, we have already been approached to develop subsequent exhibitions in new spaces in the US, but these are  projects which are as of yet unfunded. 

4. Long-term ambitions

Throughout the process of building Teen Art Salon, we will be assembling a diverse archive of adolescent work from the past and present. Additionally, we hope to establish a permanent arts centre for the exhibition, where we will continue to develop and promote the creative pursuits of adolescents, and such a collection can reside.

story:
Short Summary

Lead artist Elizabeth Pozzi's work is often disturbing.  Fascinated by finding beauty in the dark and grotesque, her art, while significant, is often out of place in a traditional gallery setting.  Much of the time she is content with her role as a curator and finds it very fulfilling to help other artists share their work with their communities.  This project, however, is a rare opportunity to see the world through the eyes of this fringe artist as she builds, quite literally, an alternate reality to contain her disquieting but exhilarating visions.

This is an opportunity not only to introduce curator as artist, but to share a body of work and a vision of the world not often explored.  Such a voyage of discovery for artist and art patron alike is rare.  Your support of this project will help create a unique shared experience unlike any you've had before or will have again.

Once complete, the experience will be shared with the public in a series of six ticketed performances.

What We Need & What You Get

An installation of this size and a transformation of this magnitude - where a 1,000 square foot gallery space becomes a traveling circus tent in every possible way - requires talent and passion, but it also requires resources.

The built environment and reasonable compensation for fire eaters, contortionists, suspensionists, and other circus performers will account for the bulk of the $3,000 production budget.  Much of this is being provided by our host venue, the Apollon Art Space, but your support will help to ensure the highest quality experience is had by artists, performers, and audience members alike.

To say thanks, we've come up with some very fun perks including show tickets, VIP time with the performers, and even free lessons from some of our most talented acts.  Always wanted to learn how fire eating works?  Now's your chance!

While we'd love to meet and surpass our goal, the good news is that, with the Apollon's support, every dollar raised will be available for these core production expenses to make the show bigger and better.   Coming up short is always possible, but, as they say in our business, the show must go on! 

Either way, your support makes you part of a broader effort to use art as a vehicle to bring unique experiences to your community.  And let's not forget the value of fun!  We can talk for days about the importance and power of community-supported artwork, but another vital role of art and for artists is to add joy, surprise, excitement, and wonder to our lives.  We take our responsibility to do just that very seriously.  Come to be impacted, but come to have fun with us, too!

Stretch Goals

$1,250: If we raise $500 beyond our goal, we'll add live circus music to every performance of the show.  Our original production budget allows for recorded music, but we'd love to include an organ grinder, an accordion player, or something equally circus-y if resources allow.

$2,000: If we raise another $750 beyond our first stretch goal, we'll add a full-fledged food truck to the production budget so that carnival snacks won't just stop at popcorn and cotton candy - they'll also include nachos, caramel apples, and FUNNEL CAKE included with your admission.

Risks & Challenges

Building an immersive production that involves four different creative disciplines, more than half a dozen different kinds of performers, and more than a dozen artists in total presents a variety of logistical and creative challenges.  While we've never built a show exactly like this one, Under the Big Top will be our 42nd interdisciplinary production since we started working together creatively.

We believe that this breadth of knowledge and experience makes us uniquely qualified to address these challenges and engage in active and proactive problem solving throughout the creative process.

Other Ways You Can Help

We've been artists for a long time, so if you just aren't in a position to contribute monetarily no one understands that better than us!  You still have something very valuable you can give - your vocal public support.

If you're excited to meet these artists, clue someone else in that they should be excited too.  If you hope, like we hope, that this thing is going to be a smashing success then do us the favor of telling your friends and asking them to support the project.  They'll listen to you and, in turn, you'll be a big part of helping us create a new and exciting world under the big top!

story:
Synchronal Magazine is a unique new bi-annual from a creative community based in Nuremberg, Germany.


Synchronal exists to create connection, moderate conversation, and cultivate curiosity, featuring content gathered from an international community of creative ruffians.  At its heart, Synchronal exists to be a connecting point between us and the world.


Issue No. 1 


We have been working on the content for "Issue 1" since the start of summer 2015, gathering stories from New York, Beirut, Portland, Nairobi and beyond, and exploring the topic of Identity - the theme of our first issue. The topic is both relevant and fitting since we are also in the process of finding our identity as Synchronal magazine. Our hope is that this issue changes the way that people view one another - more lovingly and with more grace - specifically, people who are different. There are many articles in our first issue featuring people that wouldn't seem approachable on the street; we hope that this issue allows us to identify with people entirely different from us.

Here are some example spreads of Issue #1 :






Where will your money go?

Your money will go directly to printing the magazine! Aided by our community and a network of friends built through years of travel and collaboration, Synchronal will be going as far as coffee shops in Africa and as close as your door.  


More on the character of our magazine 

From the start, Synchronal magazine has come out of a place of longing for significance and community.  

All of us involved in Synchronal magazine have experienced moments when we felt like we had no impact. From the start, we wanted everyone involved in this project to feel it was a place where they wouldn't be silenced, where they could thrive, and where they could grow to their potential -- whether as a contributor or as a core member. We want to give a platform to people writing with purpose whether it's about a global injustice like female circumcision in Africa or it's a new perspective on anxiety.

Challenges for us  

In the near future, we will release our magazine with several independent retailers. Throughout this process, we aim to find a sustainable balance which will allow us to print larger numbers of future issues and still get the magazine into all the hands we hope for.

story:
Since I creating montages my main dream has been to organize a photo exhibition series here in my home country involving pieces from my favourite works which I created over the last four years.  Here is the part when you can contribute to this story: I need your help to realise my dream.


About me...

My name is Gyula Gábor Tóth, I'm a self taught professional photographer. Mostly I am known as HeavenMan; of course this is an alias but appropriate for an artist. Tens of thousands people in Hungary and across the world know me by it.The name was given to me by a friend after viewing one of my photos. Since then it has become my signature.

I became involved in photography five years ago strictly on an amateur level; or it can be said I was just clicking without any editing. Later I learned about and started spending increasing amounts of time editing my photos. I realized that I could create artistic pieces that were realistic in appearence, but would never exist in the reality. Some of the pictures from the Gallery were made from several tens of photos with multiple daily work. This is my real world. 

Besides the fantasy world I feel comfortable in other subjects too, my other favourite is shooting pictures about the weather; photographing different cloud types, stormchasing and lightning photography and so on. I like the urban themes and landscape photos as well, these are also reflected back in the montages.

      This is me, with my little daughter :)

... and my Exhibition

The photo exhibition series will consist of between thirty and forty pictures as I plan. All square shaped, with sizes between 60x60cm to 90x90cm. The print tests are still in progress, but the plan is for the images to be printed on glass, or plexiglass with unique LED backlighting. Behind the images a button battery adapter will be places with a corresponding LED light which will illuminate the central image from different levels.

I’m still working on to fix the locations and the dates of the exhibitions, some locations are already fixed, the scheduled begining is spring or early summer of 2015.

What I need to start the Exhibition

My goal is to start a not ordinary exhibition tour. To do this I need to raise at least three thousand and fifty hundred US dollars. So I have set my target funding at 3,500 USD - It's a bit higher than the cost of the prints, but I must have to calculate with the rental cost in each places, marketing outgoings, I will need to pay to prints and shipping, pay a percentage of the earnings to the crowdfunding platform (and PayPal), and pay taxes. 

What will You get for Your contribution

Of course my goal is not only collect some cash for the campaign, in return I offer pictures from my gallery which I created over the years, you can find 60 images in this Gallery. They are not only montages, but some landscape and urban photos as well.

The images are numbered, and each of them is titled, so based on these the donors can easily choose which picture or pictures they want. In the cases of the $35, $55, $110, $300, $500, and $1000  perks, ones will get the prints on a 300g fine art paper, and all the other perks will be printed by a special UV technology to foam pvc board. This kind of printing is more resistant and spectacular, so these are really perfect as a wall picture. The images with the sign "Wall READY" [30x30 cm (11,8x11,8"), 40x40 cm (15,7x15,7"), 50x50 cm (19,6x19,6"), 60x60 cm (23,6x23,6"), 80x80 cm (31,5x31,5"), 100x100 cm (39,3x39,3")]  are equipped with spacers, so they are totally ready for wall mounting.

How can You donate and get your own Print?

It is so easy for everyone. You can donate with your typical credit cards (Visa and Mastercard) or with PayPal account. The Perks you get for your contribution are on the right side ( grey framed rectangles). 

Other ways You can help

I understand that some people are not in a position to make any kind of monetary contribution, so if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please share this campaign with your friend on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Google+ etc.
  • Please send to your email contacts who you think might be interested in this project.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools

Facebook page: https://facebook.com/heavenmanphotography

If you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask me via my email: heavenmanphotography@gmail.com

                 Thank You!

Sincerely,

HeavenMan
