story:
Our Story:

Resident Arts Emerging Artist Residency

Resident Arts' mission is to provide professional development opportunities for artists at every level of their career to cultivate the arts locally and broaden the horizons of local artists, nationally. Our programs train young, emerging, and professional artists as well as supporters of the arts to embrace experimentation and critical thinking to lay a foundation for sustainable creative practice in the region.

Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land is the first resident in our Emerging Artist Residency program. Unlike traditional residency programs, local emerging artists inhabit the studio on a part-time basis. They undergo career coaching and attend the professional development workshop series to bolster their arts career, learning about marketing, grant writing, concept development, and more. The resident artist works to create a large-scale work that is beyond the scope of their existing practice. The artist then presents the final work to the public.

Resident Arts' director works along the resident throughout the course of the three months to help realize their artistic vision for the work, while at the same time acting as a support system for time management, funding, and promotion of the work. We believe artists benefit greatly from this kind of professional support, and that it can help emerging artists take their careers to the next level.

The artist: Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land

Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land is an incredible local artist who is dedicated to Columbia's artistic vibrancy. She has done community work with True/False Film Festival, Citizen Jane Film Festival, the North Village Farmers and Artisans Market and has exhibited at local shops and exhibition spaces throughout the city.  

The project: Urban Shrine

Sarah's dedication and fascination with this city is what prompted the inspiration for "Urban Shrine" a work that has been, until now, purely research. Sarah investigated the origins of Columbia's smokestacks, iconic mid-west imagery that flanks our skyline, but is often un-considered. Sarah wanted to know "Who made these?" "Why are they here?"

Like an archaeologist, she dug into our city's history to find a story of a great fire, of new growth, and of a city made. She brings to us, a story about how our city became the college town it is, how industry and politics shaped our landscape. This story will be made manifest in "Urban Shrine" which aims to explore the power, mystery, forgotten history, and narrative contained in the urban monuments through the use of spiritual visual vocabularies.

Making it Happen:

In Resident Arts' Emerging Artist Residency, artists inhabit the studio. But Sarah is working on more than just the nuts and bolts of art-making to complete this project. While we spend time bolstering her artistic practice with the logistics and production of a large-scale work, we've also been helping to professionalize her career with one-on-one consultation, professional development workshops, and time management. While Madeleine, Resident Arts' Director, works to help refine and promote the work, Sarah is learning who she has the potential to be as an artist, and as a businesswoman.

Resident Arts believes that artists should be paid for their work so we hope to offer Sarah a small stipend in addition to the professional development, studio space, and one-on-one support she is receiving as part of the residency.


The dollars and cents of the residency:

$300 Artist Stipend

$300 Production and Installation Materials

$200 Professional Development Workshop Series

$200 Administration and Marketing Costs


Some of the expenses have already been incurred and put on credit,  we hope to recoup what has already spent.  If we do not meet our $1000 goal, the administrative and marketing costs will be donated, as well as the time of our Director. We need to meet at least $500 of our goal to provide a stipend for Sarah and a stripped down materials budget.

Should we exceed our goal, excess funds will be equally divided between Sarah as an additional stipend, and Resident Arts, to help fund future residency programs. 

We hope you'll help us meet this goal!

We're offering several great incentives for contributors including handmade archival greeting cards, prints, and originals from Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land. Every donor will receive a handwritten thank you, and for everyone who contributes $10 or more, an "Art Lives Here" Resident Arts bumper sticker, so you can show your support for the arts in Mid-Missouri.

What it Means:

This campaign will not only support the creation of this important artwork, but help to validate Resident Arts' Emerging Artists Residency, giving it traction for future growth. We believe the success of this campaign will help to illuminate our work with Mid-Missouri's emerging artists, and build momentum for future residents.

Through her research, Sarah has unearthed an incredible story about Columbia’s geographical, political, and economic histories. We believe these stories are important, and many of our discussions have focused on how the life of "Urban Shrine" will stretch beyond the residency, to ensure that it has the greatest impact. We hope to find a commercial buyer, or a public venue to display the triptych, so that it may continue to engage the community in an exploration of Columbia's history for a long time.

Risks & Challenges:

This project is the first one we have attempted as part of Resident Arts' Emerging Artist Residency.  As a non-profit that has not yet obtained our 501 (c) (3) tax exemption status, our fundraising options are fairly limited. We aren't able to apply for much of the funding that is available to tax exempt organizations. That means that are ability to execute large projects like this one, depend on our ability to raise funds directly from our supporters (you!)

This process has been a learning experience, and together, Madeleine's expertise and Sarah's willingness to go the extra mile, has gotten us pretty far.


We still have a ways to go!

We've already put some of the expenses for this project on credit, but to complete the construction and installation of this project more supplies are necessary. Perhaps even more importantly, we want this piece of work to have a life beyond the end of the residency on May 8th. To do this, both Madeleine and Sarah are working diligently to identify potential buyers for the final work, or possibly a public venue to display the work. This will require, and has already required, several work hours, more installation materials, and other associated costs.

While the project will be completed regardless of how many donations we receive, if we're unable to raise adequate funds we run the risk of having to downsize the project significantly, losing much of the impact we've already worked so hard at achieving.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Share this campaign! Use IndieGoGo's tools to share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or via email. You can also like us on Facebook, or Sign Up for our email list to keep up with Resident Arts' opportunities for artists and the supporting community.

You can also attend First Fridays, May 1st at 7pm for Sarah's presentation of the completed triptych. RSVP on our Facebook event page!

Special Thanks
to Sasha Goodnow for making our campaign video and to Rip Rap for providing the music.
story_txt: Our Story:Resident Arts Emerging Artist ResidencyResident Arts' mission is to provide professional development opportunities for artists at every level of their career to cultivate the arts locally and broaden the horizons of local artists, nationally. Our programs train young, emerging, and professional artists as well as supporters of the arts to embrace experimentation and critical thinking to lay a foundation for sustainable creative practice in the region.Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land is the first resident in our Emerging Artist Residency program. Unlike traditional residency programs, local emerging artists inhabit the studio on a part-time basis. They undergo career coaching and attend the professional development workshop series to bolster their arts career, learning about marketing, grant writing, concept development, and more. The resident artist works to create a large-scale work that is beyond the scope of their existing practice. The artist then presents the final work to the public.Resident Arts' director works along the resident throughout the course of the three months to help realize their artistic vision for the work, while at the same time acting as a support system for time management, funding, and promotion of the work. We believe artists benefit greatly from this kind of professional support, and that it can help emerging artists take their careers to the next level. The artist: Sarah Goodnow Riley-LandSarah Goodnow Riley-Land is an incredible local artist who is dedicated to Columbia's artistic vibrancy. She has done community work with True/False Film Festival, Citizen Jane Film Festival, the North Village Farmers and Artisans Market and has exhibited at local shops and exhibition spaces throughout the city.  The project: Urban ShrineSarah's dedication and fascination with this city is what prompted the inspiration for "Urban Shrine" a work that has been, until now, purely research. Sarah investigated the origins of Columbia's smokestacks, iconic mid-west imagery that flanks our skyline, but is often un-considered. Sarah wanted to know "Who made these?" "Why are they here?"Like an archaeologist, she dug into our city's history to find a story of a great fire, of new growth, and of a city made. She brings to us, a story about how our city became the college town it is, how industry and politics shaped our landscape. This story will be made manifest in "Urban Shrine" which aims to explore the power, mystery, forgotten history, and narrative contained in the urban monuments through the use of spiritual visual vocabularies.Making it Happen:In Resident Arts' Emerging Artist Residency, artists inhabit the studio. But Sarah is working on more than just the nuts and bolts of art-making to complete this project. While we spend time bolstering her artistic practice with the logistics and production of a large-scale work, we've also been helping to professionalize her career with one-on-one consultation, professional development workshops, and time management. While Madeleine, Resident Arts' Director, works to help refine and promote the work, Sarah is learning who she has the potential to be as an artist, and as a businesswoman.Resident Arts believes that artists should be paid for their work so we hope to offer Sarah a small stipend in addition to the professional development, studio space, and one-on-one support she is receiving as part of the residency.The dollars and cents of the residency:$300 Artist Stipend$300 Production and Installation Materials$200 Professional Development Workshop Series$200 Administration and Marketing CostsSome of the expenses have already been incurred and put on credit,  we hope to recoup what has already spent.  If we do not meet our $1000 goal, the administrative and marketing costs will be donated, as well as the time of our Director. We need to meet at least $500 of our goal to provide a stipend for Sarah and a stripped down materials budget.Should we exceed our goal, excess funds will be equally divided between Sarah as an additional stipend, and Resident Arts, to help fund future residency programs. We hope you'll help us meet this goal!We're offering several great incentives for contributors including handmade archival greeting cards, prints, and originals from Sarah Goodnow Riley-Land. Every donor will receive a handwritten thank you, and for everyone who contributes $10 or more, an "Art Lives Here" Resident Arts bumper sticker, so you can show your support for the arts in Mid-Missouri.What it Means:This campaign will not only support the creation of this important artwork, but help to validate Resident Arts' Emerging Artists Residency, giving it traction for future growth. We believe the success of this campaign will help to illuminate our work with Mid-Missouri's emerging artists, and build momentum for future residents.Through her research, Sarah has unearthed an incredible story about Columbia’s geographical, political, and economic histories. We believe these stories are important, and many of our discussions have focused on how the life of "Urban Shrine" will stretch beyond the residency, to ensure that it has the greatest impact. We hope to find a commercial buyer, or a public venue to display the triptych, so that it may continue to engage the community in an exploration of Columbia's history for a long time. Risks & Challenges:This project is the first one we have attempted as part of Resident Arts' Emerging Artist Residency.  As a non-profit that has not yet obtained our 501 (c) (3) tax exemption status, our fundraising options are fairly limited. We aren't able to apply for much of the funding that is available to tax exempt organizations. That means that are ability to execute large projects like this one, depend on our ability to raise funds directly from our supporters (you!)This process has been a learning experience, and together, Madeleine's expertise and Sarah's willingness to go the extra mile, has gotten us pretty far. We still have a ways to go!We've already put some of the expenses for this project on credit, but to complete the construction and installation of this project more supplies are necessary. Perhaps even more importantly, we want this piece of work to have a life beyond the end of the residency on May 8th. To do this, both Madeleine and Sarah are working diligently to identify potential buyers for the final work, or possibly a public venue to display the work. This will require, and has already required, several work hours, more installation materials, and other associated costs.While the project will be completed regardless of how many donations we receive, if we're unable to raise adequate funds we run the risk of having to downsize the project significantly, losing much of the impact we've already worked so hard at achieving. Other Ways You Can Help:Share this campaign! Use IndieGoGo's tools to share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or via email. You can also like us on Facebook, or Sign Up for our email list to keep up with Resident Arts' opportunities for artists and the supporting community.You can also attend First Fridays, May 1st at 7pm for Sarah's presentation of the completed triptych. RSVP on our Facebook event page!Special Thanksto Sasha Goodnow for making our campaign video and to Rip Rap for providing the music.

story:
An Online Gift Registry For Art

Gather is an online shop that features local artists and sells their work. Our next step is to be the matchmakers between couples seeking unique and local items for their registries, and artists seeking a new market. When we started this endeavor we thought we would be able to easily build an online registry site using an existing e-commerce site, like the template that hosts our current shop. But we were wrong, the options out there simply won't work for what we need to create. We need a site which allows couples to log-in and create their own gift registry, and then send their unique, personal gallery URL to their wedding guests. This is why we need you. We are raising funds through this campaign to build an on-line art gift registry that is easy to use, secure, and as unique as the products we are promoting. 


The Bride. The Artist. The Gift Giver.

We’re the team, and best friends, behind Gather. Hilary was a bride last year, wishing she could register for hand made ceramic dishes instead of standard china from a big box store. Anna is a ceramic artist with a passion for bringing art out of the museum and into peoples homes. Rachel has been a wedding guest more times than she can count and found herself wanting a more creative alternative to the towels and toasters that fill traditional gift registries.

Over the years we've found ourselves thinking - why isn't there a gift registry that specializes in art?

So we created Gather, an online retail shop featuring a curated collection of pieces by local artists as the first step toward realizing our dream of an art gift registry. 


Our Goal: Gather Couples, Artists and Guests Together Online

With our shop we promote local artists and sell their work. Our next goal is to be the matchmakers between couples seeking unique and local items for their registries, and artists seeking a new market. Here's how it will work:
Step 1: Engaged couples will be able to build a personal registry page with items they pick from our permanent gallery, and will also be able to suggest new artists to include on their individual registry. 
Step 2: Their wedding (and shower and engagement party) guests will view the couple's personal registry, purchase gifts, or make contributions to larger-ticket items. 
Step 3: The Gather website handles all the logistics needed to make purchases happen smoothly.
Step 4: Gifts are delivered, couples are thrilled with new art that fills their home and guests feel satisfied knowing that they gave a truly unique and wanted gift. 
Step 5: Is it too much to hope for that this will result in more homes filled with local art, more people engaging with Minnesota artists, and more couples gathering art well beyond their wedding day, creating a new economy for artists? We don't think so. 

Help Build the Registry
When we started this endeavor we thought we would be able to easily build an online retail site using an existing e-commerce site. There are several web templates for online stores (like the one that hosts our shop) so we thought "heck, there must be one that could hand a registry". But we were wrong. 
When we started to research options, it quickly became apparent that what is out there simply won't work for what we need to create. We need a site where couples can log-in and create their own gift registry, and then send their unique, personal gallery URL to their wedding guests. This is far more complex than any e-commerce platform that currently exists on the web. We want our site to be easy to use, secure, and as unique as the products we are promoting. This will require a complex database to support all the registry and e-commerce functions. So we need a programmer to build it from scratch. 
This is why we need you. We are raising funds to pay a programmer to build the registry website with these essential functions:
  • a gallery of art pieces that show the site's permanent collections
  •  a customer log-in and the ability to build a personalized registry
  • secure retail transactions
Our goal of $18,000 is based on research, multiple technology bids and many conversations about how to best provide services to artists and customers alike. This is why we are asking you, friends, family, artists and art supporters, to help make this dream of creating a new economy for art, a reality.  

Connecting Artists and a New Generation of Collectors: The Long-term Vision

The vision for Gather is simple, create a new economy for art, with a mission to represent and compensate artists fairly for their work and educate consumers to convert them from one-time buyers into collectors.

We seek to create a market for art where artists are paid fairly for the value of their work. Artists work hard, and Gather wants them to be compensated for the hours of labor, creativity and expertise that goes into a single object. Through Gather, we have the opportunity to make connections between artists and buyers, providing education and insight into the artistic process and the business of being an artist. 

Think of a matchmaker - someone who brings two people together with the idea of creating a relationship. We want to bring buyers to artists and artists to buyers to create a relationship that lasts beyond a wedding day. One of the great things about being an art collector is getting to know an artist, learning about their process, following their career, learning how they share their creativity and passion through a tangible piece of work. One of the great things about being an artist is sharing your work and passion with others and learning how they see what you've created. Together artists and collectors get to share in the excitement and beauty of a created object. Gather will turn art lovers into collectors, and match them with the makers. 


I Loved the Art I Saw in the Video, Who Made It?

Check out our image gallery to see the images from the video and find the artists who made them. You can also shop for items by all of these artists at our preview shop: www.gatherartregistry.com


How Else Can I Get Involved?

Thank you so much for considering our campaign. We hope you love this idea as much as we do. While this campaign is focused on raising funds for creating this website, there are other ways to get involved with Gather.

  • Shop at our preview shop! See a sampling of items from our permanent collection artists. There's something for everyone at every price point. (www.gatherartregistry.com)
  • Share this with your friends! We already have some connections to the local art community. But we want more people to know about Gather. Share this with artists who want to create a new economy for art. Share it with your friends who are getting married soon and are setting up their gift registries. Share it with anyone who's ever bought a wedding present!
  • Getting married soon? We would love to include you as one of the first couples to use the new Gather website. And you’ll be in good company, Anna will be using it for her wedding registry next summer!
  • Let’s talk! We’ve been amazed at the energy that has grown around this idea. And some of our best ideas have come from our friends and the artists you see in this campaign. If this is inspiring you or you have your own ideas about Gather, let’s go out for a coffee or a beer and talk about it! Shoot us an e-mail and we’ll set up a time to chat.

story:
Our Story

You asked, we answered:   Free Press readers started offering to pony up from the moment the CFL announced they were fining members of the Winnipeg Blue Bombers for speaking the truth about the refs in the Montreal game.  Here’s your chance to help.


The Impact

These guys don't get paid like NFL players... should they be out of pocket for something the league admits was brutal?


What We Need & What You Get

The total fines are estimated to be $2,500. That is our goal, and we hope to raise it quickly so they are not out of pocket for long.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have cash to spare, use the buttons above to share this campaign with others.  Spread the word!

story:
My Story

My name is Francine Levine. There aren't many spots in my home that aren't stuffed with various natural materials in different stages of decay. It's not that I don't keep a neat home. Where one might see fodder for the compost heap, I see art. I am a papermaking artist. These found materials that I bring home are in the process to become works of art.

I always noticed beautiful objects in nature and brought some home to comtemplate, decorate and for my cat to investigate. But then looking for a diversion from advocating for inner city infants and toddlers and operating a book business, I started taking papermaking classes at the Birmingham Bloomfield Art Center. I quickly mastered the techniques under the guidance of Anne Storm Van Leeuwen, an accomplished paper artist.

I am proud of how far I have taken myself in this endeaver. My work has been shown at the Birmingham Bloomfield Art Center, at Haifa's Bet Chagall Museum, in Jerusalem and in Beersheva. I am eager to progress further in the field

The Impact

I am passionate about papermaking and wish to advance my skills by attending the Watermarks 2012 conference in Cleveland, Ohio. Held at the Morgan Art of Papermaking Conservatory, members of Dard Hunter and IAMPA with join together for five days of workshops, lectures, exhibits and museum tours. A preconference entitled Eco-Print Plant Color for Paper is being offered by India Flint. This is a perfect way for me to advance my skills and take them to the next level.

What I Need & What You Get

To attend the five day conference and preconference I will need $1400. This will cover my transportation to and from Cleveland, 5 nights accommodations and the conference fee of $250. To attend the preconference I will need an additional $225. I am hoping that many small gifts will add up to create a big impact. Everyone who contributes will receive a personal handmade note and the other perks as listed. If not all the funds are raised, hopefully it will lower my costs to attend and progress further with my papermaking.

Other Ways You Can Help

I appreciate any assistance you can give. No contribution is too small. If you are unable to help at this time, maybe you know someone who can. Share this page with them. Email it. Post it on your Facebook page, Twitter, or Blog.
Your help is greatly appreciated.

story:
This autumn time-culture.net is opening as a space for dialogue about how our perception of time organises our individual and collective lives as well as our relation to the natural world. Help us make it happen!

Recognising how time unfolds

Born out of a centuries long drive towards efficiency and speed the networked society has created a world of instantaneous communication and real-time control systems. However, the acceleration of social and natural processes has come at the cost of the health of humans and nature.

Every thing, being or process has its own internal time, or temporality, according to which it develops. Becoming aware of how our lives unfold within a multiplicity of temporalities - say our own physical rhythms, social interactions, seasonal cycles and historical time - is one of our most important tasks if we are going to lead flourishing lives.

Navigating different temporalities has become an essential life skill in the networked society and time-culture.net aims to contribute towards building a new time culture by establishing the dialogue and resources we need to re-integrate with the natural time processes inherent in the world that surrounds us.

Who we are and what we do

Long-time friends and collaborators we have had a dialogue about time for many years and worked together on different projects.

Morten Svenstrup is a father, cellist and composer who recently finished his degree in Modern Culture and Cultural Communication at Copenhagen University. He is perhaps better known for his work as a member of Danish rock band Under Byen and his collaborations with other other musicians, film-makers, and performers.

Jeppe Graugaard is currently researching for his doctoral thesis on grassroots innovations examining the role of narratives and culture in social change. He runs the website PatternWhichConnects where you can also read more about his work.

After we began to extend our conversation around time we noticed how responsive people are to many of the ideas we drew on - the role of time in our lives is not an esoteric matter and everyone relates to being online, changing work modes and information overload.

We believe that dialogue around these kind of things are one of the most important and meaningful things we can do in a time of financial, political and ecological crises.

What We Need & What You Get

We need around $1500 (or £1000) to launch the project. This money will go towards translating Morten's thesis "Time, Art and Society - Contributions to the Composition of New Time Culture" into English. You can read the English abstract here, and the entire thesis here. If this sounds like a lot of money we guarantee you that this is a very low price for translating a text of this length (we are getting it translated by our friend, Peter Holm-Jensen). The translated text is going to be available for free and will provide the majority of the material for time-culture.net.

The website will be created and maintained completely on a voluntary basis, we will not use any of your donation to cover the time and effort we put into the it. Once launched time-culture.net will:

  • Facilitate dialogue about how our perception of time organises our lives individually and collectively 
  • Provide a platform for sharing knowledge and perspectives on the relation between time and social institutions and technology use
  • Create a study group and hold symposiums on time and ecology
  • Pool resources for building a new time culture
 
If we don't reach our target set for this campaign we will consider other funding options - and as a last resort use the money we do raise to get portions of the text translated.

If you can't make a contribution but would like to help us realise this project, please help spread the word about this campaign - share by email, Facebook or Twitter.

Visit time-culture.net for more about the project, the underlying analysis and what we hope to achieve.

You can read the English abstract here, and the entire thesis here. If this sounds like a lot of money we guarantee you that this is a very low price for translating a text of this length (we are getting it translated by our friend, Peter Holm-Jensen). The translated text is going to be available for free and will provide the majority of the material for time-culture.net.
The website will be created and maintained completely on a voluntary basis, we will not use any of your donation to cover the time and effort we put into the it. Once launched time-culture.net will:

Facilitate dialogue about how our perception of time organises our lives individually and collectively 
Provide a platform for sharing knowledge and perspectives on the relation between time and social institutions and technology use
Create a study group and hold symposiums on time and ecology
Pool resources for building a new time culture


 
If we don't reach our target set for this campaign we will consider other funding options - and as a last resort use the money we do raise to get portions of the text translated.

If you can't make a contribution but would like to help us realise this project, please help spread the word about this campaign - share by email, Facebook or Twitter.
Visit time-culture.net for more about the project, the underlying analysis and what we hope to achieve.

story:
To very briefly summarise, I will draw 7 lines with LASER between the earth and the other planets in our local space, making an incomprehensibly big diagram -- a drawing, in fact, that is better measured in time rather than space. Light takes about 4 hours to get to Neptune, so the whole performance will take at least that. But there are numerous other problems that need sorting, in collboration with cosomolgists, mathematicians, etc. The objective is to have all 7 lines of light simultaneouslyconnecting us to our neighbours. 

This is a long-term public drawing performance that explores space-time relations, using the coherent light of LASER technology as a kind of pure line, drawn across the geometry of space itself as a support. The drawing will be a simple node-link graphic – an important networking diagram in logic and computer science, that allows views on relationships that are otherwise very difficult to grasp. This particular use of node-link graphics will give us a view on the inconceivable, pushing our understanding of drawing as a thinking tool to an extreme. Like any drawing, lines will be made on surfaces, but the sum and substance of those lines and surfaces will be decisively uncertain. It thus interrogates the advantages of technical graphics by directly engaging with things that cannot be made easier to understand through them. Is there a space that disallows the mapping of logical relations by node-link graphics? Is connectivity always a knowable state? What are the upper limits of the denotational logic of such diagrams? The actual performance of the drawing will require collaborations between disciplines, to support a diagram that is actually and equally measurable in temporal terms as in spatial terms.

Aside from the actual performance, which has complex staging and technical requirements, there will be outputs of preparatory drawings, diagrams and models which describe the problems at hand, and possible solutions. The collaborative nature of the drawing will provide opportunities for interactions between artists and scientists, thinking over drawings of the invisible, and the impossible. Beginning the research and development for this project at the NIDA/Share Artistic Research symposium, near Vilnius, Lithuania, will provide crucial information and discussion. I am seeking funding for what will be a 2 year program of creativity and collaboration. All funds collected will go to technical and related costs: the target is CAD 1200/ USD1200/ GBP 750.

I have written about and presented aspects of this idea in a number of peer-reviewed journals and presentation contexts - all that is left is the drawing of the drawing.

story:
Our Indiegogo campaign was a total success!  We are now going into full production, if you would like you can still participate by visiting us at: http://thislightshines.com

"This Light Shines" is a digital exhibition to honor those we've loved and lost.  To remember those we light candles: at churches, on lakes, and some send lanterns into the heavens. The goal of this project is to continue that tradition on-line, and light up 1,500 candles on an interactive map, and around the world. 


We lost a dear friend in 2012. Adi (ah-dee) sold candles on Etsy, but when he fell sick the business went to the wayside. We retrieved the remaining supplies from his family and began to develop a new candle in his honor, centered around the Buddhist belief of rebirth. 

The essence of the Buddhist belief in rebirth is that our energy is carried  forward. We are considered to be an endless energy passing from one to the next, much like the flame of a candle lighting another. The flame transfers, but the new flame carries its own identity.


When you support our Indiegogo campaign, you’ll receive a hand-made, numbered candle as a gift, which you’ll be able to register on http://thislightshines.com. From there, you’ll be able to dedicate the light to the memory of someone you’ve loved.


We will pin-point the flame on an interactive map. Using the hashtag #shines4 will cause your flame to blossom into a Lotus Flower for eight hours. Each time you think of your loved one, you can tweet the map to keep their blossom full.


A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit a health campaign for those in need of assistance. If this project is successful, we hope to develop other candles for more causes.

This interactive art project is one of the many ways that we carry Adi’s energy forward..  

All candles will be shipped before April 2014.  We are asking everyone to light their devoted candle for the first night on April 4th, so we can share in a communal showing of love for all those whom have passed… and light up the world.


*Pictured - Limited Edition Buddha Photo.

OUR CHALLENGES:

Website development will be key in our endeavor. We have sought the advice of some of the top developers in NYC on this project - but implementation of social interactions is always challenging. We will continue to look for and work with the best talent in NYC to make this website a reality.

Candle production: We've prototyped and tested the candles with the highest quality materials available. But this product is handmade and mass-production will be complicated and slow, we look forward to the challenge and are confident that we will reach out goal date of April 4th. If there is a delay in production we will let you know as soon as possible.

Our initial goal of $7500 is to place a minimum order for 2500 candles.
Our secondary goal of $15,000 will address more technical aspects of the website.  With challenges in social interaction we hope 

We are excited for you to join us on our journey! LET'S LIGHT IT UP!

---

Now in 8+ Countires!

story:
Please help my tarot decks find their way to eager hands.


Hello, I'm Colleen.

For years now I have wanted to Illustrate a tarot deck. Up until I began work on the series I knew relatively little about tarot, but I was attracted to the idea of expressing through symbolism the rather involved respective meanings of each of the cards into clearly evocative and aesthetically graceful compositions. The number of pieces (78) is much more than in any of my past series. The challenge is exciting and has already been a very transformative process for me creatively. Most of all though, I hope to see my illustration in the hands of people who can study and interact with it intimately; to create something and then be able to really surrender ownership of it to the user.

My process
As both an illustrator and fine artist I value the time honored character and vitality of painstakingly hand drawn illustrations. After months of work I am about half way through the illustration of this 78 piece series and seeking funding to see it fully illustrated, printed, and in the hands of anyone who could appreciate it.

What this project really costs:
  • Each marker costs 4 dollars (each illustration exhausts about 1.5 markers)
  • Each Pencil costs 2 dollars (every two illustrations exhaust about 3 colored pencils)
  • 1 sheet of Paris Bleed-proof paper costs .275 dollars
  • Every illustration costs about 8 hours of my life
  • The estimated printing cost is 15 dollars per deck

And in return...
I am not looking for any handouts here all donations at the requested levels will be treated as pre-orders on prints, decks, and original illustrations at a considerable discount from the post printing price. All pre-orders will ship promptly upon completion of the project (estimated to be in early September) before the opening of the show.

And remember, if you can't contribute financially any kind of support you can offer is still always welcome.
Share a link to my campaign or to my Etsy site Written by Rabbits. Or just hug me the next time you see me, I need it.

story:
(Image: Some Places I Have Never Been To, 2003)

Elly Clarke

I am an artist & curator and founder of Clarke Gallery in Berlin / Birmingham. I have been invited to put on a solo show at Techno Park Studios in Melbourne in May and I am raising funds to cover my flight and most basic expenses to help me to do this. The planned exhibition dates are 12th-27th May 2012; I will be in Australia for about three weeks.
 
I will present a variety of projects in this show, including:
 
  • Some Places I Have Never Been To, 2003 - a slide show of 81 (old fashioned) slides, projected small direct onto the wall. The slides were taken by my father during travels he went on during 1950s - '80s, but which were discoverd only after he died.
  • The Leica Replacement Project, 2010 - Photographs and drawings of (Leica) photographs that were sold from 100 I selected and uploaded to Flickr in an attempt to raise cash to replace my stolen camera. This project has never been exhibited before. See the whole series on Flickr here.
  • my three-screen video installation Moscow to Beijing. Previously exhibited at venues that include Kiasma Museum, Helsinki; The Banff Centre, Canada; London Gallery West, University of Westminster, London; Museum of Fine Arts, Ekaterinburg & the National Centre of Contemporary Art, Moscow, Russia; The Latin Collector/Federico Sevres, New York, USA and, most recently, Milton Keynes Gallery;
  • some other videos & photos made over the past 10 years. 
 
While I am in Melbourne I will also find work to bring back for the third and final part of another exhibition I have curated, BERLIN / BIRMINGHAM / BEYOND / , which is currently installed at mac birmingham.
 
I will also visit some owners of portraits by George Richmond RA (1809-1896), for my ongoing George Richmond Portrait Project, where I am tracing privately owned family portraits by Richmond (who is my great great great grandfather) to private homes in order to photograph both the portraits and their current guardians (descendents of those portrayed) in situ.
 
And finally, the Next Wave festival is also on during the time I want to be there, giving me further opportunity to meet people, for future connections and collaborations for both my own practice and Clarke Gallery.

Funding Strategies

I have used alternative funding strategies at various points in my career, to help me attend or organise events and exhibitions that fall outside Arts Council / British Council or other funding remits, and as well has having helped me do projects I would not otherwise have been able to, they have resulted in new work being produced.

More recently, thinking about the difficulty of coming by arts funding - as well as of selling work - resulted in the exhibition BERLIN/ BIRMINGHAM/ BEYOND / at mac birmingham. I wrote an article to accompany this show, entitled 'Why mention money when we're looking at art?', which you can read here.  

Other ways in which you can help

Please promote this via Twitter/Facebook or best of all word of mouth. You can find Clarke Gallery on Facebook and both Clarke Gallery and me on Twitter. Or sign up to the Clarke Gallery maling list.

In any case, THANK YOU very much FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!

All sponsors will be credited on my website as well as in all exhibition material.

story:
Hello, and thank you for visiting our page! We are a group of passionate educators who are on a mission to bring an after school art program to our school! We teach at Voices College Bound Language Academy, which is a high performing dual immersion school located in San Jose, California. Voices is a developing charter school currently in its 7th year. And although our students are excelling academically, the majority of our student population is low-income, which means access to the arts out of school is fairly limited. We all know how crucial the arts are to our student's development of creativity, confidence, and innovation, which is why we want to bring Art to Voices!
    Due to nation wide budget cuts, limited funding for the arts is available. With your contribution, we would get the support we need to build a completely new art program from the bottom up. This means purchasing art materials such as paint brushes, assorted types of paint, card stock, canvas, drawing pencils, charcoal, etc. We would also be using your contribution to take our students on a field trip to an art museum here in San Jose! Classes will be given to our students once a week for one and half hours. Each month focussing in on a new form of media and artist. For example, one of the first projects we have planned is teaching students printmaking using Andy Warhol as a model. Specifically for this project we would need, individual canvases, card stock, ink, and rollers. Each monthly project is budgeted anywhere from 200-250 dollars for roughly 35-40 students, making our total goal to raise $2,200 dollars. Should you choose to contribute to our project, we would love to keep you on our mailing list to send you e-mail updates of the wonderful projects we are confident our students will be producing! 
    Every great thing begins with an idea. But most times, it's the support we receive from our friends, family, and even strangers who believe in the idea that help make it a reality. We are asking for your partnership in making this idea a reality! By bringing art classes to our students we are gifting them with an opportunity that will prosper more than just great art to look at, but a wider knowledge of the arts, and a planted seed of creativity that will continue to bare fruit for the rest of their lives! Creativity that is essential for the real world that follows.
    Please take a moment to share our page with your friends, family, neighbors etc.! Get the word out, so we can make this very idea a reality for our students! Lets bring Art to Voices!

story:
About us
The SCAD Graduate Illustration Club fosters an active graduate community by
connecting students at the Savannah College of Art and Design with industry
professionals. Through workshops, exclusive Skype interviews with prolific artists, and
other visiting artist demonstrations/information sessions, we strive to be a place of
education, resources, and fun within the SCAD Illustration community.
To further our goals, we organize the GIC Illustration Anthology: a juried collection of
exceptional works from Graduate Illustration students to be sent to art directors and
industry professionals of all kinds. The Illustration Anthology is produced exclusively by
SCAD students, providing professional experience and insight into the publication
process while also creating an environment of collaboration and teamwork amongst
students. Contributing students follow the progress of the anthology as we collect
submissions, advertise, and design the anthology, working together to produce the
book.
The following GIC Executives are proud to present and facilitate this project:
President: Natalia Cardona Puerta
Vice President: Ruaida Mannaa
Treasurer: Elle Powell
Secretary: Komal Singh Pahwa
Communications: Meaghan L Mark

Why are we doing this / what is the impact?
Our continued goal is to bridge the gap between student and industry professionals by
producing this publication and getting it to into the hands of art directors. It is our hope
to create networking opportunities and other success for our students while sharing in
the pride of SCAD as a network itself. The Illustration Anthology will be released and
available to purchase at the Illustration Expo, an annual artist market event hosted by
GIC SCAD in May of 2018. This event also aligns with Art Directors week at SCAD,
which means artists in the SCAD Illustration Anthology and at the Expo will have a
chance to show their work and speak with art directors. As a result, part of the

Indiegogo funding will also allow us to reserve and provide a number of anthologies as
take-away thank yous for visiting art directors. 
This project not only connects the SCAD community but also connects us to the outside
professional world! This juried initiative is a great way to showcase our collective talent
and help students establish contacts that could have a positive impact on their careers.
Furthermore, the book serves as a souvenir of the SCAD community and experience.
Let’s help the SCAD community leave a lasting impression!

What We Need & What You Get 
What will my contribution be used for?
Printing: Supporting the local community is important to us, so we will be printing
exclusively in the Savannah area.
Packaging: This will cover any extra supplies for packaging and storage of books
before shipment.
Shipping: Help us ship these beauties safely and quickly!
Art Director copies: As previously mentioned, we want to set aside a number of copies
for visiting art directors and send copies to relevant art directors in the United States.
What do I get?
Every little bit counts, so we want to say thanks to everyone by putting each and every
contributor's name on a special thank you insert within the Illustration Anthology. From
there, the perks just get better and better. They include digital copies, physical copies,
early bird and discounted orders, stickers, and artist prints! 
 

What if we don't make our fundraising goal?

Don't worry! Thanks to Indiegogo's allowance of partial funding, you will still receive any copies of the anthology that you ordered - whether digital or physical.

How else can I help?

You – yes, you! -- have a huge impact on the success of our Anthology, and every
contribution, like, and share counts! We encourage you to get the word out about this
project any way you can. Let's make some noise about our campaign!
The Anthology will be completed in time for the 3rd Annual Illustration Expo in May. The
sooner we are able to get the necessary financing, the sooner we’re able to get the ball
rolling on printing the Anthologies.
We’re ready whenever you are, and we’re excited to get everyone their copies! 

Thank you for reading,

The Graduate Illustration Club Execs

What We Need & What You Get What will my contribution be used for?Printing: Supporting the local community is important to us, so we will be printingexclusively in the Savannah area.Packaging: This will cover any extra supplies for packaging and storage of booksbefore shipment.Shipping: Help us ship these beauties safely and quickly!Art Director copies: As previously mentioned, we want to set aside a number of copiesfor visiting art directors and send copies to relevant art directors in the United States.What do I get?Every little bit counts, so we want to say thanks to everyone by putting each and everycontributor's name on a special thank you insert within the Illustration Anthology. Fromthere, the perks just get better and better. They include digital copies, physical copies,early bird and discounted orders, stickers, and artist prints!  
What if we don't make our fundraising goal?
Don't worry! Thanks to Indiegogo's allowance of partial funding, you will still receive any copies of the anthology that you ordered - whether digital or physical.
How else can I help?
You – yes, you! -- have a huge impact on the success of our Anthology, and everycontribution, like, and share counts! We encourage you to get the word out about thisproject any way you can. Let's make some noise about our campaign!The Anthology will be completed in time for the 3rd Annual Illustration Expo in May. Thesooner we are able to get the necessary financing, the sooner we’re able to get the ballrolling on printing the Anthologies.We’re ready whenever you are, and we’re excited to get everyone their copies! 
Thank you for reading,
The Graduate Illustration Club Execs

story:
"The places of possibility within ourselves are dark because they are ancient and hidden; they have survived and grown strong through that darkness. Within these deep places, each one of us holds an incredible reserve of creativity and power, of unexamined and unrecorded emotion and feeling." -Audre Lorde, "Poetry is not a Luxury"

 

forego the vanities
               for Assata

 

first

witch

ancient

hidden

your magic hands

burn us shadow home

 

-Vanessa Huang, May 18, 2013

 

About this Poem-Print Intervention

On May 2, The FBI announced it was adding Assata Shakur to its "Most Wanted Terrorists" list, adding another $1 million reward to the $1 million bounty already offered by New Jersey.

In response, I penned this poem for Assata, in call and response with her poem, "I believe in living," and with Audre Lorde's poem "For Assata" (from which my poem's title is borrowed), Lorde's always homing essay, "Poetry is not a Luxury," Cheryl Clarke's poem "wearing my cap backwards" (in which she writes, "poets are among the first witches"), and Morgan Bassichis' play "The Witch House".

Inspired by a tree I happened upon over a rainy, thunderous Atlanta weekend, carried by the words and spirit of Assata, Audre, Cheryl, and Morgan, I visioned a two-tone relief print integrating image and text. I carved two linoloeum blocks, tested colors, and made artist proofs for the print I'd love to share with you and yours as we amplify our liberation love frequency in the midst of the state's witch hunt and ever growing climate of terror -- I heard that there are Assata wanted signs all along the New Jersey Turnpike now.

How to Harvest?

To print this poem-print intervention so we can share in our homes and community centers, I need your support and partnership:

  • $8* covers the cost of packaging, shipping, and distribution for each print;
  • $20* covers an hour of access to printmaking studio, tools, materials, and guidance, as well as gas money to get there (to carve two print blocks, test colors, and make artist proofs);
  • $120* honors my love and labor to channel the poem and vision for the print, or to test colors and make the artist proofs;
  • $190* covers the cost to print an edition of 25 prints (with interest and support, we can print a larger edition -- see below);
  • $220* honors my love and labor to carve and refine one of the two linoleum blocks;
  • $295* covers the cost to print an edition of 50 prints (with interest and support, we can print a larger edition -- see below);
  • $555* covers the cost to print an edition of 100 prints.

At minimum, this goal of $500 would cover the cost of distribution, studio access and materials to carve and proof the blocks, and the printing of a 25-print edition. If we raise more, it will honor my own time (see above), as well as cover the cost to print a larger edition (see above).

*Cost includes estimated Indiegogo and third party fees.

Added Perks

In addition to amplifying our liberation love frequency, you can opt in to receiving these perks:

Registration in "Our Poembody Selves"

The course is a journey through the “5 A’s” (appreciation, allowing, affection, attention, acceptance) of loving and living the creative being you are:

  • Befriend the core integrity of your creative aliveness
  • Feed your courage heart to create to the edges of what you’re here to create
  • Celebrate influence and lineage with your council of elders
  • Map your ecology of accountability and support
  • Cultivate a dedicated practice, and honor performance as part of your practice

The series will close with an informal “poemsong swap” and potluck gathering, where you can invite your friends and family to experience a call and response taste of your journey in class. Join us!

Dori Midnight's new elixir for deep healing and radiant protection

For edge walkers, shape shifters, magicians, priestesses, change makers, those who dwell between worlds and genders, and lovers of the great mother. Made with all green and black plants and stones, such as Ladies' Mantle, Ladies' Thumb, Mugwort, Emerald, Green and Black Tourmaline, and more, this powerful elixir can help transform ancient wounds and grief from centuries of oppression, release patterns of shame and self hatred for being different, and create a profound sense of safety so that you can walk the magnificent path you are here to walk.

New chapbook of poems written in Georgia

Poetic Wisdom Reading

One of my letterpress poetry greeting cards

Occupy Capitalism letterpress broadside

About my Practice

POET, ARTIST, AND CULTURAL ORGANIZER Vanessa Huang weaves poemsongs with moments of creative aliveness and transformative encounter, color, and texture in call and response with kindred spirits who dream and make worlds where each and all of us are free. A finalist for Poets & Writers’ 2010 California Writers Exchange Award, Vanessa’s poetry and practice inherit teachings from the prison abolition, migrant justice, gender liberation, transformative justice, disability justice, and reproductive justice movements.

Vanessa’s work and writings have conversed through performance and ritual, moving pictures and digital media, letterwriting, handcrafted letterpress prints, and a range of activist media and national print and online publications, including Revolution Starts at Home: Confronting Intimate Violence Within Activist Communities (South End Press, 2011), Captive Genders: Trans Embodiment and the Prison Industrial Complex (AK Press, 2011), and Feminist Studies. Vanessa’s poetry and cultural organizing have stood-sat with courage hearts including California’s prison hunger strikers, Miss Major, Marilyn Buck, Melissa Roxas, Troy Davis, Cece McDonald, and a range of life-affirming collaborations including the Free Shifa campaign in Atlanta, organizing against transphobic violence and discrimination in NYC, Oakland’s first general strike since 1946, and campaigns in Providence to restore food stamps and voting rights for loved ones returning home from prison.

Additional Ways to Amplify our Liberation Love Frequency

  • Share this poem (or your own!) and information about what's happening with a neighbor or friend, and host a potluck or event about Assata on your porch or with your membership! (For instance, if you're in Atlanta, RBG is hosting a June 2 day for Assata, teach-in, bike ride, and all!)
  • If you haven't already, sign and share this petition on change.org, and check out and follow Alixa Garcia's amazing Arise for Assata Project!
  • Join this team, and share the love with your constellation that loves and believes in the safety and wellbeing of Assata and all poets, witches, freedom dreamers, and liberaton workers in this moment! Message me.
  • Join us for monthly Poetry is not a Luxury Dharmacasts, first Wednesdays of the month! Let's continue growing our courage hearts.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Cindy Lapeña and I'm really passionate about art, writing, and teaching. I have over 20 years of teaching experience, including adult education and professional training experience, and over 10 years of management experience. I'm also an exhibited artist and a published author. My credentials include
  • a Master of Arts in English Literature (focus on Drama and Teaching Creative Writing)
  • a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics for Teachers
  • a Teaching Certificate 6 (Canada)
  • a Diploma in Art (Visual; Canada)
  • TESL Certification (Canada)
The Art 'n' Words campaign will, hopefully, raise enough funds for me to start operating a studio and gallery where I will teach visual arts, oral & written business communication, research & report writing, creative writing, public speaking, speech improvement, and oral reading. I'm doing this because, as an immigrant to Canada, I have been unable to find employment that recognizes and makes use of my varied skills after 6 years of living here. I was laid off from a full-time ESL teaching job last year and have applied to over 20 different jobs, none of which considered me. I was lucky to be accepted to the Self-Employment Benefit program, which has given me the opportunity to take time to establish my own business to assure myself of a career that has been my dream for the longest time.
The federal and provincial budget cuts to education and the arts in PEI, Canada have taken their toll on me and on arts and education as well. A lot of people who would like to pursue their interest in arts or need more time to improve skills in writing and speaking are not given that opportunity. Your contribution will give so many people the opportunity to fulfill their dreams of learning art and writing and becoming exhibited artists and published authors. Your contribution will also provide anyone from the ages of 8 and above the opportunity to improve speaking and writing skills to help them in school and at work. Your contribution will help mold stronger skills in reading and writing, which will, in turn, strengthen the present and future workforce. 

What We Need & What You Get

To start my business, I will need $10,000 CAD, broken up as follows:
  • First month's lease     ..................................................................    $1396.00
  • Technology (computer, 4-in-1 printer, phone, projector)  ...........       1150.00
  • Furniture & fixtures (chairs, tables, whiteboards, organizers) ...         950.00
  • Non-consumables (office equipment, art tools & equipment) ....       1050.00
  • Office & cleaning supplies, writing supplies................................         400.00
  • Art supplies (paints, pencils, fixatives, frames, pads, etc.)........       3150.00
  • Advertising, Marketing, Promotions ...........................................         700.00
  • Professional fees & dues (registrations, memberships, permits)...    910.00
  • Miscellaneous (transportation, photocopying, emergencies).........    300.00
                                                   Total start-up expenses:                   $10,006.00
Every contribution will be acknowledged in social media, on my website, and at my grand gallery opening and launch. Contributors will also receive one-of-a-kind art products that I make, such as bookmarks, artist trading cards, postcards, greeting cards, prints and original paintings from my collection!
Even if I don't meet my goal here, all funds will be put to good use to obtain the most basic necessities, starting with my lease--without which I won't even be able to operate. The other basic necessities include furniture, art supplies, art tools, and lots of paper for writing and printing. 

The Impact

When I came to Canada, I settled on PEI because of the rich cultural community that exists here. I was a little saddened to find out that about 40% of Islanders are illiterate, that there are no strong art programs that run the whole year round, and that so many students and workers do not have the writing and speaking skills they need to do research, reports, or presentations. Writing and speaking skills are extremely important when you are out in the real world, while art is food for the soul and helps make the world a better place. I felt a huge need for this and now that I have been given this chance to teach these skills, I really want it to succeed. All these will help make PEI and, by extension, Canada, a much better place for cultural diversity and professionalism.

Before I came to Canada, I traveled all over the Philippines delivering training workshops to professionals in various industries, especially in education, on Effective Communication, among a multitude of other topics. I prepared countless programs in English for specific purposes, tailored to whatever the industry required. I was also an Assistant Professor in the tertiary level as well as the Executive Director of Benildanze, a college dance company that gave dance scholarships to deserving students. I produced and co-directed 5 successful major performances and 1 summer performance tour, managing the fund-raising, marketing, and other technicalities. 

I have always believed in doing my best and helping others, and I know that I have been contributing to create a better world by using my talents in art, speaking and writing as a teacher. If PEI cannot provide this service to Islanders, I know that I can. My biggest hope is that I will instill a love for art and writing, and a desire to develop excellent communication skills in my students, because IT IS NEVER TOO LATE TO LEARN! 

I will always devote myself to teaching passionate, personalized, progressive, professional programs all year round through creative communication and expression and Art 'n' Words Studio & Gallery is the best way I can do it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't spare a bit of cash now, contributions in kind are also welcome and you can send them to 155 Queen Street, Lower Level, Charlottetown, PE C1A 4B4 Canada. 

Another really big way you can help me is to let others know how they can help me through this link:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/art-n-words/

Indiegogo is such a great tool, and has share tools that make it easier for you to get the word out. All it takes is the click of a button!

story:
Hungarian after English

Dear Friends and Community -support three trans* activists-community organizers (us!)) , members of TransPoint in representing our values and our communities in the upcoming TGEU council in Budapest!

Since our scholarship application for the participation in the council got a negative reply from the organizers' representatives, we choose to turn to our community and friends for your kind support. 340 dollars is required for the three of us to participate in the 3 days of conference-way beyond an average financial ability of Hungarian trans* activists.  In the current conditions, your support mean even much more morally than financially, thus few dollars or many hugs-we will be very grateful for you standing beside us!

We really want to attend the conference, create connections with other trans* individuals form all over Europe and to be able to represent our communities. Also, any sum beyond the 340 dollars will go towards our community building plans. Your kind support strengthens our belief in a need of the work we are doing. 

TransPoint was established in 2013 with goals and activities as following: 

 - Transfeminist activism and advocacy

 - Training of local women's and LGBTQI organizations 

- Training of Hungarian LGBTQ helpline operators

 - Helping to  domestic violence against crisis lines, so that they will be available for all trans

 - Professional editing , medical and educational materials

 - Creating a safe and empowering space for Trans* 

 - Create a strong , inclusive, trans- conscious community

Whom are we?

Kolett , transfeminist blogger and activist (Budapest)

Kolett is a transfeminist activist and a trans*blogger. For the last few years she was coordinating  the Human Rights Education Group and the Women's Group in Amnesty International in Hungary. Kolett was a member of 2013 Budapest Pride organizing team. Her blog-Transitions gets thousands of views every year .Niki is  founding member of the Trans- point . Her objectives in the activism include raising awareness of violence against trans women, as well connecting among human rights, feminist and LGBT movements. 

Andreas, trans* activist and counselor (Budapest)

Andreas is LGBTQI activist since 2009. Andreas is a frequent trainer and lecturer on LGBT issues, he is the only trans* counselor on the Hungarian LGBT crisis line, a core member of TransPoint,  a co-director of  Home-International Center for Holistic change and the founder of TransHome-trans*project for spiritual and psychological empowerment of Trans* communities and individuals. 

Florish, trans* and human rights activist (Budapest)

Flosrish is a trans*activist in anti globalization and critical civil disobedience movement. He is an LGBTQ activist since 2007  and is an organizing activist of the asexual community in Budapest. At present, Florish is a TransPoint core team member. Florish is a student of veterinary studies and his objectives in activism also include a promotion of equal access to health services. 

we thank you very much for your kind support, 

and sent you Love

K, A, F


Támogasd Te is a TranszPont aktivistáit, hogy részt vehessenek a TGEU konferenciáján!


Segíts anyagi hozzájárulással a TranszPont három transznemű aktivistájának, hogy részt vehessen a 5th European Transgender Council budapesti eseményén!


Mivel az ösztöndíjért beadott pályázatunkat a szervezők elutasították, ezért a közösséghez fordulunk támogatásért. A pályázat során szerzett tapasztalataink után nagyon sokat jelent nekünk a bizalmatok és a mellettünk való kiállás. 340 dollars szükséges ahhoz, hogy a csoportunkból három helyi transz aktivista részt vehessen a konferencián. Bármilyen kis összegű támogatás nagyon sokat számit. Ha nincs lehetőséged anyagi hozzájárulással segíteni, akkor minden bíztatást vagy támogatást szívesen veszünk!


Nagyon szeretnénk részt venni a konferencián, hogy hitelesen képviselhessük közösségünket. Bizalmatok és segítségetek megerősít minket abban, hogy szükség van a munkánkra.


A TranszPont tevékenységeiről:

- Transzfeminista aktivizmus és érdekképviselet

- Hazai LMBTQ és nőjogi szervezetek tréningezése

- Az egyetlen magyarországi LMBTQ segélyvonal operátorainak képzése

- Segítjük transzbaráttá tenni a hazai erőszakellenes krízisvonalakat, amelyek így elérhetővé válnak minden transz számára

- Szakmai, egészségügyi és ismeretterjesztő anyagok szerkesztése

- Egy elnyomásoktól mentes biztonságos tér megteremtése

- Erős, befogadó, öntudatos transz közösség létrehozása


Aktivistáinkról:


Kolett, transzfeminista blogger és aktivista (Budapest)

2010 és 2013 között az Amnesty International Magyarország aktivistája, 2012-től az Emberi Jogi Oktatás Csoport és a Nők Csoport koordinátora. A 2013-as Budapest Pride szervezőcsapatának tagja. ATransition Blog szerkesztője. A TranszPont alapító tagja. Célkitűzései között szerepel a transz tudatosság erősítése a hazai emberi jogi, LMBTQ és feminista mozgalmakban.


András, transz aktivista (Budapest)

2009 óta önkéntes a Háttér Társaságnál. A Home és a Trans Home egyik vezetője. A Home logisztikai menedzsere és konzulense. A TranszPont tagja. Célkitűzései között szerepel a transz közösség építése és az egyéni segítségnyújtás.


Flóris, transz és emberi jogi aktivista (Budapest)

A magyarországi globalizációkritikai és civil engedetlenségi mozgalom aktivistája. 2007 óta LMBTQ aktivista, az aszexuális közösség egyik szervezője. Jelenleg a TETT (Társaság Egy Tudatos Társadalomért) és a TranszPont tagja. Állatorvosi tanulmányokat folytat, érdeklődési területe az endokrinológia. Célkitűzései között szerepel az egészségügyi szolgáltatásokhoz való egyenlő hozzáférés előmozdítása.
story_txt:
Hungarian after EnglishDear Friends and Community -support three trans* activists-community organizers (us!)) , members of TransPoint in representing our values and our communities in the upcoming TGEU council in Budapest!Since our scholarship application for the participation in the council got a negative reply from the organizers' representatives, we choose to turn to our community and friends for your kind support. 340 dollars is required for the three of us to participate in the 3 days of conference-way beyond an average financial ability of Hungarian trans* activists.  In the current conditions, your support mean even much more morally than financially, thus few dollars or many hugs-we will be very grateful for you standing beside us!We really want to attend the conference, create connections with other trans* individuals form all over Europe and to be able to represent our communities. Also, any sum beyond the 340 dollars will go towards our community building plans. Your kind support strengthens our belief in a need of the work we are doing. TransPoint was established in 2013 with goals and activities as following:  - Transfeminist activism and advocacy - Training of local women's and LGBTQI organizations - Training of Hungarian LGBTQ helpline operators - Helping to  domestic violence against crisis lines, so that they will be available for all trans - Professional editing , medical and educational materials - Creating a safe and empowering space for Trans*  - Create a strong , inclusive, trans- conscious communityWhom are we?Kolett , transfeminist blogger and activist (Budapest)Kolett is a transfeminist activist and a trans*blogger. For the last few years she was coordinating  the Human Rights Education Group and the Women's Group in Amnesty International in Hungary. Kolett was a member of 2013 Budapest Pride organizing team. Her blog-Transitions gets thousands of views every year .Niki is  founding member of the Trans- point . Her objectives in the activism include raising awareness of violence against trans women, as well connecting among human rights, feminist and LGBT movements. Andreas, trans* activist and counselor (Budapest)Andreas is LGBTQI activist since 2009. Andreas is a frequent trainer and lecturer on LGBT issues, he is the only trans* counselor on the Hungarian LGBT crisis line, a core member of TransPoint,  a co-director of  Home-International Center for Holistic change and the founder of TransHome-trans*project for spiritual and psychological empowerment of Trans* communities and individuals. Florish, trans* and human rights activist (Budapest)Flosrish is a trans*activist in anti globalization and critical civil disobedience movement. He is an LGBTQ activist since 2007  and is an organizing activist of the asexual community in Budapest. At present, Florish is a TransPoint core team member. Florish is a student of veterinary studies and his objectives in activism also include a promotion of equal access to health services. we thank you very much for your kind support, 
and sent you LoveK, A, FTámogasd Te is a TranszPont aktivistáit, hogy részt vehessenek a TGEU konferenciáján!Segíts anyagi hozzájárulással a TranszPont három transznemű aktivistájának, hogy részt vehessen a 5th European Transgender Council budapesti eseményén!Mivel az ösztöndíjért beadott pályázatunkat a szervezők elutasították, ezért a közösséghez fordulunk támogatásért. A pályázat során szerzett tapasztalataink után nagyon sokat jelent nekünk a bizalmatok és a mellettünk való kiállás. 340 dollars szükséges ahhoz, hogy a csoportunkból három helyi transz aktivista részt vehessen a konferencián. Bármilyen kis összegű támogatás nagyon sokat számit. Ha nincs lehetőséged anyagi hozzájárulással segíteni, akkor minden bíztatást vagy támogatást szívesen veszünk!Nagyon szeretnénk részt venni a konferencián, hogy hitelesen képviselhessük közösségünket. story:
Short Summary

Every magazine, newspaper, poster, advert, film and music video has edited images of unattainable 'beauty'. We have been brainwashed for years into thinking that we should look a certain way to be accepted in society. We're tired of being told every day that our bodies aren't good enough. 

This project is just the beginning. We want to start a revolution. We want to celebrate women's bodies for exactly what they are regardless of age or shape. We want to help women and girls to feel powerful, in control, confident.

We can't do this on good intentions alone, we need money for production and marketing of our first body positive swimwear calendar and would like to raise even more to help with future projects too.

The calendar will feature 12 photos of women in swimwear taken by carefully selected photographers. In each photo the models will be in complete control of the styling and will be left free to do their hair and makeup as they like it and wear what they feel comfortable in. There will be a mixture of solo and group shots.

The final calendar will be sold online with 25% of the profits going towards body positive charities.

What We Need & What You Get

Our fundraising goal is £3000, made up as follows.

Photography and post-production - £600

Initial Print Run & Perks - £1800

Marketing - £300

Contingency - £600
