story:
Brushwood Center at Ryerson Woods

Nurturing art, nature and discovery

Help us explore the relationship between people and nature through art by supporting quality art exhibitions offered in a stunning setting—Brushwood Center at Ryerson Woods.

Aligning art and nature is key to our mission, and Brushwood Center does it well. Here visitors find diverse ways to discover nature in every season—be it through creative programs offered within the historic and intimate Brushwood Center home or the surrounding vast and beautiful woodlands.

We seek support for our gallery exhibitions—showcasing painting, photography, sculpture, video, performance art, spoken word, music, fiber arts and more.  These provide the visitor an opportunity to contemplate the natural world through the expression of emerging and established artists. 

Our goal is to lead each visitor on a personal journey of discovery while deepening their environmental ethic.

Who We Are

Brushwood Center at Ryerson Woods is a non-profit that connects people with nature. We seek to build an environmental ethic through innovative public programs presented against a backdrop of stately woods where pre-settlement flora and fauna still flourish.

Brushwood Center invites a diverse community of voices to engage in the discourse around art, culture, the environment, as well as the relationship between those concepts.

Ryerson Woods

Brushwood Center is located in the heart of Ryerson Woods, a property of the Lake County Forest Preserves. Ryerson Woods is one of the most ecologically significant preserves in Illinois.  Serving as a living classroom, Ryerson Woods is an oasis of 561 acres of magnificent woodlands.

What We Do

“Art,” according to the French post-impressionist painter Pierre Bonnard, would “never be able to exist without nature.” Since 1984,Brushwood Center has drawn people into nature with innovative programs that feature art, music, film and literature, often at little or no cost to the public. Offered out of an elegant and historic Classical Revival home (the Ryerson family’s former summer home) with a columned portico, Brushwood Center’s programs are unique in the region and offer the community a myriad of ways to discover the magic of nature.

We Need You

We need

Brushwood Center relies on the generosity of the public to support its work.  This crowdfunding campaign will raise vital funds for Brushwood Center’s art exhibition program.  With your donation and help in spreading the word about this campaign, we cultivate a community that understands the importance of Brushwood Center’s mission.

Current show:

Views from Brushwood Farm

Photographs by Edward L. Ryerson and Edward Ranney, 1937–1974

As a special celebration for Brushwood Center’s 30 years, this exhibition reflects back on the visionary family that guaranteed the protection of this special place.  The show combines photographs made by Edward L. Ryerson of activities of his family and friends at Brushwood Farm with pictures of the house and woods made by his grandson, professional photographer Edward Ranney, before the property was transferred to the Lake County Forest Preserves in 1971.  Mr. Ryerson's pictures are reprinted from the extensive photographic archive he compiled between 1937–1971, and the pictures of the house, as furnished by the Ryersons, are from the collection made by their grandson Edward Ranney between 1972–1974. The majority of photographs presented are black and white, augmented by color pictures made by Mr. Ryerson after the late 1950s. Exhibition runs September 7 through October 30, 2014.

Upcoming show:

Hidden / Protected:  Paintings by Nina Weiss

This series of landscape oil paintings by artist Nina Weiss depict nature with colors intense, lush and dramatic.  Her work travels beyond traditional ideas of a green landscape, as she teases out the complex colors of nature, creating layers of contrast, line and form.  Through her paintings, she celebrates hidden natural landscapes that are often ignored or overlooked in urban environments.  Her work provides the viewer with a contemporary look at the traditional genre of landscape. Exhibition runs November 9 through December 23, 2014.

Recent exhibitions include:

Avian Spirits

For centuries, artists have been attracted to—and inspired by—the ephemeral qualities of birds. Soaring above the Earth, birds have long symbolized freedom and aspiration. Including the work of 14 artists, this group exhibition presents birds as metaphors for the human spirit.  Curated by Franck Mercurio.  July 13 through August 31, 2014.

Moving Targets

The year 2014 marks the centenary of the extinction of the passenger pigeon, once the most abundant bird in North America that was hunted to extinction within a period of 40 years. Moving Targets, a collaborative art installation by Ann Rosenthal and Steffi Domike, links the artists’ forced family migrations to the story of the passenger pigeon through a shared visual language, maps, and creative research. In addition to exhibiting their own work, the artists invited 14 artists to each represent a state within the former pigeon nesting range, to create a passenger pigeon “portrait gallery.” May/June 2014

If you have visited Ryerson Woods or the galleries of Brushwood Center, you know that it is run by a small group of dedicated staff and volunteers.  But like any other museum or educational institution, dedication alone is not enough to make it work—money is needed to pay for the staff members who conceive and organize the events, the curators who assemble exhibitions, the supplies required to professionally hang exhibitions and the talented artists who often travel to us from far beyond Illinois.  Many costs are associated with art exhibitions. Because Brushwood Center does not pass the cost of art exhibitions to the individuals and families who attend our events, we rely on the generous donations of people like you who believe in the importance of our mission. 

Brushwood Center at Ryerson Woods is grateful for your donation of any amount and offers a variety of perks to those who contribute, from tote bags to limited edition artwork by talented regional artists.  Please make sure to review the list of these perks before deciding on the amount of your donation . . .

The Perks

At $25, you’ll receive a packet of milkweed seeds.  The population of the emblematic monarch butterfly is diminishing. By spreading native milkweed seeds (which is the monarch’s sole food source) in your backyard garden, you provide the monarchs with vital habitat and food.

For $50, we offer you the opportunity to give the gift of a family membership to Brushwood Center.  Members receive discounts on programs, receive our newsletter, the Ryerson Almanac, and will be recognized for the gift in the fall issue of our newsletter.

With a gift of $100, you’ll receive a photograph by professional nature photographer Carol Freeman.  Freeman is the founder of the Endangered Species Photography Project, and her photos have appeared in well-known journals like National Geographic and Nikon World.  After your donation is made, we will contact you with your three photograph options.

At $250, you’ll receive a tote bag featuring Brushwood Center’s attractive logo which can be used to haul groceries or carry books.

We offer a limited-edition medallion to those who donate $500.  Designed by Glenn and Deborah Doering of DOEprojekts, the medallion is based on the Doering’s outdoor installation Code for Avian Navigation that appears as part of the Avian Spirits exhibition.  The medallion is engraved with the stylized images that reflect homing mechanisms used by migratory birds.  The Doering’s work has been exhibited and performed at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago and the Art Institute of Chicago.

For $1000, Brushwood Center offers a remarkable sculpture of a passenger pigeon designed and fabricated by artists Sarah Belknap and Joseph Belknap.  The Belknap’s work has been displayed in prominent museums and galleries throughout the country, including the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago and are instructors at The School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

Finally, for $2,500, you and up to seven guests will be given a private tour of Brushwood Center and its exhibits by Nick Bothfeld, chair of Brushwood Center’s Board of Directors.  On the tour, Nick will discuss the history of the Ryerson estate, the historic building and the artwork on display.

story:
I am Eileen Lillian Doyle, and I am fundraising for the exhibition Garbage World 7 - Never Nothing Now in Philadelphia, PA at the gallery Little Berlin. I am a curatorial member of Little Berlin, which I joined in July of 2012. My background is as a performance artist and I have my BFA from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago. My on-going project is the Garbage World Performance Series, which I founded in Chicago in 2009. I took on this project with the thought of creating an opportunity for artists to present the work they're committed to make -- be it messy, joyful, or grotesque. Over the course of a year between 2009 and 2010 I organized four events. Garbage World 4 was a three day festival with 24 performances. Many of the performers were recurring to allow opportunities for experimentation and development of new work. Afterwards, I left Chicago to live in Austin due to family concerns and took a hiatus from event organizing. I moved back to the East Coast, specifically New Jersey, at the end of February 2012, then moved to Philadelphia in May 2012. My aim in Philadelphia has been to integrate into a new art community and to take the transition as an opportunity to push my work in a new direction.

Garbage World 7 pushes this project into new territory and is part of an effort to create an exchange between two cities, Chicago and Philadelphia. Garbage World 5 in Philadelphia and 6 in Chicago featured artists from both cities, and 7 is the continuation of this trend. Both cities share similar artist-driven communities and can learn new ways of art-making and organization from each other. It is also important in artistic development to travel and experience the nuances of different cities since the change of pace and environment can influence new ideas.

Garbage World 7 will have performances and installations occurring through the month of July. On First Friday, July 5 from 6PM to 10PM, a performance ephemera installation will open. Costumes, notes, and props from artists who performed at previous Garbage Worlds will be installed within Little Berlin's space. Those who have confirmed submissions, thus far, are: Beth Heinly (Philadelphia), William Haughery (Philadelphia), Adam Rose (Chicago), Heather Lynn (Chicago), Jose Hernandez (Chicago), Molly Shea (Los Angeles), Sara Heymann (Chicago), Meg McCarville (Chicago), Fred J. Henzel (Chicago), Katrina Therese-Schaag (Madison, WI), Andrew Oberstadt (Dakar, Senegal), Josh Finck (Easton, PA), Sofia Morena (Chicago). The installation will be open for viewing until Sunday, July 14th. The objects will completely fill the space of Little Berlin, which is a white cube with 30ftx34ft walls and 20ft ceilings. Objects will be hung from the ceiling, displayed on platforms installed on the walls, and installed on the floor.

$800 of the budget goes towards the materials needed to make this installation happen, such as twenty 2"X8"s, ten 4'x2' plywood, rental of a miter saw, heavy duty nylon rope, screws, paint, and spackle. $60 will be used for showcards to promote the opening of this installation.

Sofia Moreno will debut the second video in her P O R N A G A I N project, CYBERNYMPH, on July 19. The opening night will begin at 7pm and feature a performance by Sofia. The space will be decorated in silver and bathed in pink and purple lights. The following days, the 20th and 21st, will be open for viewings between 12pm and 5pm. Sofia is a mixed media artist whose work investigates expressions of the divine and profane, exploring the body, sensuality, religion, and culture. Her credits include working in curatorial projects along side  S+S Project from 2009 to present: Within the Body, From Diva to Mundane, Elektro-Sexual and  Fill-In, as well as co-curatorial projects such as Heaven Knows, Scented Illusions: Avon and Art, and the Homocult Show.

An additional $300 goes towards the materials needed for this installation, such as enough aluminum foil to cover 30'X20' and 34'x20' walls, staple gun with staples, more spackle, and showcards for the event.

The gallery will then make space for the official Garbage World 7 - Never Nothing Now performance event. This will take place on the 26th and 27th, starting at 7PM and ending at 10pm each day. Philadelphia and Chicago artists will participate in this event. Confirmed artists thus far are Eric Clark, Will Haughery and Kris Harzinski, Betty Devoe (Chicago), Hanna M. Owens (Chicago), and Adam Rose (Chicago), with more artists to be announced.

$1,200 of the budget goes to plane tickets for three performers coming from Chicago. Ticket prices, including tax and security fee, are $400 for two-way flights.

 

Money raised beyond the goal will go towards extra supplies as needed, operational costs of the gallery during the month (i.e. utilities to run air conditioners especially since July can get hot), and future exhibitions at Little Berlin.
story_txt:
I am Eileen Lillian Doyle, and I am fundraising for the exhibition Garbage World 7 - Never Nothing Now in Philadelphia, PA at the gallery Little Berlin. I am a curatorial member of Little Berlin, which I joined in July of 2012. My background is as a performance artist and I have my BFA from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago. My on-going project is the Garbage World Performance Series, which I founded in Chicago in 2009. I took on this project with the thought of creating an opportunity for artists to present the work they're committed to make -- be it messy, joyful, or grotesque. Over the course of a year between 2009 and 2010 I organized four events. Garbage World 4 was a three day festival with 24 performances. Many of the performers were recurring to allow opportunities for experimentation and development of new work. Afterwards, I left Chicago to live in Austin due to family concerns and took a hiatus from event organizing. I moved back to the East Coast, specifically New Jersey, at the end of February 2012, then moved to Philadelphia in May 2012. My aim in Philadelphia has been to integrate into a new art community and to take the transition as an opportunity to push my work in a new direction.

Garbage World 7 pushes this project into new territory and is part of an effort to create an exchange between two cities, Chicago and Philadelphia. Garbage World 5 in Philadelphia and 6 in Chicago featured artists from both cities, and 7 is the continuation of this trend. Both cities share similar artist-driven communities and can learn new ways of art-making and organization from each other. It is also important in artistic development to travel and experience the nuances of different cities since the change of pace and environment can influence new ideas.
Garbage World 7 will have performances and installations occurring through the month of July. On First Friday, July 5 from 6PM to 10PM, a performance ephemera installation will open. Costumes, notes, and props from artists who performed at previous Garbage Worlds will be installed within Little Berlin's space. Those who have confirmed submissions, thus far, are: Beth Heinly (Philadelphia), William Haughery (Philadelphia), Adam Rose (Chicago), Heather Lynn (Chicago), Jose Hernandez (Chicago), Molly Shea (Los Angeles), Sara Heymann (Chicago), Meg McCarville (Chicago), Fred J. Henzel (Chicago), Katrina Therese-Schaag (Madison, WI), Andrew Oberstadt (Dakar, Senegal), Josh Finck (Easton, PA), Sofia Morena (Chicago). The installation will be open for viewing until Sunday, July 14th. The objects will completely fill the space of Little Berlin, which is a white cube with 30ftx34ft walls and 20ft ceilings. Objects will be hung from the ceiling, displayed on platforms installed on the walls, and installed on the floor.
$800 of the budget goes towards the materials needed to make this installation happen, such as twenty 2"X8"s, ten 4'x2' plywood, rental of a miter saw, heavy duty nylon rope, screws, paint, and spackle. $60 will be used for showcards to promote the opening of this installation.

Sofia Moreno will debut the second video in her P O R N A G A I N project, CYBERNYMPH, on July 19. The opening night will begin at 7pm and feature a performance by Sofia. The space will be decorated in silver and bathed in pink and purple lights. The following days, the 20th and 21st, will be open for viewings between 12pm and 5pm. Sofia is a mixed media artist whose work investigates expressions of the divine and profane, exploring the body, sensuality, religion, and culture. Her credits include working in curatorial projects along side  S+S Project from 2009 to present: Within the Body, From Diva to Mundane, Elektro-Sexual and  Fill-In, as well as co-curatorial projects such as Heaven Knows, Scented Illusions: Avon and Art, and the Homocult Show.
An additional $300 goes towards the materials needed for this installation, such as enough aluminum foil to cover 30'X20' and 34'x20' walls, staple gun with staples, more spackle, and showcards for the event.
The gallery will then make space for the official Garbage World 7 - Never Nothing Now performance event. This will take place on the 26th and 27th, starting at 7PM and ending at 10pm each day. Philadelphia and Chicago artists will participate in this event. Confirmed artists thus far are Eric Clark, Will Haughery and Kris Harzinski, Betty Devoe (Chicago), Hanna M. Owens (Chicago), and Adam Rose (Chicago), with more artists to be announced.
$1,200 of the budget goes to plane tickets for three performers coming from Chicago. Ticket prices, including tax and security fee, are $400 for two-way flights.
 
Money raised beyond the goal will go towards extra supplies as needed, operational costs of the gallery during the month (i.e. utilities to run air conditioners especially since July can get hot), and future exhibitions at Little Berlin.

story:
We walk and talk for culture! And you?

WALK&TALK is multi-dimensional and participative public art festival that annually transforms the Island of São Miguel in a privileged stage for contemporary art. In it's 3rd edition, W&T showcases a broughter circuit of public art interventions and a program with colective exhibitions, workshops, music, performance and a lot of conversation. 

WALK&TALK aims to foster networks and partnerships between cultural operators, in a logic of sustainable and autonomous creation, capable of generating socio-economic opportunities for the region. It enhances new ways of thinking, interpretation and renewed visions within the Azorean population.

This year the Festival will assume itself as a space and privileged moment for the presentation and dissemination of arts, incorporating the format of an international art residence, crossing the Azorean talent and creativity with artists, curators and cultural players from around the world.

Who are we?

Anda&Fala - Interpretação Cultural is a non-profit cultural association dedicated to public space intervention and social awareness through art. It was founded in early 2011 with a vision of dynamizing the Azores through cultural investment. It’s activities are focused in promoting and activating contemporary artistic expressions.

Anda&Fala works in partnership with other local organizations and entities that are part of the Walk&Talk creative network, standing as co-creator agent of the Azorean creative ecosystem.

What we need

This year, in order to continue the construction of a public museum in São Miguel Island, and to enhance the participation of the local comunity, artists and their ideias, we need your help!!

The support that we ask is used directly in the logistics of the festival, ie the materials! We're talking about all the materials that artists will use in their interventions and all associated logistics. It goes from the simple adhesive tape, to iron or cranes. Everything is important.

All artists are participating voluntarily, so it is essential to ensure all the materials they need.

Impact > what do you gain supporting WALK&TALK?

You gain an outdoor museum. Democratic. Accessible to a community, increasingly in contact with art. But essencially you gain a creative destination to visit in the middle of the atlantic, in a paradise island that combines art, creativity and nature!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can come and visit the Azores during WALK&TALK, participating and helping the artists and organization. Creative vacations!

 

CONTACTS

Follow us on facebook.com/walktalkmovement or visit our website www.walktalkazores.org and our youtube channel to understand the impact of the festival > http://www.youtube.com/user/Walktalkfestival

 

NOTE: 

We've noticed that a lot of supporters dont have a paypal acount, so if you prefer you can make a bank transfer and will deposit in Indiegogo Campain with reference to your name! Thanks

NIB 0038 0000 39455785771 94

IBAN PT50 0038 0000 3945 5785 7719 4

story:
Two-Tone's History

Two-Tone Art Gallery opened on April 10, 2013. It is the brain child of Todd Wilson, a tattoo artist in Murfreesboro, TN. An avid painter, Todd wanted a space to not only create and showcase his own art but to allow other local artists to create and showcase art of all styles and media. The past two years have been a whirlwind of growth and learning experiences for us.

Two-Tone's Future

Todd plans on opening his own tattoo shop in the rooms behind the art gallery early next year. We are excited at the thought of this new endeavor bringing more traffic into the gallery, and want to make sure it's prepared for the influx. As interest grows, we want to be able to improve our business to best fit the art needs of our community. Note: None of the money raised in this campaign will fund supplies for the tattoo shop - it is all going toward updating the gallery.

What We Need

  • paint for the walls/ceilings
  • trim for the baseboards & crown molding
  • supplies to build mobile walls, providing more display space
  • a sturdy stool for the employee working the register
  • comfortable seating for customers
  • lockers for artists to store supplies
  • a filing cabinet to store paperwork
  • a sturdy glass display case
  • smaller display cases for local papers, postcard-sized prints, jewelry, etc.
  • an easel or two to both display art and for the use of artists
  • a proper gallery hanging system
  • better lighting, including track lighting along the ceiling
  • a projection system to allow new ways of art expression
  • Advertising! Business cards, fliers, ads in papers and on the radio, etc.

View our Pinterest board wish list for an idea of what we're hoping to purchase:

  • http://www.pinterest.com/2toneartgallery/wish-list/

Unmet Goal?

Doesn't matter! Every dollar will help us! While we would love to get everything on our wish list, even $50 will allow us to buy some much-needed lumber and paint. Whether you can donate $5 or $500, we assure you that we will find a useful purpose for every cent given during this campaign.

What You Get:

Amazing local art! Several local artists believe in our message and have agreed to help us raise funds by donating prints, originals, and commissions as Perks for this campaign.

Amber Duarte-White is a freelance artist specializing in Oil Paintings and Murals. (She accepts commissions!) Follow her on Instagram to view current projects: twoowls2
Ashley Boyona is a living art inspired self taught artist starving to paint the world. She is a freelance photographer as well. "Life is a canvas and I'm here to paint a masterpiece."
Christy Simmons is one of those creative people that is constantly looking at things and thinking of how she can make them better, more unique, or more artistic. She loves taking someone's ideas and making them come to fruition in a way that's better than they even dreamed.
Cinespire Photography was born from Norbert Thiemann's inspiration by the art cinema as a basic foundation. Sometimes unsettling, and often NSFW, model collaborations with Cinespire have helped to create a unique catalog of thought-provoking images.
Liz Kelly Zook has been drawing, creating, painting, sewing, etc for as long as she can remember and doesn't ever plan on stopping. She likes to take a things that are dark and let some light in; or take things that are typically fun and add a twist.
Mai Hamric is a visual artist located in Murfreesboro, TN. In addition to her art work, she curates local art and music shows and is a regular contributor to the Murfreesboro Pulse arts section. She also hosts painting workshops from her home studio.
Michelle Sweatt is inspired by the challenge of restoring objects that were at one time in their existence considered prized belongings to someone, but now find themselves either sitting on a dusty shelf in a thrift store or permanent fixtures in the landfill.
Patti Mann brings a very unique perspective and color sense to her artworks. She enjoys to create original and custom artworks and illustration on canvas, paper or board using paints, graphite, water media, pen & ink. Art for all purposes, art for everyone.
Ryan Frizzell, a.k.a. "The Rhinovirus", is a mixed media artist / illustrator. His goal is to make as much art as possible, and show it to as many people as possible.
Todd Wilson is a local tattoo artist and founder of Two-Tone. He loves Ghostbusters, comic books, and creating ridiculous art.

To view samples of their work, visit our website.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help us financially, but can donate your time, we will be hosting a work day at the end of our campaign to make all the improvements we can afford. Follow us on Facebook to stay updated!

Most importantly, please help us by spreading the word! Share this campaign, and tell your friends about Two-Tone Art Gallery. Murfreesboro is full of amazing talent, and we are proud to be able to display it. Feel free to stop by Two-Tone during regular business hours and check out all the local art on display.

#ShopLocal #SupportLocalArtists #BuyLocalArt

story:
Background:

In fall 2013, Artist Dawn Marie Marchand was approached by a community member who knew that the final Truth and Reconciliation Commission event was going to Edmonton March 2014. Knowing the power of Walking With Our Sisters Exhibit which provided immense awareness to the issue of Murdered and Missing Indigenous women, it also gave people a voice to be heard and often much needed healing. She wondered if such a project could happen for Residential School Survivors and their intergenerational descendants who are still affected even if they did not attend themselves. This project was born from that original conversation.  A public announcement for paper bricks was made, that would be visual representations of stories from Indian Residential School or how it affected them or their descendants. Art builds were held around Alberta which included Edmonton, Calgary, St. Paul and others. Many more bricks were mailed from across Canada. Notably Winnipeg held art builds where over 56 participants contributed bricks to the art installation. These were collaged onto the canvas walls of a gazebo to create a one room school house. Each brick represented a story that for some were the first steps towards healing. The bricks were treated in a way that honours each story and participant. They were all smudged and wrapped in prints while they were being compiled. When they were being installed they were smudged again and not allowed to touch the floor.  At the viewing, people were asked to hold a stone in their left hand and leave it with use when they left. These stones will be laid into the walking paths of theHealing Garden at Blue Quills First Nation College. It is a symbolic representation of placing the hurts under our feet.  The installation was well received with 1000’s of people attending. The feedback was incredibly positive and received good publicity as it was then moved to CBC Radio at Edmonton Place after the TRC event. It was then requested to be viewed again in Edmonton at the International Works Festival where it was one of the feature exhibits in the Big Tent with Ken Armstrong’s powerful photography on Homelessness in Edmonton. It was the most visited exhibit averaging over 1,200 people daily. There was a great deal of dialogue created with this predominantly mainstream non-native event.

What we need to raise:

We are looking to fund the travel expenses to Winnipeg.  

A venue has been located and donated in-kind:

Indigenous Family Centre

470 Selkirk Avenue

Winnipeg, MB  R2W 2M5

With dates set for August 20 - 31, 2014

These expenses are as follows:

Mileage: Travel (Bonnyville, AB to Winnipeg, MB return 2,600 km @ $0.45)  $ 1,200

Meals (2 days breakfast $8, lunch $15, dinner $20) x 3  $ 258

Accommodation on the road.  (one night in Saskatoon)  $150

Incidentals  $ 250

Total:  $1 858

Here are some links that provide more information about "A Place to Hang Your Stories" and help in additional ways.  If we make our goal; we will still need volunteers and help setting up and tearing down. 

http://www.scribd.com/doc/234304720/A-Place-to-Hang-Your-Stories-Funding-Request-Updated

Internet Resources:

Hampshire, G. Building a sense of Residential School; Brick by Brick:http://www.cbc.ca/news/aboriginal/building-a-se...

Parrish, J. Truth and Reconciliation Commission set to begin:http://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/truth-and-reconcilia...

Jones, S. Truth and Reconciliation: http://globalnews.ca/video/1233433/truth-reconciliation

Hampshire, G. Circle of Courage: http://www.cbc.ca/m/news/#!/content/1.2588414

Narine, S. Art Part of the Healing Process of Residential Schools:http://ca.ammsa.com/publications/alberta-sweetg...

Edmonton Arts Council. Outline:http://www.edmontonarts.ca/static_media/pdfs/fi... 

Commanda, K. Legacy of Living Together art Project Approaches Healing for IndigenousArtists.http://thegatewayonline.ca/article/view/the_leg...

Vue Weekly, Arts. The Legacy of Living Together Inserts Arts into Truth and Reconciliation:http://www.vueweekly.com/the-legacy-of-living-t...

Richard Douglas Brinkman. Reconciliation? http://youtube/8ybT4v7YywM

story:
Interact Center for the Visual and Performing Arts is a professional arts organization offering the daily practice of visual and performing arts at a professional level to adult artists with disabilities. Please support our ongoing theater collaboration with The Bricklayers, in order to provide in-depth training in modern mask technique to Interact theater artists. 

In January of this year, The Bricklayers traveled from Chicago to Minneapolis to share their unique training with our artists.  Specializing in l’essential, a modern mask technique, The Bricklayers immersed our artists into their highly regarded and technical neutral mask method, strengthening our theater ensemble and challenging our artists to find a greater autonomy in their work. 

The experience was a completely new one for Interact artists and in addition to the fun and joy it brought to our daily practice, The Bricklayers’ efforts at Interact have had exciting and remarkable results.  Their technique and presence has enriched our artistic community, building new skills and confidence with their freeing and compassionate methodologies. 

Many of our performing artists have found new acting strengths and successes through this technique that was not so with more traditional acting methods.  We have found that many of our artists’ capability for eye contact - onstage and off - has skyrocketed. Many have experienced significant boosts in their concentration and physical awareness. Others still have found their artistic spirits reignited by the playful yet rigorous working environment.

We are raising funds to support this collaboration, which, through the dedication and hard work of both companies, has provided a seminal technical training for Interact artists.  Your financial support will make it possible for us to continue our relationship with The Bricklayers, building on this compelling new way of working with our artists. The Bricklayers’ technique has helped to empower the artists and the ensemble, and we are eager to continue our research into how their methods can continue to impact the lives of our artists, providing them with new ways to share their life stories and unique talents through art and theater.



About Interact: Creating Art to Challenge Perceptions of Disability

Since 1996, Interact’s mission to create art that challenges perceptions of disability has opened doors for artists with disabilities and audiences eager to experience their work, who might never have seen the arts as a life choice, but who now see the arts as essential to their humanity. With over 125 artists working in theater and/or studio arts, Interact is multi-cultural, intergenerational, and embraces the entire spectrum of disability labels.

Interact’s work is driven by a vision of radical inclusion. We collaborate with artists with and without disabilities, from mainstream and marginalized communities, whose stories and life experiences are the grist for our original, ensemble-generated theatrical work, and inspire the spectrum of media that are created in our studio. Interact was the first – and remains the only –visual and performing arts organization for artists with disabilities, nationally or internationally, that is creating full-time at the professional level, and sharing exciting seasons of performances and exhibitions with our audiences

About The Bricklayers: The Mask Unmasks

The goal of our work at Interact has been to first remove all external expressions and find one’s neutral point, humility and openness.  This work then opens whole new avenues of creation. The actors learn to control themselves under the pressure of performance and to search beneath the surface of a first impulse, beyond the obvious and into the intricacies and contradictions that make life and performance rich with humanity.  This work refines the actor’s creativity, patience, engagement, and their ability to communicate with their ensemble and community.  


About Ship of Fools: A Work in Progress

Based on the fifteenth-century allegory by Sebastian Brant, Interact’s Ship of Fools considers the foolishness of high-society and the brilliance of the underdog – all in the topsy-turvy language and style of mask theater. Come aboard as the Interact artists with and without disabilities play alongside The Bricklayers in this hilarious voyage into humanity’s quirks and treasures!
story_txt:
Interact Center for the Visual and Performing Arts is a
professional arts organization offering the daily practice of visual and
performing arts at a professional level to adult artists with disabilities.
Please support our ongoing theater collaboration with The Bricklayers, in order
to provide in-depth training in modern mask technique to Interact theater
artists. 
In January of this year, The Bricklayers traveled from Chicago
to Minneapolis to share their unique training with our artists.
 Specializing in l’essential, a modern mask technique, The Bricklayers
immersed our artists into their highly regarded and technical neutral mask
method, strengthening our theater ensemble and challenging our artists to find
a greater autonomy in their work. 
The experience was a completely new one for Interact artists and
in addition to the fun and joy it brought to our daily practice, The
Bricklayers’ efforts at Interact have had exciting and remarkable results.
 Their technique and presence has enriched our artistic community,
building new skills and confidence with their freeing and compassionate
methodologies. 
Many of our performing artists have found new acting strengths
and successes through this technique that was not so with more traditional
acting methods.  We have found that many of our artists’ capability for
eye contact - onstage and off - has skyrocketed. Many have experienced
significant boosts in their concentration and physical awareness. Others still
have found their artistic spirits reignited by the playful yet rigorous working
environment.
We are raising funds to support this collaboration, which,
through the dedication and hard work of both companies, has provided a seminal
technical training for Interact artists.  Your financial support will
make it possible for us to continue our relationship with The Bricklayers,
building on this compelling new way of working with our artists. The
Bricklayers’ technique has helped to empower the artists and the ensemble, and
we are eager to continue our research into how their methods can continue to
impact the lives of our artists, providing them with new ways to share their
life stories and unique talents through art and theater.
About Interact: Creating Art to Challenge Perceptions of
Disability
Since 1996, Interact’s mission to create art that
challenges perceptions of disability has opened doors for artists with
disabilities and audiences eager to experience their work, who might never have
seen the arts as a life choice, but who now see the arts as essential to their
humanity. With over 125 artists working in theater and/or studio arts, Interact
is multi-cultural, intergenerational, and embraces the entire spectrum of
disability labels.
Interact’s work is driven by a vision of radical
inclusion. We collaborate with artists with and without disabilities, from
mainstream and marginalized communities, whose stories and life experiences are
the grist for our original, ensemble-generated theatrical work, and inspire the
spectrum of media that are created in our studio. Interact was the first – and
remains the only –visual and performing arts organization for artists with
disabilities, nationally or internationally, that is creating full-time at the
professional level, and sharing exciting seasons of performances and
exhibitions with our audiences
About The Bricklayers: The Mask Unmasks
The goal of our work at Interact has been
to first remove all external expressions and find one’s neutral point, humility
and openness.  This work then opens whole new avenues of creation. The
actors learn to control themselves under the pressure of performance and to
search beneath the surface of a first impulse, beyond the obvious and into the
intricacies and contradictions that make life and performance rich with
humanity.  This work refines the actor’s creativity, patience, engagement,
and their ability to communicate with their ensemble and community.  About Ship of Fools: A Work in
Progress
Based on the fifteenth-century allegory by
Sebastian Brant, Interact’s Ship of Fools considers the foolishness
of high-society and the brilliance of the underdog – all in the topsy-turvy
language and style of mask theater. Come aboard as the Interact artists with
and without disabilities play alongside The Bricklayers in this hilarious
voyage into humanity’s quirks and treasures!

story:
Hi! My name is Alina and I'm the founding Editor of Walden Magazine. 


I started working on Walden for a couple reasons. The first being that I was just a little bit disappointed with the lack of publications geared towards young people here in Maine. As a "20-something" I'm really interested reading journalism that is created by and for my peers. There simply isn't a magazine in Maine that reaches out to this demographic in a way that reflects the talent and interests of the young people here. Maine needs a young magazine.

The second reason I started Walden was because I think illustration is great and in some ways underrated in commercial publications today. Last winter I spent a lot of time researching old magazines from the late 19th century—pre-photography. I found the style and the use of illustration in these old mags to be really imaginative and uniquely expressive. By using illustration to convey a place and the experience of a traveller, we can potentially broaden what we think of as "travel journalism." And let's be real, illustration is just a great way to visualize a story. 

And thirdly, my wonderful team and I wanted to bring the magic back to travel. Travel is precious experience—especially to young people. In a time when travel journalism is ruled by lists and suggestions for restaurants, we wanted to create something that felt more like the real experience of being in a place. 

So, wow, that was a lot to read. Are you still with us? Because we would really love it if you helped us print this beautiful mag..

Our first issue is (appropriately) about Maine. We need $4,000 to print this first issue and set this baby up proper! Printing a magazine ain't cheap and we have estimated that printing the first issue will cost close to $2,500. The rest of your contributions will go to getting the website off the ground, starting the second issue and throwing our artists a couple of bucks (because even though they all agreed to do this for free, they are also poor 20-somethings that would totally appreciate getting a little extra love for contributing their work). If we don't reach our whole goal, we will print as many copies of the first issue as we can and distribute it all over Maine and as much of the rest of the country as possible.

 We want to thank you for reading that colossal bit of text above. We really hope that we've excited you about Walden. 

Feel free to shoot me an email if you have questions: alinacsutherland@gmail.com
You can also find us on Instagram—the one place we do use pictures ;) : @waldenmag

story:
About Turbines Curatorial Collective

Turbines is a burgeoning non-profit curatorial collective that facilitates the production and presentation of socially- and/or politically-minded performance art in Kingston, Ontario. Formed in January of 2014, the collective operates using a consensus-based decision making model, and currently consists of six members who identify as performance and visual artists, independent curators, activists, and/or scholars of visual culture. By working with existing arts-based and community organizations within Kingston, Turbines aims to bring together local, professional, international and emerging artists to create an opportunity for collaboration, mentorship, and the sharing of artistic knowledges. Our main objective is to foster dialogue and artistic exchanges through free events in order to make performance art accessible to a wider community.

As a collective, Turbines believes that performance art is an ideal medium for sparking new conversations and thoughts between audiences, artists, and communities due to its immediacy, dynamism, and interactive nature. We also believe that these same qualities make performance art a perfect avenue for broaching difficult but important conversations about the kinds of ideologies we inhabit. Interlacing art with social justice and an overarching desire to make our world a more livable and enjoyable place for all people, Turbines seeks to engage artists, groups, communities and collectives who work to nurture feminist, queer, trans*-positive, anti-racist, anti-colonialist, anti-ableist, and other forms of anti-oppressive politics and ideologies. 

Turbines is: Pansee Atta; Gabriel Cheung; Anne Dunsford; Alison Fraser; Robin Alex McDonald; Katharine-Vingoe-Cram

About Utopias Performance Art Festival

Turbines’ inaugural curatorial project brings performance artists from diverse geographical, social, cultural, and professional backgrounds to Kingston for a three-day performance festival, to be hosted at Modern Fuel Artist-Run Centre’s new, fully accessible venue at the Tett Centre for Creativity and Learning in March 2015. In addition to the presentation of live performance art, the festival will include artist-led workshops on "Art and Activism" that seek to consider how art can be utilized as a tool for social change.

Though the professional artist roster is still in the works, we are very excited to announce that we have been in dialogue with the extraordinary Vaginal Davis (http://www.vaginaldavis.com) and are looking to use some of these funds toward her travel from Berlin.

The call for local/emerging artists will be disseminated in November, so stay tuned... We hope that you apply!

Goal

The budget for this project in its current iteration is approximately $18,000. Thanks to the generous support of the City of Kingston Arts Fund, the George Taylor Richardson Memorial Fund, Queen's Department of Gender Studies, Queen's Department of Art, and Queen's Cultural Studies program, we have secured $13,750.  That means we have over $4,000 to go --- and your contribution can help get us there!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially but would still like to help make this festival possible, please contact us at turbinescuratorialcollective@gmail.com

We would be oh so grateful for any volunteer assistance, help with marketing and postering, billeting artists, or anything else you might be able to lend a hand with!

story:
The goal is simple: I want to take this adorable Marshfellow figurine...

...and transform him into a cuddly, super-soft plush!

The goal of $1,000 to just get started on the Plush! But there are so many more stretch goals that we all hope to achieve here together!


What is a Marshfellow? 

A Marshfellow is a chubby, sweet-faced, little marshmallow creature made entirely out of love. 

For the past seven years Marshfellow fans have adorned their bookshelves, windowsills, desks, and counter tops with these super-cute collectibles. And for the past seven years I have heard and read this phrase over and over again: "He's so cute I just wanna squeeze him!" 

So, that is what I want to do! I want to be able to offer a high quality, super soft, and squeezable Marshfellow perfect for cuddling! The plush itself will be made of ultra-soft minky fabric, with embroidered eyes and mouth, and the Marshfellow signature blush pink cheeks! So take a load off and get a little toasted like one of our favorite Marshfellows while you wait for a plush!

We've also created a Marshfellow Bar which is this super awesome shelf that you can hang on the wall to showcase all of your favorite Marshfellows!

Marshfellows has partnered with Golden Bell's Stuffimals!

Marc Goldner, Rachel Korsen, and Robert Gross are coming on as co-creators of the new Marshfellows cartoons, comics and all the merchandise! We wanted to unveil here on IndieGoGo before anywhere else what the world of Marshfellows is transforming into. We hope you're all excited!

Each and every Marshfellows has been custom crafted and people have found a little bit of themselves in each and every one. With that process we hope to create a character that becomes part of the family from now on. In our opinion, no perfect plush is complete without a memorable story to go along with it. These stories are always fun while also teaching good values!

What is the story about our favorite Marshfellows?

Cute and cuddly, the Marshfellows live in a Marshmallowy world that's on the verge of being S'MORED by the chocolate and graham cracker countries. After years of separation between the other delicious kingdoms, the Marshfellow Prince embarks on an epic quest with an arrogant Chocolate Unicorn and a double-sided Graham Cracker Bear to bring order back to his once peaceful and cuddly kingdom. 

On their journey they'll deal with MarshVampires, Frankenfellow monstrosities, and of course try to stop the onslaught of the invading Zombie Marshfellow horde. The Zombiefellows are way too toasted and our Prince must find his father, who has been absent for a long time looking for the old magical fires and the mysterious Stick of Roasting to stop the dark, evil force that none of the homeless wizards know enough about. 

Every step of the way the Prince and his friends will have to deal with the fact that they're merely soft, delicate dessert food, no older than adolescents, living in an increasingly terrifying world of epic candy propositions. Like their quest to fend off monsters, our kids will combat the REAL fears of growing up and the challenges of managing new friendships.

What Do Parents Say?

"I absolutely LOVE my marshfellow unicorn! She's the prettiest little girl! Such quality goes into making these marshfellos! The shipping was so fast and customer service is top notch!!" 

- Kimberlee Brigan, 5 Star Review

"This was amazing! She worked with me every step of the way to get exactly what I wanted and responded very quickly to emails. My custom was a gift for someone, but it turned out perfectly! It looked exactly like the pic I sent. It was finished sooner than I expected and shipped quickly. Amazing Work! I honestly just can't say enough to do it justice. Thank you!

-Kelly Cook, 5 Star Review

"My marshfellow cookie boy is so cute and unique! I'm sure I will be buying more in the future for myself and for gifts"

- Erica James, 5 Star Review

"This little cutie is awesome. Very good craftsmanship. I am impressed that the melted chocolate looks so realistic."

- Peggy Barnhart, 5 Star Review

"I've been wanting to buy from marshfellows for some time now and I finally got a chance to place my first order of personalised Cupcake necklaces for my nieces. They are so cute and I LOVE them. I am very happy and definitely coming back again for more. I'm a huge fan of personalised orders , and what better place to come for a unique gift idea that is 'perfectly cute' than to buy from Marshfellows."

- Kate Wilder, 5 Star Review

"I am at a loss for word as to how adorably perfect Marshfellow is."

- Kayla Moop, 5 Star Review

Q & A for the Marshfellows!

How are the Marshfellows different then other stuffed animals?

Marshfellows aren't just like any other stuffed animal. They are cute and cuddly desserts with a face you can squish. Everyone loves candy treats, our little Marshfellows give kids a reason to take a second helping in the form of a stuffed animal! The Marshfellows are made to last, be remembered, and constantly be there for kids of all ages. Everyone will be able to find part of themselves in the Marshfellows whether you're an artist or a businessperson!

How long have the Marshfellows been around for?

Marshfellows were started over 7 years ago as a rainy-day hobby when Autumn was feeling homesick being away from Massachusets. Growing up in the land that created fluff, she brought a little bit of home to life in the form of our favorite desserts! Being overseas inspired Autumn to continue creating the world of fluff that we've come to know and love. These fellows will be around forever!

How many lives have the Marshfellows reached?

Marshfellows have touched the lives of tens of thousands of people over the past decade or so. With thousands and thousands of custom orders completed for people across the globe, Autumn felt it was time to create a stuffed animal plush that could get in the hands of even more people to have a buddy to snuggle up with when they were either feeling blue or maybe a bit hungry!

What is the recommended age for the Marshfellows?

The Marshfellows are recommended for people of all ages. Everyone from little kids to married couples have adored these custom handmade figurines. You will be able to find yourself in any Marshfellow you can think to create. The plush will let people use their imaginations to create a world of dessert deliciousness that they can play in as they bask in the glory of fluff.

What type of reception have the Marshfellows had?

Marshfellows have been critically acclaimed by fans of all ages. With glowing reviews from parents, kids and singleites, the list keeps growing. To have a happy fan and put a smile on someones face is what we all have set out to do together. The hundreds of 5 star glowing and stellar reviews of Marshfellows shows the type of quality, care, love and time that we put into Marshfellows.

Would you recommend Marshfellows for Toddlers?

The Marshfellows STUFFED ANIMAL PLUSH is for everyone! Whether you're a toddler or a grandparent! However, the collectible figurines of Marshfellows are handcrafted in Polymer Clay and are easily breakable and contain parts that are not suitable for children. The best safest option is to get a the stuffed plush!

Are the Marshfellows safe for newborns?

While the stuffed animal plush is safe for newborns, the handcrafted Polymer Clay figures are easily breakable & contain parts that aren't suitable for babies.

Are the Marshfellows machine washable?

The Marshfellow plush stuffed animals are all machine washable!

Who composed that awesome music in the video?

Jonathan Meller and Derek Etman!

FAQ About Pre-Orders

When will the Marshfellows be delivered?

The Marshfellows will all be deleiveredy by March 2017 just in time for that last bit of Winter where you can roast some S'mores along with your Marshfellow!

Will the Marshfellows be shipped globally?

All the Marshfellows will be shipped around the world for a little bit extra cost!

How does pledging work and when am I charged?

If our campaign is successfully funded, your card will be charged when the project reaches its funding deadline. If the project does not reach its funding goal, your card is never charged. It's a risk-free situation for you, the backer. It's that easy!


Rewards vary for all kinds of budgets! So if you'd really like to help, but don't want to break the bank, our top reward tiers are budget-friendly, and remember even a $5.00 pledge is still incredibly helpful, and shows your love and support of Marshfellows!


Are there any risks and challenges?

Golden Bell Studios is an established Entertainment company working with hundreds of creators. Like any collaborative project, production delays with the factory or shipping delays may occur. If these should happen, I will notify all backers through updates here and by email. If you have any questions you'd like for me to answer, simply leave them in the comments and I will answer them in the FAQ section.



How did Marshfellows Begin? 

Marshfellows began as my rainy-day hobby, an outlet for me to be creative, while combining my love of all things cute, with my love of all things sweet.

story:
Who are you and what is this?

Ik ben Jeroen de Beer, een gepassioneerd bodybuilding en fitness fotograaf uit Tilburg. De meeste van jullie zullen me kennen via Instagram, waar ik vaak mijn werk plaats (en selfies ^_^). Na mijn studie psychologie besloot ik het roer om te gooien en van mijn passie mijn werk te maken. Ik wil iets doen waarvan ik tot leven kom, waar ik elke dag met plezier naartoe ga en waar ik trots op ben. Fast forward naar een jaar later en mijn droom is uitgekomen. Het is zelfs zo snel gegaan dat ik van mijn eerste studio, waar ik een jaar geleden ben begonnen, door wil verhuizen naar een grote loods! Daar kunnen jullie me bij helpen, want het is ook wel tof als ik die loods gelijk kan inrichten met een lading gymspullen!

Help mij mijn droom verder te verwezenlijken en jezelf aan de gaafste foto's ooit door me te steunen via deze campagne!

 

Wat ik nodig heb en wat jullie krijgen

Voor een basis stukje sportschool in mijn nieuwe loods heb ik minimaal 5.000 euro nodig, maar hoe meer ik binnen haal hoe meer ik neer kan zetten en hoe toffer het wordt. Ik hoop met deze campagne 10.000 euro in te zamelen en dat zal allemaal naar de inrichting van de loods gaan.

Mocht het zo zijn dat ik veel meer dan dat inzamel, dan zet ik de rest opzij om in ieder geval een paar maanden de huur te kunnen betalen. Je kunt er in ieder geval verzekerd van zijn dat ik geen cruise naar de Bahama's boek op het moment dat ik het geld ontvang ;).

Als ik de 5.000 euro voor het stukje sportschool niet binnen haal is het ook geen probleem, dan leg ik de rest zelf bij. Voor mij is het vooral een mooie manier om in te schatten hoeveel animo er voor is en om iedereen enthousiast te krijgen over mijn nieuwe studio. 

So what's in it for you? Op de eerste plek natuurlijk een ontzettend goed gevoel dat je iemand kunt steunen in het volgen van zijn hart en als je het specifiek doet omdat je mij wilt steunen een hele oprechte knuffel de eerste keer dat ik je (weer) zie! Maar ook leuke kortingen op de prijzen, one-of-a-kind shirts, handgeschreven bedankbriefjes, workshops en nog veel meer :)

Een van de grootste voordelen van het kopen van een bon is dat hij geldig is tot en met 2017. Het is het laatste jaar ongelofelijk snel gegaan en ik ben niet van plan any time soon gas terug te gaan nemen. Dat is samen gegaan met meerdere verhogingen van mijn prijzen, eigenlijk elke keer dat ik 3 maanden van tevoren volgeboekt ben gaan ze weer iets omhoog. Hetzelfde verwacht ik voor het komende jaar, dus als je weet dat je sowieso nog bij me op de foto wilt is dit het ideale moment!

 

Alle hulp is belangrijk en wordt gewaardeerd!

Dit is de eerste keer ooit dat ik probeer iets te laten crowdfunden en ik vind het best wel spannend ^_^ Ik wil jullie in ieder geval op het hart drukken dat ik alle hulp ontzettend waardeer en ik jullie allemaal amazing vind!

 

Risico's voor jullie

Ik heb geprobeerd het risico zo klein mogelijk te houden voor jullie; de loods gaat sowieso door en je geld gaat nooit verloren, ik gebruik het altijd voor de inrichting en als het veel harder gaat dan ik verwacht steek ik alles terug in mijn bedrijf. Bovendien raak je je geld nooit kwijt; de bonnen zijn geldig tot en met 2017, maar als je om welke reden dan ooit geen afspraak kunt maken voor die tijd, krijg je het betaalde geld als korting op de dan geldige prijzen. 

Je kunt je geld echter niet terug krijgen, ik ga er van uit dat je super enthousiast bent over mij als fotograaf en zeker weet dat je bij me op de foto wilt, bovendien gebruik ik al het ingezamelde geld voor de inrichting van mijn nieuwe studio, dus je kunt geen refund krijgen nadat de campagne afloopt.

 

Andere manieren waarop je me kunt helpen

Als je met me meeleeft en me graag wilt helpen, zou ik het enorm waarderen als jullie wat mond-op-mond reclame willen maken voor mijn campagne in jullie gym en bij je vrienden. Als jullie mijn campagne willen sharen op facebook/instagram/where-ever ben ik jullie al helemaal eeuwig dankbaar, alle beetjes helpen veel meer dan je zou denken!

Ik wil jullie in ieder geval heel erg bedanken voor alle lieve berichtjes op instagram, alle mensen die hebben aangeboden te helpen en iedereen die met me mee leeft via social media!! Zonder jullie had ik deze campagne en deze (voor mij weer hele grote) stap nooit aangedurfd. 

THANK YOU GUUUYS!!!

t-shirt design:

story:
Summary

My name is Todd Lacharite and I am a local promoter of music and the arts in Lethbridge, Alberta under the banner of Think Tank Events.

Lethbridge is just one city of many which is incredibly rich with talented local artists and musicians. I believe I have come up with a great way to get these individuals as well as other Canadians much needed exposure in a fun and unique way!

I will be organizing 52 Canadian artists and 52 Canadian bands to work together to create a unique poker size playing deck of cards called Shuffle Up & Deal 3: Audio/Visual.

Each artist will be teamed up with a musician/band to create an image which interprets the musician/band or their song that they have submitted. There will be 52 original and unique playing cards (plus the jokers).

The artwork will be showcased on the playing cards and then each musician/band will submit a recorded song. These songs can be then accessed by an online source as part of an album by the purchaser of the deck of cards.

There will also be index cards included in the deck of cards which will have a list of the artists and musicians as well as contact information or website to help promote them.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of $6,000 is the least amount we need to produce and manufacture the cards. The more money we raise, the more we will be able to do (T-shirts, Art shows, concerts, & mass exposure of the deck of cards etc). And the sooner we hit the goal, the sooner you'll be able to see the finished deck.

These cards will make an awesome souvenir, gift and collector’s item that does Canada PROUD!

Are you a Canadian artist or musician who wants to participate in the project? Please email me at toddlacharite@hotmail.com

 

MUSICIANS FOR THE DECK ALREADY:

  • Shred Kelly (British Columbia)
  • Romi Mayes (Manitoba)
  • Willhorse (British Columbia)
  • The Void (Alberta)
  • The Motorleague (New Brunswick)
  • Mobina Galore (Manitoba)
  • Transit (Alberta)
  • Jesse and the Dandelions (Alberta)
  • Hank & Lily (British Columbia)

ARTISTS FOR THE DECK ALREADY:

  • Nicholas Louma (Saskatchewan)
  • Will Woods (Alberta)
  • Jason Trotter (Alberta)
  • Cate Currie (Alberta)
  • Hank Pine (British Columbia)
  • Tarryn Forai (Alberta)

Risks & Challenges

I have done two Shuffle Up & Deals in the past and are using the same companies we've used to do the projects. So we are confident in their work. The only problem is making sure all the artists follow deadlines so the finished product gets printed.

story:
J.E.T. Predicament:

We need your help to keep the doors opened at J.E.T. Studios-J.E.T. Studios is a multi-facet forum consisting of 3 studios, 1 TV/ Camera room and a 60 seat Theatre with raked seating  that provide professional space for Theatrical productions, film screenings, rehearsals, Virtual and regular casting, acting classes, and film/video shoots.

"Allowing Artists to Create- A Place where Relationships Develop".

 *Special thanks to John Ruff and Marielou Mandl for the additional footage on the campaign video- Jcruff@comcast.net; sassysurvivalguide@gmail.com

Advocacy:

Thank you again for a great audition space! I LOVED being at J.E.T. Studios and can't imagine any theatre company not wanting to make it their home away from home. Your waiting room for the actors was so inviting, the generous use of the fridge, counter space and tables made is easy for everyone to sign in and have cold water while they wait, the audition space was a directors dream with terrific air conditioning on a hot day. We look forward to our next audition at J.E.T. Studios.


  Sincerely,
  Ron Celona Artistic Director
  Coachella Valley Repertory

 

"Great facility!!! Nice stages, lovely artwork, and overall good vibes for creative folks whether film, theatre or artist types :-)"
  -Deborah Rombault

 

"Excited to bring more of our education program to JET : ) "
-Hollywood Shorts

 

Community Impact:

J.E.T. Studios was created to provide artist with a forum to create. We offer Festivals of original works to promote new works by playwrights, allowing a creative process for not only the playwright but the director and the actors. 

We offer a forum for up and coming independent film makers to be able to afford to screen their film in an environment which offers HD Blu ray capabiities and a beautiful lounge/concession area to entertain their guest.

The NoHo area is becoming the Arts Center of LA and needs facilities like this to help keep noho on the map as one of the best art communities in the Los Angeles area.

Our campaign is focused on raising money to pay our bills for the next 6 months and help fund some of our future projects

CREW: I, Judith E., am the sole proprietor-with a volunteer web master and a cleaning crew.

 

There are two important ways to lend a hand in our efforts:


  1. Contribute to this Indiegogo campaign

  2. Spread the word to Save J.E.T. Studios to everyone you know.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $40,000 to stay opened.

 

Our perks are targeted to be useful for those individuals in the creative arts:

1-50% off rehearsal rental fees-specific times only

2- 20% discount for theatrical productions

3- 2  hours for film screening

4- 1 months of wall space to exhibit and sell your ART work/with reception time for your opening. All sales are yours 100%.

5-A huge Thank you for supporting the Arts in NoHo..

6-Link on our web site for 1 month.

7- Movie nights with friends

 

 

WITHOUT YOUR CONTRIBUTION WE WILL HAVE TO CLOSE OUR DOORS AND ARTISTS WILL LOOSE THEIR SAFE-HOME.

Other Ways You Can Help:

 

We need assistance in the following area:

 Your free time for:

1-an assistant to show the space to prospective clients

 

2-someone who is social media savvy to help increase our awareness to others and keep our social media updated on a daily basis

 

3- Help with maintaining the facility clean and our toiletries replenished on an ongoing basis.

 

In return we can give you some of the perks mentioned: free film screening  time/50% of rehearsal space/20% of theatrical productions, etc. (Pending availability)

story:
OUR STORY AND WHY

 

“The Post-Catastrophe Collaboration Workshop”, curated by Lydia Lunch, seeks to give agency to women by encouraging artistic empowerment especially inthese times of global chaos, media negativity and the devastating effects on the psyche of disaster capitalism and catastrophe that plagues the individual on a daily basis.

-------------

For 3 days, in the Summer of 2012, Ateliers du Vent, a community art space in Rennes France, will become a collaborative and transformative exchange, for women and by women. 

The artists involved will cover a wide range of mediums from visual and practical applications of art to spoken word and dance.

-------------

The outcome of this workshop will be realized in a collaborative group performance at Ateliers du Vent.

The purpose of this event is to empower the women involved to form a global collective, which will encourage not only those in attendance, but spread a contagious enthusiasm to creative women everywhere.  


 

 

WHO WE ARE/ WHAT WE ARE DOING

Lydia Lunch (Barcelona, Spain): Luminary performer. Voted by Time Out Magazine as, “one of the most influential performers to have merged from New York City”.

Written and spoken word workshops.

Bibbe Hansen (New York, New York): Daughter of Fluxus artist Al Hansen, mother of the musician Beck, youngest Warhol Star.

Works on “Happenings” and unblocking creative potential to inspire us from passive art consumers to culture producers.

Sadie Mae aka Lisa Tomicich (Nyack, New York): Musician, collaborated with Lydia Lunch and Kim Gordon on “Harry Crews”.

Workshops on the agency of freelance art, various techniques and applications. 

Vanessa Skantze (Seattle, Washington): Performance artist, Butoh.

Workshops on Butoh and the power of the body.

Celine Le Corre (Rennes, France):Creator and pioneer of Atelier du Vent.

Merging word, photography and sound in various exhibitions.

Nicoleta Esinencu (Chisinau, Moldova):Writer and performer.

Gained international attention with her monologue “Fuck you, Eu.ro Pa”

Workshop on political performance art.

Lilia Dragneva (Chisinau, Moldova):Visual artist, critic and curator. Founder of “Ksa’k (Center of Contemporary Art in Chisinau)

Workshops on experimental video and sound installations

Laetitia Sheriff (Rennes, France): Musician, writer.

Workshops on poetry and musical collaboration.

Jillian McManemin(Brooklyn, NY):  Multimedia artist/writer

Workshops on ephemeral art. Frequent collaborator of Sadie Mae.

Elise Passavant (Paris, France):

Award winning filmmaker, editor, VJ, “multi-media Swiss army knife”

 

------All of these women are linked through their politics and aim to change the status quo through art and group empowerment. -------



 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Where our funding will go: Transportation and Accommodation

- We need to cover the cost of accommodation, air and train transportation from The United States, France, Moldova and Spain for 9 artists.

We will get supplemental grants toward these costs from sponsors solicited by Atelier du Vent.


Where our funding will go: DVD Documentation and SELECT CLIPS FOR ONLINE DOWNLOAD

- We want this to have a larger impact then to only those who can afford to come to Rennes, to SHARE the vision we aim to create documentation of the entire workshop and all of the collaborative performances and art created during these days. 

- The production of this DVD is a very important aspect to this event. The workshop is about sharing, exchange, and the furthering of ideas discussed at Atelier du Vent.  Artists from different countries and different generations will be represented at the space, and we hope to influence other countries and new generations through the production of a DVD, which when edited will then be available as an online download.

------------------

 

 

Any and all contributions are greatly appreciated; please see “Perks” for information on our gifts to you. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Please send this site to artists, collectives, women you know and anyone who needs to be schooled.

If you would like to read more information about the project and women involved please download our PDF, click the "Gallery" tab on the top of the page.  Thank you.

- We want this to have a larger impact then to only those who can afford to come to Rennes, to SHARE the vision we aim to create documentation of the entire workshop and all of the collaborative performances and art created during these days.  
- The production of this DVD is a very important aspect to this event. The workshop is about sharing, exchange, and the furthering of ideas discussed at Atelier du Vent.  Artists from different countries and different generations will be represented at the space, and we hope to influence other countries and new generations through the production of a DVD, which when edited will then be available as an online download.
------------------

 
 
Any and all contributions are greatly appreciated; please see “Perks” for information on our gifts to you. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
 
Please send this site to artists, collectives, women you know and anyone who needs to be schooled.
If you would like to read more information about the project and women involved please download our PDF, click the "Gallery" tab on the top of the page.  Thank you.

story:
Photography As Justice

The idea is simple: put cameras into the hands of children around the world, educate them on how to use the camera and make a good composition, and then set them loose to take photos which are collected into books whose sales benefit the daily work of the NGO’s working with those children.


A Brief History

World Through Their Eyes began after watching the film Born Into Brothels, a documentary about director Zana Briski who went to India and discovered many children at risk of growing up into a life of sexual exploitation. Determined to not let this happen, she took her gifting of photography and spent a year with these children, training them how to take a great photo and eventually some of their work was featured in galleries around the world and the film also won the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature in 2004. 

Inspired, we decided to take cameras to Russia. Having already been working with the Detsky Dom’s (children’s homes) and a transition center for young people for the past couple of years, we chose to put cameras into the hands of the beautiful Russian children and raise money for the transition home through the book sales. In 2008, the first World Through Their Eyes | Russia book was published and is still available on Lulu.com for purchase.


NOW: World Through Their Eyes: Congo

In one month, I have been given the opportunity to travel with a team of friends to Africa. We will be going to the nations of Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda and the D.R. Congo. In Congo, I have been given permission to do the first World Through Their Eyes photobook in Congo! 

 

Here are our needs:

  • 15 Cameras for 15 Students
  • 50 Rolls of 120 Film ($25 for 5)
  • Film processing ($15 per roll)
  • Just 15 people to sponsor $150/each or 10 people to sponsor $200/each.

 

The Impact

When we come home from Africa, we will take the book and make the first World Through Their Eyes book to be done on African soil: World Through Their Eyes | Congo. Every purchase of a book has it's sale divided into two costs: the printing of the book itself and the donation. In this case, all donations after printing costs will go towards the world being done in Congo. Here is what the costs will go towards:

  • Covering the costs of running and operating the Justice Rising schools
  • Helping rehabilitate children in the war-zone and redeeming their childhood
  • Help feed and clothe the men, women and children in Congo's redzone
  • Providing funds to establish businesses that create new livelihoods and improve the community

 

It's a Future-Forward Investment

The cameras we will be purchasing will help us have the equipment we need to do this project in other countries! So far, we are already working on doing projects in Thailand and in India!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • If you know people passionate about photography, justice, Africa, or children, let them know about this project!
  • Maybe you don't have money, but know people that do, tell them about this project! Even coins and dollars can help us!
  • If you know people with connections to cameras who would be willing to donate, let us know at info@worldthroughtheireyes.com. 
  • If you feel like doing an offline-fundraise for this project, let us know here  info@worldthroughtheireyes.com and we will glady support you!

 

Write-Offs 

World Through Their Eyes is NOT a 501C3 nonprofit organization. However, the US government allows you to take up to $500 off your taxes, unclaimed. If you want a write-off, we can give you a receipt, and PayPal and Indiegogo will also provide receipts for you to be able to claim up to $500 off on your taxes come tax time.

 

Thank you all again for taking the time to read this! We haven't been able to get this fair along without your help!
